there are no facilities as described in subsection (1) available within the boundaries, or there are facilities outside the boundaries that are more accessible as described in that subsection;
the chief election officer considers that the location will be more convenient for a majority of electors of the municipality or electoral area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A voting place for an additional general voting opportunity or for an advance voting opportunity may be outside the boundaries of the municipality or electoral area for which the election is being held.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of voting machines

bcl:text.#text: A local government may, by bylaw, provide for the use of automated voting machines, voting recorders or other devices for voting in an election, subject to any requirements, limits and conditions established by regulation under section 168 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) must include the following:

bcl:text.#text: procedures for how to vote, to be used in place of those established by section 129 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the form of ballot, if this is to be different from the form of ballot otherwise required by this Act;

bcl:text.#text: procedures, rules and requirements regarding the counting of votes, if these are to be different from those established by Division 14  of this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bylaw under subsection (1) includes only provisions referred to in subsection (2), to the extent there is an inconsistency between the procedures, rules and requirements established by the bylaw and the procedures, rules and requirements established under this Part, the bylaw prevails.

If a bylaw under subsection (1) includes provisions other than those referred to in subsection (2) and is approved by the minister, to the extent that there is an inconsistency between the procedures, rules and requirements established by the bylaw and the procedures, rules and requirements established under this Part, the bylaw prevails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipal voting divisions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish municipal voting divisions, or
authorize the designated municipal officer or chief election officer to establish municipal voting divisions.

bcl:text.#text: The authority under subsection (1) is subject to any requirements, limits and conditions established by regulation under section 168 .

bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), if municipal voting divisions are established,
may vote on general voting day only at the voting place specified for that voting division.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: electors who reside in a municipal voting division, and
electors who are non-resident property electors in relation to property within the voting division

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The restriction under subsection (3) does not apply to voting at an additional general voting opportunity or a special voting opportunity.

bcl:text.#text: The notice of election under section 99  must include the following additional information if municipal voting divisions are established:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that municipal voting divisions will be used in the election;

that electors residing in a municipal voting division or who are non-resident property electors in relation to property within that voting division will be entitled to vote on general voting day only at the voting place specified for the voting division unless they are voting at an additional general voting opportunity or a special voting opportunity, if any is offered;
either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the boundaries of each municipal voting division and the voting place for each division, or
how electors can obtain information as to where they are entitled to vote on general voting day.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer may provide additional notice to electors in a municipal voting division of the voting place where they are entitled to vote.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Form of ballots

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer must establish the form of ballots to be used in an election.
Without limiting subsection (1), the chief election officer may do either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determine that composite ballots are to be used, on which an elector's votes on 2 or more elections may be indicated;
determine that ballots are to be in the form of a ballot set, in which ballots for 2 or more elections are packaged together.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What must and must not be included on a ballot

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A ballot for an election must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: instructions as to the number of candidates to be elected to the office;
instructions as to the appropriate mark to make a valid vote for a candidate;
the full name of each candidate or, if a candidate specified a different usual name in the nomination documents, this usual name;
if applicable, the name, abbreviation or acronym of the endorsing elector organization for a candidate, as shown on the endorsement documents for the candidate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception, if the name, abbreviation or acronym referred to in subsection (1) (d) is too long to be reasonably accommodated on the ballot, the chief election officer may, after consulting with the authorized principal official of the elector organization, use a shorter name, abbreviation or acronym that, in the opinion of the chief election officer, identifies the elector organization.
A ballot for an election must not include any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an indication that a candidate is holding or has held an elected office;
a candidate's occupation;
an indication of a title, honour, degree or decoration received or held by a candidate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order of names on ballot

bcl:text.#text: Unless a bylaw under section 117  is adopted,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the names of the candidates must be arranged alphabetically by their surnames, and
if 2 or more candidates have the same surname, the names of those candidates must be arranged alphabetically in order of their first given names.

bcl:text: If 2 or more candidates

bcl:text.#text: the chief election officer, after receiving the approval of these candidates, may include on the ballot additional information to assist the electors to identify the candidates, subject to the restrictions under section 115 (3) .

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have the same surnames and given names, or
have names so similar that, in the opinion of the chief election officer, they are likely to cause confusion,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer's decision on the order of names on a ballot is final.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order of names on ballot determined by lot

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, permit the order of names on a ballot to be determined by lot in accordance with this section.
The chief election officer must notify all candidates as to the date, time and place when the determination is to be made.
The only persons who may be present at the determination are the candidates, or their official agents, and any other persons permitted to be present by the chief election officer.
The procedure for the determination is to be as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of each candidate is to be written on a separate piece of paper, as similar as possible to all other pieces prepared for the determination;
the pieces of paper are to be folded in a uniform manner in such a way that the names of the candidates are not visible;

the pieces of paper are to be placed in a container that is sufficiently large to allow them to be shaken for the purpose of making their distribution random, and the container is to be shaken for this purpose;
the chief election officer is to direct a person who is not a candidate or candidate representative to withdraw the papers one at a time;

the name on the first paper drawn is to be the first name on the ballot, the name on the second paper is to be the second, and so on until the placing of all candidates' names on the ballot has been determined.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ballot boxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Ballot boxes for an election may be any box or other appropriate receptacle that is constructed so that ballots can be inserted but not withdrawn unless the ballot box is opened.
Separate ballot boxes must be used for each of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ballots used to vote at required general voting opportunities;
ballots used to vote at additional general voting opportunities;
ballots used to vote at advance voting opportunities;
ballots used to vote at special voting opportunities;
mail ballots used to vote.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A ballot box used at one type of voting opportunity referred to in subsection (2) (a) to (e) may be used again at another voting opportunity of the same type.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Persons who must be present at voting places

bcl:text.in:desc: [persons unable to enter a voting place]
bcl:text.#text: A presiding election official and at least one other election official must be present at all times at each voting place during voting hours, except during a suspension of voting under section 132 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an election official does not attend at a voting place as expected, the presiding election official may appoint a person as an election official in the missing person's place, whether or not this authority has already been given under this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Persons who may be present at voting places

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in this section, a person must not be present at a voting place while voting proceedings are being conducted.
The following persons may be present at a voting place while voting proceedings are being conducted:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: persons who are present for the purpose of voting and persons in the care of those persons;

in:desc: [persons needing assistance to mark their ballots]
bcl:text.#text: persons assisting under section 63  or 131 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: election officials;

the official agent of a candidate in the election and, for each ballot box in use at that time for receiving ballots for that election, one scrutineer for each candidate, unless a bylaw under subsection (3) permits more to be present;
other persons permitted to be present by the presiding election official.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, permit more than one scrutineer for each candidate to be present for each ballot box in use at a voting place while voting proceedings are being conducted, subject to any restrictions and conditions specified in the bylaw.
Other than for the purpose of voting, a candidate must not be present at a voting place or special voting opportunity while voting proceedings are being conducted.

bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsection (6), each person present at a voting place while voting proceedings are being conducted and each candidate representative present at a special voting opportunity must make a solemn declaration to preserve the secrecy of the ballot in accordance with section 123 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (5) does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person attending to vote,
a person in the care of a person attending to vote, or

bcl:text.#text: a peace officer assisting the presiding election official under section 61 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Sealing of ballot boxes containing ballots

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a ballot box is used for ballots, the presiding election official, in the presence of at least one witness, must inspect the ballot box to ensure that it is empty and seal it in such a manner that it cannot be opened without breaking the seal.
After a ballot box is used for ballots, the presiding election official must seal it at the following times in a manner to prevent the addition or withdrawal of ballots:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the close of voting at a voting opportunity;
between each addition of mail ballots;
if the ballot box becomes full while voting proceedings are being conducted;

in:desc: [persons unable to enter a voting place]
bcl:text.#text: if voting proceedings are adjourned under section 62  or suspended under section 132 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to sealing by the presiding election official, candidate representatives are entitled to add their seals for the purposes of this section.

bcl:text.#text: Unless it is to be used again in accordance with section 118 (3) , a ballot box that has been sealed under this section must remain sealed and unopened until the ballots are to be counted under Division 14  of this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a ballot box sealed under subsection (2) is to be used again in the election, the presiding election official must remove the seal in the presence of at least one witness.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time for voting extended

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the start of voting at a place, as set under this Part, is delayed and the presiding election official considers that a significant number of electors would not be able to vote without an extension under this section, that election official may extend the time for the close of the voting but the extension must not permit voting for a longer length of time than would have been permitted had voting not been delayed.

bcl:text: If, at the time set under this Part for the close of voting at a place, there are electors
in order to vote, those electors are entitled to vote and the ballot box must remain unsealed until their ballots are deposited.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: waiting in the place, or
waiting in line outside the place

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No electors other than those referred to in subsection (2) are entitled to vote after the end of the set closing time.

bcl:text.in:desc: [application to court respecting validity of election]
bcl:text.#text: The decision of the presiding election official as to who is or who is not entitled to vote under subsection (2) is final and may not be the basis of an application under section 153 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The presiding election official must notify the chief election officer as soon as possible of any extension of voting under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Voting to be by secret ballot

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Voting at an election must be by secret ballot.

Each person present at a place at which an elector exercises the right to vote, including persons present to vote, and each person present at the counting of the vote must preserve the secrecy of the ballot and, in particular, must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: interfere with a person who is marking a ballot;
attempt to discover how another person voted;
communicate information regarding how another person voted or marked a ballot;
induce a person, directly or indirectly, to show a ballot in a way that reveals how the person voted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer must ensure that each voting place has at least one area that is arranged in such a manner that electors may mark their ballots screened from observation by others and without interference.
An elector may not be required in any legal proceedings to reveal how the elector voted in an election.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Each elector may vote only once

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not vote more than once in the same election.

For the purpose of ensuring compliance with subsection (1), the presiding election official must ensure that a record is maintained of all persons who receive ballots at the voting proceedings for which the presiding election official is responsible.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements before elector may be given a ballot

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must meet the following basic requirements in order to obtain a ballot:

bcl:text.#text: if the person is not shown on the list of registered electors as having registered in advance, the person must register in accordance with section 72  or 73 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is shown on the list of registered electors as having registered in advance, the person must sign a written declaration that the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote in the election, and
has not voted before in the same election;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person must sign the list of registered electors or the voting book, as directed by the presiding election official, giving

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person's name,
the person's present residential address, and
if the person is a non-resident property elector, the address of the real property in relation to which the person is voting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As applicable, the following additional requirements must be met in order for a person to obtain a ballot:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at a special voting opportunity, the person must also sign a written declaration that the person is entitled to vote at that time and stating the circumstances that entitle the person to vote;
if the person is challenged under section 126, the person must also meet the requirements of subsection (3) of that section;

bcl:text.#text: if it appears that another person has already voted in that person's name, the person must also meet the requirements of section 127 (2) ;
if the person requires assistance to mark the ballot, the requirements of section 131 (3)  must also be met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Once the requirements of subsections (1) and (2) have been met, the election official must give the elector the ballot or ballots to which that elector is entitled.
A person who does not meet the requirements of subsections (1) and (2) is not entitled to vote and must not be given a ballot.

A voting book or list of registered electors may be prepared in such a manner that all the applicable requirements of subsection (1) or (2), or both, may be met by entries on the voting book or list of registered electors.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Challenge of elector

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirements before elector may be given a ballot]
bcl:text.#text: A person's right to vote may be challenged in accordance with this section at any time during the procedures under section 125 (1) and (2)  to obtain a ballot up until the time the person receives the ballot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A challenge may be made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only in person by an election official, a candidate representative or an elector of the municipality or electoral area for which the election is being held, and
only on the basis that the person proposing to vote

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is not entitled to vote, or

bcl:text.#text: has contravened section 161 (3) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to receive a ballot, a person whose right to vote has been challenged must either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide evidence satisfactory to the presiding election official that the person is entitled to vote, or
make a solemn declaration before the presiding election official as to the person's entitlement to vote.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The solemn declaration required by subsection (3) (b) must state that the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meets all the qualifications to be registered as an elector of the municipality or electoral area,
is either registered as an elector of that municipality or electoral area or is applying at this time to be registered,
is in fact the person under whose name the person is registered or registering as an elector,

bcl:text.#text: has not contravened section 161 , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has not voted before in the same election and will not vote again in the same election.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The presiding election official must keep a record indicating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the person was challenged,
the name of the person who made the challenge, and
how the person challenged satisfied the requirement of subsection (3).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: If another person has already voted under an elector's name

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirements before elector may be given a ballot]
bcl:text.#text: This section applies if an elector meets the requirements of section 125  but the voting book or list of registered electors indicates that another person has already voted using the name of the elector.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to obtain a ballot, the person asserting the right to vote as the named elector must either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide evidence satisfactory to the presiding election official that the person is the named elector, or

bcl:text.#text: make a solemn declaration described in section 126 (4)  as to the person's entitlement to vote as the named elector.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The presiding election official must keep a record indicating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a second ballot was issued in the name of the elector, and
any challenge under section 126 of the person who obtained the second ballot.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replacement of spoiled ballot

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an elector unintentionally spoils a ballot before it is deposited in a ballot box, the elector may obtain a replacement ballot by giving the spoiled ballot to the presiding election official.
The presiding election official must immediately mark as spoiled a ballot replaced under subsection (1) and retain the spoiled ballot for return to the chief election officer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to vote by ballot

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After receiving a ballot, an elector must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed without delay to a voting compartment provided,
while the ballot is screened from observation, mark it by making a cross in the blank space opposite the name of the candidate or candidates for whom the elector wishes to vote,
fold the ballot to conceal all marks made on it by the elector,
leave the voting compartment without delay,
deposit the ballot in the appropriate sealed ballot box, and
leave the voting place without delay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An election official may and, if requested by the elector, must explain to an elector the proper method for voting by ballot.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: One person to a voting compartment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: While an elector is in a voting compartment to mark a ballot, no other person may observe or be in a position to observe the ballot being marked.
As exceptions to subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person assisting an elector under section 131 may be present with the elector, and
if the presiding election official permits, a person who is in the care of an elector may be present with the elector.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Persons needing assistance to mark their ballots

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to electors who are unable to mark a ballot because of physical disability or difficulties with reading or writing.
An elector referred to in subsection (1) may be assisted in voting by an election official or by a person accompanying the elector.
In order to receive a ballot to be marked under this section, the following requirements must be met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person assisting must sign a written statement giving

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the assisting person's name and residential address,
the name and residential address of the elector being assisted, and
if the elector being assisted is a non-resident property elector, the address of the real property in relation to which the elector is voting;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who is not an election official must make a solemn declaration before the presiding election official that the person will

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: preserve the secrecy of the ballot of the elector being assisted,
mark the ballot in accordance with the wishes of the elector, and
refrain from attempting in any manner to influence the elector as to how the elector should vote;

bcl:text.#text: if assistance is needed because the elector needs a translator to be able to read the ballot and the instructions for voting, the person assisting must make a solemn declaration in accordance with section 63 (3) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The assisting person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must accompany the elector to the voting compartment or other place to be used for voting,
must mark the ballot in accordance with the directions of the elector, and
may, in the presence of the elector, fold the ballot and deposit it in the ballot box.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Candidates, candidate representatives and financial agents must not assist in marking a ballot.
A person does not vote by assisting under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Persons unable to enter a voting place

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to electors who come to a voting place to vote but who are unable to enter the voting place because of physical disability or impaired mobility.
An elector referred to in subsection (1) may request to vote at the nearest location to the voting place to which the elector has access.

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirements before elector may be given a ballot]
bcl:text.#text: If a request is made, the presiding election official or another election official designated by the presiding election official must attend the elector at the nearest location to the voting place for the purpose of allowing the elector to meet the requirements under section 125  to obtain a ballot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The election official must ensure that the elector's marked ballot is placed in the appropriate ballot box, taking whatever steps the official considers necessary to maintain the secrecy of the ballot.
The presiding election official may temporarily suspend voting proceedings in order to allow an elector to vote under this section.

bcl:text.in:desc: [persons who may be present at voting place]
bcl:text.#text: The presiding election official may have separate ballot boxes available for the purposes of this section, and these ballot boxes are not to be considered to be ballot boxes in use for the purposes of determining the number of candidate representatives who may be present at a voting place under section 120 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When and where counting is to be done

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The counting of the votes on ballots for an election must not take place until the close of general voting for the election, but must take place as soon as practicable after this time.

The counting of the votes on ballots used for general voting is to be conducted at the voting place where the ballot boxes containing them are located unless the chief election officer directs that the counting is to take place at another location.
The counting of the votes on ballots other than those referred to in subsection (2) is to be conducted at a place specified by the chief election officer.

The chief election officer must notify the candidates in an election of any place other than a voting place referred to in subsection (2) at which the counting of the votes for the election is to be conducted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Who may be present at counting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A presiding election official and at least one other election official must be present while counting proceedings are being conducted.
Candidates in an election are entitled to be present when counting proceedings for the election are being conducted.

For each place where the votes on ballots for an election are being counted, one candidate representative for each candidate in the election is entitled to be present at each location within that place where ballots are being considered.

Persons other than those referred to in subsections (2) and (3) and election officials taking part in the counting may not be present when counting proceedings are being conducted, unless permitted by the presiding election official.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Who does the counting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The counting of the votes on ballots for an election must be conducted by the presiding election official or, except as limited by subsection (2), by other election officials under the supervision of the presiding election official.
The presiding election official must personally deal with all ballots

bcl:text.in:desc: [rules for accepting votes or rejecting ballots]
bcl:text.#text: rejected under section 139 , or
objected to under section 140 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Opening of ballot boxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As the first step in the counting of the votes on ballots in a ballot box, the ballot box is to be opened by an election official in the presence of at least one witness.
If the seals on a ballot box are not intact when it is opened under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the ballots in the ballot box must not be combined under section 137, and
the ballots in the ballot box must be counted separately and a separate ballot account and separate ballot packages for the ballots must be prepared.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Combination of ballots for counting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After ballot boxes are opened under section 136, the ballots in them may be combined in accordance with this section.
The election official responsible for the counting may combine ballots in different ballot boxes together in a single ballot box as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ballots in a ballot box used at a required general voting opportunity may be combined with ballots in other ballot boxes used at the same required general voting opportunity;
ballots in a ballot box used at an additional general voting opportunity may be combined with ballots in other ballot boxes used at the same or another additional general voting opportunity;
ballots in a ballot box used at an advance voting opportunity may be combined with ballots in other ballot boxes used at the same or another advance voting opportunity;
ballots in a ballot box used for a special voting opportunity may be combined with ballots in other ballot boxes used at the same or another special voting opportunity;
ballots in a ballot box used for mail ballots may be combined with ballots in other ballot boxes used for mail ballots;

if some of the ballots in a ballot box are for a different election than the one for which the ballot box was intended, the election official may combine the ballots that do not belong in the ballot box with ballots in the appropriate ballot box.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of preserving the secrecy of the ballot, if there would be fewer than 25 ballots in a ballot box after combination under subsection (2), the presiding election official may combine those ballots with ballots in any other ballot box.
Except for combination under this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the votes on each class of ballots referred to in subsection (2) must be counted separately from the votes on ballots in any other class, and
a separate ballot account under section 141 and separate ballot packages under section 142 must be prepared for each class of ballots referred to in subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedures for counting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All ballots in each ballot box must be considered in accordance with this section.
As each ballot for an election is considered, it must be placed in such a manner that the persons present at the counting are able to see how the ballot is marked.

bcl:text.#text: Unless rejected under section 139 (4) , a mark referred to in section 139 (1) on a ballot for an election must be accepted and counted as a valid vote.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Counting must proceed as continuously as is practicable and the votes must be recorded.
The presiding election official must endorse ballots to indicate the following as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the ballot was rejected under section 139 in relation to an election;
that the rejection of the ballot was objected to under section 140;
that a mark on the ballot was accepted as a valid vote but the acceptance was objected to under section 140.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An endorsement under subsection (5) must be made at the time the presiding election official considers the ballot and in such a manner that it does not alter or obscure the elector's marking on the ballot.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rules for accepting votes and rejecting ballots

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are marks that are to be accepted and counted as valid votes for an election unless the ballot is rejected under subsection (4):

bcl:text.#text: a mark of the type required by section 129 (1) (b) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tick mark that is placed in the location required by section 129 (1) (b);

a mark of the type required by section 129 (1) (b) that is out of or partly out of the location on the ballot in which it is required to be put by that provision, as long as the mark is placed in such a manner as to indicate clearly the intent of the elector to vote for a particular candidate;
a tick mark that is placed as described in paragraph (c) of this subsection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A mark on a ballot other than a mark referred to in subsection (1) must not be accepted and counted as a valid vote.

bcl:text.#text: If a ballot is in the form of a composite ballot under section 114 (2) (a) , for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) of this section each portion of the ballot that deals with a single election is to be considered a separate ballot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Ballots must be rejected as invalid in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a ballot must be rejected in total if it appears that the ballot physically differs from the ballots provided by the chief election officer for the election;
a ballot must be rejected in total if there are no marks referred to in subsection (1) on the ballot;
a ballot must be rejected in total if the ballot is uniquely marked, or otherwise uniquely dealt with, in such a manner that the elector could reasonably be identified;
a ballot must be rejected in total if more than one form of mark referred to in subsection (1) is on the ballot;
a ballot is to be rejected in relation to an election if there are more marks referred to in subsection (1) for the election on the ballot than there are candidates to be elected.

bcl:text.#text: In the case of a ballot that is part of a ballot set under section 114 (2) (b) , the ballot is not to be rejected under subsection (4) (a) solely on the basis that the ballot is part of an incomplete ballot set or that the ballot has become separated from its ballot set.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Objections to the acceptance of a vote or the rejection of a ballot

bcl:text.#text: A candidate or candidate representative may object to a decision to accept a vote or reject a ballot, with the objection recorded in accordance with section 138 (5) and (6) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An objection must be made at the time the ballot is considered.

bcl:text.#text: The decision of the presiding election official regarding the acceptance of a vote or the rejection of a ballot may not be challenged except as provided in this section and the decision may be changed only by the chief election officer under section 145  or on a judicial recount.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ballot account

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Once all counting at a place is completed, ballot accounts for each election must be prepared in accordance with this section and signed by the presiding election official.
A ballot account must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the office to be filled by the election;
the number of valid votes for each candidate in the election;
the number of ballots received by the presiding election official from the chief election officer for use at the voting opportunity;
the number of ballots given to electors at the voting opportunity;
the number of ballots for which marks were accepted as valid votes for the election without objection;

bcl:text.in:desc: [objection to acceptance of vote or rejection of ballot]
bcl:text.#text: the number of ballots for which marks were accepted as valid votes, subject to an objection under section 140 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number of ballots rejected as invalid without objection;
the number of ballots rejected as invalid, subject to an objection under section 140;
the number of spoiled ballots that were cancelled and replaced under section 128;
the number of unused ballots;

bcl:text.in:desc: [combination of ballot boxes to preserve secrecy of the ballot]
bcl:text.#text: the number of ballots added under section 137 (3)  to the ballots for which the ballot account is prepared;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number of ballots not accounted for.

bcl:text.in:desc: [delivery of election materials to chief election officer]
bcl:text.#text: A copy of the ballot account must be prepared and signed by the presiding election official and included with the election materials under section 143 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Packaging of ballots

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The presiding election official, or an election official under the supervision of the presiding election official, must separately package each of the following classes of ballots for delivery to the chief election officer:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ballots that were rejected in total, subject to an objection regarding the rejection;
ballots that were rejected in part, subject to an objection regarding the rejection or regarding the acceptance of a vote;
ballots that were subject to an objection regarding the acceptance of a vote, unless included in a package under paragraph (b);
ballots that were rejected in total without objection;
ballots that were rejected in part without objection to the rejection or the acceptance of a vote;
ballots for which all votes were accepted without objection;
spoiled ballots that were cancelled and replaced under section 128;
unused ballots.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each ballot package must be clearly marked as to its contents and sealed by the presiding election official.
Candidates and candidate representatives present at the proceedings are entitled to add their seals to a ballot package.
If ballot boxes are used as ballot packages, they must be sealed in accordance with section 121.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Delivery of election materials to chief election officer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the ballot accounts are completed and the sealed ballot packages prepared, the following must be placed in ballot boxes from which the counted ballots were taken:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sealed ballot packages, if these are not ballot boxes themselves;
the copy of the ballot account prepared under section 141 (3);
the voting books;
any copies of the list of registered electors used for the purposes of voting proceedings;
any records required under this Part to be made during voting proceedings;
any stubs for ballots given to electors;
any solemn declarations taken and any signed written statements required under this Part in relation to voting proceedings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The ballot boxes in which the election materials are placed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be sealed in accordance with section 121, and

bcl:text.#text: must not be opened until after the declaration of the results of the election under section 146, except by the chief election officer for the purposes of section 145 (4) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If votes for an election are counted at more than one place, the presiding election official must deliver to the chief election officer, in the manner instructed by the chief election officer, the original of the ballot account, the sealed ballot boxes and all other ballot boxes in the custody of the presiding election official.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preliminary election results

bcl:text.#text: The chief election officer may announce preliminary results of an election before the determination under section 145  is completed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Preliminary results must be based on the ballot accounts prepared under section 141, determined by calculating the total number of valid votes for each candidate in the election as reported on the ballot accounts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Determination of official election results

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As the final counting proceeding subject to a judicial recount, the chief election officer must determine the results of an election in accordance with this section.

The chief election officer must notify the candidates in an election of the date, time and place when the determination is to be made and the candidates are entitled to be present when those proceedings take place.
The chief election officer must begin the determination by reviewing the ballot accounts or by having them reviewed by election officials authorized by the chief election officer.

The chief election officer may verify the results indicated by a ballot account by counting the votes on all or some of the ballots for the election, including reviewing the decision of a presiding election official regarding the acceptance of some or all of the votes or the rejection of some or all of the ballots.

The chief election officer may be assisted in counting under subsection (4) by other election officials, but must personally make all decisions regarding the acceptance of votes or the rejection of ballots that were subject to objection under section 140.

The chief election officer may reverse a decision of another election official regarding the acceptance of a vote or the rejection of a ballot made at the original consideration of the ballot and, if this is done, the chief election officer must endorse the ballot with a note of the reversal.

The chief election officer or an election official authorized by the chief election officer must either mark on the original ballot accounts any changes made under this section or prepare a new ballot account of the results of the counting under subsection (4).

On the basis of the ballot accounts, as amended or prepared under subsection (7) if applicable, the chief election officer must prepare a statement of the total number of votes for each candidate in the election.
A decision of the chief election officer under this section may be changed only on a judicial recount.

If a ballot box or ballot package is opened for the purposes of subsection (4), the contents must be replaced and it must be resealed during any adjournment and at the end of the review of the contents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Declaration of official election results

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before 4 p.m. on the fourth day following the close of general voting, the chief election officer must declare the results of the election as determined under section 145.
The results must be declared as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an election for an office to which one person is to be elected, the chief election officer must declare elected the candidate who received the highest number of valid votes for the office;

in the case of an election for an office to which more than one person is to be elected, the chief election officer must declare elected the candidates who received the highest number of valid votes for the office, up to the number of candidates to be elected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception, if a candidate cannot be declared elected because there is an equality of valid votes for 2 or more candidates, the chief election officer must declare that the election is to be referred to a judicial recount.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When elected candidates may take office

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A candidate declared elected under section 146 is not entitled to make the oath of office until the time period for making an application for a judicial recount has ended.

If an application for a judicial recount of an election is made, a candidate declared elected in the election is not entitled to make the oath of office until the recount has been completed and the candidate's election has been confirmed unless permitted by the court under subsection (3).

The Provincial Court may, on application, authorize a candidate who has been declared elected to make the oath of office if the court is satisfied that the candidate's election will not be affected by the results of the judicial recount.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for judicial recount

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application may be made in accordance with this section for a judicial recount, to be undertaken by the Provincial Court, of some or all of the votes in an election.
Except as provided in subsection (5), an application may be made only on one or more of the following bases:

bcl:text.in:desc: [rules for accepting votes and rejecting ballots]
bcl:text.#text: that votes were not correctly accepted or ballots were not correctly rejected as required by the rules of section 139 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a ballot account does not accurately record the number of valid votes for a candidate;

bcl:text.#text: that the final determination under section 145  did not correctly calculate the total number of valid votes for a candidate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The time period during which an application may be made is limited to the time between the declaration of official election results under section 146 and 9 days after the close of general voting.
The application may be made only by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an elector of the municipality or electoral area for which the election was held,
a candidate in the election or a candidate representative of a candidate in the election, or
the chief election officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application must be made by the chief election officer if, at the end of the determination of official election results under section 145, a candidate cannot be declared elected because there is an equality of valid votes for 2 or more candidates.
The document commencing an application must set out briefly the facts on which the application is based and must be supported by affidavit as to those facts.
At the time an application is commenced, a time must be set for the recount that is adequate to allow the court to complete the recount within the time limit set by section 149.
The person making the application must notify affected persons

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by immediately notifying the chief election officer and the affected candidates in the election, if any, that a judicial recount will be conducted at the time set under subsection (7), and
within 24 hours of filing the document commencing the application, by delivering to these persons copies of that document, the accompanying affidavit and a notice of the time for the recount.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Judicial recount procedure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A judicial recount must be conducted in accordance with this section and completed by the end of the thirteenth day after the close of general voting.

The person who made the application for the recount, the chief election officer, the candidates in the election and the official agents and counsel of the candidates are entitled to be present at a judicial recount and other persons may be present only if permitted by the court.

The chief election officer must bring to the recount all ballot accounts used for the determination of official election results under section 145 and the ballot boxes containing the ballots for which the recount is requested.

in:desc: [rules for accepting votes and rejecting ballots]
bcl:text.#text: In conducting a recount, the court must open the ballot boxes containing the ballots for which the recount is requested, count those ballots in accordance with sections 138  and 139  and confirm or change the ballot accounts in accordance with the counting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In its discretion, the court may count other ballots in addition to those for which the recount was requested and, for this purpose, may require the chief election officer to bring other ballot boxes.
The court may appoint persons to assist in the recount.
As exceptions to the obligation to conduct a recount in accordance with the other provisions of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person who made the application for the recount, the chief election officer and the candidates present at the recount agree, the court may restrict the ballots to be recounted as agreed by these persons at that time, or

if the court determines on the basis of the ballot accounts that the results of a recount of the ballots, if it were conducted, would not materially affect the results of the election, the court may confirm the results of the election and take no further action under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise directed by the court, the ballot boxes at a judicial recount must remain in the custody of the chief election officer.

bcl:text.#text: During a recess or adjournment of a judicial recount and after the completion of the judicial recount, the ballot boxes must be resealed in accordance with section 121  by the person having custody of them and may be additionally sealed by other persons present.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Results of judicial recount and orders as to costs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the completion of a judicial recount, the court must declare the results of the election.

bcl:text.in:desc: [power of court on application respecting validity of election]
bcl:text.#text: The results declared under subsection (1) or following a determination by lot under section 151 are final, subject only to a declaration under section 155  that the election was invalid, and may not be appealed.

All costs, charges and expenses of and incidental to an application for judicial recount, including the recount and any other proceedings following from the application, must be paid by the local government, the applicant and the persons notified of the application under section 148 (8) , or any of them, in the proportion the court determines.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the conclusion of a judicial recount, the court must make an order for the purposes of subsection (3) having regard to any costs, charges or expenses that, in the opinion of the court, were caused by vexatious conduct, unfounded allegations or unfounded objections on the part of the applicant or the persons who were given notice.
In relation to subsection (3), the court may order that the costs be determined in the same manner as costs within the meaning of the Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Determination of results by lot if tie vote after judicial recount

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, provide that, if at the completion of a judicial recount the results of the election cannot be declared because there is an equality of valid votes for 2 or more candidates, the results will be determined by lot in accordance with this section rather than by election under section 152.

If a bylaw under subsection (1) applies and there is an equality of votes as described in that subsection, the results of the election are to be determined, as the conclusion of the judicial recount, by lot between those candidates in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of each candidate is to be written on a separate piece of paper, as similar as possible to all other pieces prepared for the determination;
the pieces of paper are to be folded in a uniform manner in such a way that the names of the candidates are not visible;

the pieces of paper are to be placed in a container that is sufficiently large to allow them to be shaken for the purpose of making their distribution random, and the container is to be shaken for this purpose;
the court is to direct a person who is not a candidate or candidate representative to withdraw one paper;
the court is to declare elected the candidate whose name is on the paper that was drawn.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Runoff election if tie vote after judicial recount

bcl:text.#text: If at the completion of a judicial recount the results of the election cannot be declared because there is an equality of valid votes for 2 or more candidates, a runoff election must be held in accordance with this section unless a bylaw under section 151  applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in this section, this Part applies to a runoff election under subsection (1).
The candidates in the runoff election are to be the unsuccessful candidates in the original election who do not withdraw, and no new nominations are required or permitted.

As soon as practicable after the judicial recount, the chief election officer must notify the candidates referred to in subsection (3) that an election is to be held and that they are candidates in the election unless they deliver a written withdrawal to the chief election officer within 3 days after being notified.
The chief election officer must set a general voting day for the runoff election, which must be on a Saturday no later than 50 days after the completion of the judicial recount.

bcl:text.#text: If advance registration would otherwise be permitted, the closed period under section 71 (4)  extends until the day after the close of general voting for the election under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No new list of registered electors is required and sections 77 to 80 do not apply.

bcl:text.#text: So far as reasonably possible, election proceedings must be conducted as they were for the original election except that, if voting under section 112  was used for the original election, it is not necessary to use this for the election under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (8), so far as reasonably possible, voting opportunities equivalent to those provided for the original election must be held and, for these, no new bylaws under this Part are required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application to court respecting validity of election

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The right of an elected candidate to take office or the validity of an election may not be challenged except by an application under this section.
An application may be made in accordance with this section to the Supreme Court for a declaration regarding the right of a person to take office or the validity of an election.
The time limit for making an application is 30 days after the declaration of official election results under section 146.
An application may be made only by a candidate in the election, the chief election officer or at least 4 electors of the municipality or electoral area for which the election was held.
An application may be made only on one or more of the following bases:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a candidate declared elected was not qualified to hold office at the time the candidate was elected or, between the time of the election and the time for taking office, the candidate has ceased to be qualified to hold office;
that an election should be declared invalid because it was not conducted in accordance with this Act or a regulation or bylaw under this Act;

bcl:text.#text: that an election or the election of a candidate should be declared invalid because section 161 , 162  or 163 (2) (a)  was contravened.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a restriction on subsection (5) (b), an application may not be made on any basis for which an application for judicial recount may be or may have been made.

At the time the petition commencing an application is filed, the court registry must set a date for the court to hear the application, which must be at least 10 days but no later than 21 days after the date the petition is filed.

As soon as practicable, but no later than 2 days after a petition is filed, the person making the application must serve the petition and the notice of hearing on the municipality or regional district for which the election was held.

bcl:text.#text: If a candidate affected by an application files a written statement renouncing all claim to the office to which the candidate was elected, the court may permit the petition for the application to be withdrawn unless it is based on an allegation that the candidate who has renounced the office contravened section 161  or 162 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Hearing of application

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Supreme Court must hear and determine an application under section 153 as soon as practicable and, for these purposes, must ensure that the proceedings are conducted as expeditiously as possible.

bcl:text.#text: If the application is based on a claim that section 161  or 162  was contravened, the evidence regarding that claim must be given orally by witnesses rather than by affidavit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power of court on application

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the hearing of an application under section 153 regarding the qualification of an elected candidate to take office, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: declare that the candidate is confirmed as qualified to take and hold office,
declare that the candidate is not qualified to hold office and that the office is vacant, or
declare that the candidate is not qualified to hold office and that the candidate who received the next highest number of valid votes is elected in place of the disqualified candidate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the hearing of an application under section 153 regarding the validity of an election, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: declare that the election is confirmed as valid,
declare that the election is invalid and that the offices that were to be filled in the election are vacant,
declare that the election of a candidate is invalid and that the office is vacant, or
declare that the election of a candidate is invalid and that another candidate is elected in place of that candidate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The court must not declare an election invalid by reason only of an irregularity or failure to comply with this Act or a regulation or bylaw under this Act if the court is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the election was conducted in good faith and in accordance with the principles of this Act, and
the irregularity or failure did not materially affect the result of the election.

bcl:text.#text: The court may confirm the election of a candidate in relation to which the court finds there was a contravention of section 161  or 162  if the court is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the candidate did not contravene the applicable section, and
the contravention did not materially affect the result of the election.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the court declares that a candidate is not qualified to hold office or that the election of a candidate is invalid, the court may order the candidate to pay the municipality or regional district for which the election was held an amount of money not greater than $20 000 towards the expenses for the election required to fill the vacancy.

If the court makes a declaration under subsection (1) (c) or (2) (d) that another candidate is elected, the candidate who is replaced ceases to be entitled to take or hold the office and the other candidate declared elected is entitled to take the office.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Legal costs of application

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the court declares that a candidate is not qualified to hold office or that an election is invalid, the costs, within the meaning of the Supreme Court Civil Rules, of the persons who made the application under section 153 must be paid promptly by the municipality or regional district for which the election was held.

The court may order that costs to be paid under subsection (1) may be recovered by the municipality or regional district from any other person as directed by the court in the same manner as a judgment of the Supreme Court.
Except as provided in subsection (1), the costs of an application are in the discretion of the court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Status of elected candidate

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person affected by an application under section 153 who has been declared elected is entitled to take office and to vote and otherwise act in the office unless the court declares the candidate disqualified and the office vacant.

If a person who is declared disqualified to hold office by the Supreme Court appeals the decision, the appeal does not operate as a stay of the declaration and the person is disqualified pending the final determination of the appeal.

bcl:text.in:desc: [disqualified candidate required to pay money towards cost of by-election]
bcl:text.#text: If the person is declared qualified to hold office on the final determination of the appeal, the court may order that any money paid under section 155 (5)  be repaid with interest as directed by the court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is declared qualified to hold office on the final determination of an appeal is entitled,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the term of office for which the person was elected has not ended, to take office for any unexpired part of the term and, for this purpose, any person elected or appointed to the office since the declaration of disqualification ceases to hold office at the time the person declared qualified takes office, and
if the term of office for which the person was elected is expired, to be nominated for and to be elected to office at any following election if otherwise qualified.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Report of election results

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after the declaration of official election results under section 98 for an election by acclamation or under section 146 for an election by voting, the chief election officer must submit a report of the election results to the local government.
In the case of an election by voting, the report under subsection (1) must include a compilation of the information on the ballot accounts for the election.

bcl:text.in:desc: [application to court respecting validity of election]
bcl:text.#text: If the results of the election are changed by a judicial recount or on an application under section 153  after the report under subsection (1) of this section is submitted, the designated local government officer must submit to the local government a supplementary report reflecting the changed results.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Publication of election results

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after elected candidates have taken office, the designated local government officer must submit the names of the elected officials to the Gazette for publication.
Within 30 days after persons appointed to local government have taken office, the designated local government officer must submit the names of the appointed officials to the Gazette for publication.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Retention and destruction of election materials

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Until the end of the period for conducting a judicial recount, the chief election officer

bcl:text.in:desc: [delivery of election materials to chief election officer]
bcl:text.#text: must keep the sealed ballot packages delivered under section 143  in the officer's custody,
is responsible for retaining the nomination documents and endorsement documents for the election, other than the written disclosure under the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is responsible for retaining the remainder of the election materials delivered under section 143.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the end of the period for conducting a judicial recount, the designated local government officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is responsible for retaining the materials referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (c), and
must retain the nomination documents and endorsement documents referred to in subsection (1) (b) until 5 years after the general voting day for the election to which the documents relate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) (b) applies to documents retained in respect of the 2014 general local election and all subsequent elections.

bcl:text.#text: The designated local government official is not in contravention of subsection (2) (b) if, under section 76  of the , the local government is required to provide the documents to the BC chief electoral officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: From the time of the declaration of the official election results under section 146 until 30 days after that date, the following election materials must be available for public inspection at the local government offices during regular office hours:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the voting books used for the election;
any copies of the list of registered electors used for the purposes of voting proceedings;
any records required under this Part to be made during voting proceedings;
any solemn declarations taken and any signed written statements or declarations required under this Part in relation to voting proceedings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before inspecting materials referred to in subsection (3), a person other than a local government officer or employee acting in the course of duties must sign a statement that the person will not inspect the materials except for the purposes of this Part.
The designated local government officer must ensure that the statements referred to in subsection (4) are kept until after general voting day for the next general local election.
A person who inspects materials referred to in subsection (3) must not use the information in them except for the purposes of this Part.

bcl:text.#text: Despite section 95 (3) of the  and section 27 (7) of the , a person who is entitled to inspect the materials referred to in subsection (3) of this section is not entitled to obtain a copy of those materials.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following materials must be destroyed as soon as practicable following 56 days after the declaration of the official election results under section 146:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the ballots used in the election;
any stubs for ballots used in the election;
any copies of the list of registered electors used for the purposes of voting proceedings;
the voting books used in the election;
any solemn declarations and any written statements or declarations in relation to voting proceedings, other than those used for the registration of electors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As exceptions, subsection (8) does not apply

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if otherwise ordered by a court, or

bcl:text.in:desc: [application to court respecting validity of election]
bcl:text.#text: if the materials relate to an election that is the subject of an application under section 153 , until the final determination of that application or the court authorizes their destruction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided under this Act, a person may not inspect a ballot.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Canvassing in housing cooperative, strata and rental properties

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means an individual authorized in writing by a candidate to canvass electors and distribute candidate information on the candidate's behalf;
has the same meaning as in the ;
means printed information about

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a candidate, and
if applicable, the elector organization that has endorsed the candidate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following individuals and organizations must not unreasonably restrict access to residential property by a candidate or an authorized canvasser for the purposes of canvassing electors and distributing candidate information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a housing cooperative or individual acting on behalf of a housing cooperative;
a landlord or individual acting on behalf of a landlord;
a strata corporation or individual acting on behalf of a strata corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: While canvassing electors or distributing candidate information at a residential property, access to which is controlled by any of the individuals or organizations referred to in subsection (2), a candidate or authorized canvasser must produce government-issued photo identification and either proof of candidacy or a candidate's written authorization to canvass electors and distribute candidate information, as applicable, at the request of any of the following individuals:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a resident of the property;
an individual referred to in subsection (2) (a), (b) or (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) applies from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. during the campaign period.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Vote buying

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  includes money, gift, valuable consideration, refreshment, entertainment, office, placement, employment and any other benefit of any kind.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not pay, give, lend or procure inducement for any of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to induce a person to vote or refrain from voting;
to induce a person to vote or refrain from voting for or against a particular candidate;
to reward a person for having voted or refrained from voting as described in paragraph (a) or (b);
to procure or induce a person to attempt to procure the election of a particular candidate, the defeat of a particular candidate or a particular result in an election;
to procure or induce a person to attempt to procure the vote of an elector or the failure of an elector to vote.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not accept inducement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to vote or refrain from voting,
to vote or refrain from voting for or against a particular candidate, or
as a reward for having voted or refrained from voting as described in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not advance, pay or otherwise provide inducement, or cause inducement to be provided, knowing or with the intent that it is to be used for any of the acts prohibited by this section.
A person must not offer, agree or promise to do anything otherwise prohibited by this section.
A person prohibited from doing something by this section must not do the prohibited act directly, indirectly or by another person on behalf of the first person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Intimidation

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means to do or threaten to do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use force, violence or restraint against a person;
inflict injury, harm, damage or loss on a person or property;
otherwise intimidate a person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not intimidate another person for any of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to persuade or compel a person to vote or refrain from voting;
to persuade or compel a person to vote or refrain from voting for or against a particular candidate;
to punish a person for having voted or refrained from voting as described in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not, by abduction, duress or fraudulent means, do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impede, prevent or otherwise interfere with a person's right to vote;
compel, persuade or otherwise cause a person to vote or refrain from voting;
compel, persuade or otherwise cause a person to vote or refrain from voting for a particular candidate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person prohibited from doing something by this section must not do the prohibited act directly, indirectly or by another person on behalf of the first person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other election offences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to nominations, a person must not do any of the following:

bcl:text.#text: contravene section 87 (4) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before or after an election, purport to withdraw a candidate from an election without authority to do so or publish or cause to be published a false statement that a candidate has withdrawn;

bcl:text.#text: before or after an election, purport to withdraw the endorsement of a candidate by an elector organization except as provided in section 95 (b) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to voting, a person must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vote at an election when not entitled to do so;

bcl:text.#text: contravene section 124 (1)  regarding voting more than once in an election;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain a ballot in the name of another person, whether the name is of a living or dead person or of a fictitious person;

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirement to preserve secrecy of the ballot]
bcl:text.#text: contravene section 123 (2)  regarding the secrecy of the ballot.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to ballots and ballot boxes, a person must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without authority supply a ballot to another person;
without authority print or reproduce a ballot or a paper that is capable of being used as a ballot;
without authority take a ballot out of a place where voting proceedings are being conducted;
put in a ballot box, or cause to be put in a ballot box, a paper other than a ballot that the person is authorized to deposit there;

bcl:text.#text: interfere with voting under section 112  contrary to the applicable bylaw and regulations;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without authority destroy, take, open or otherwise interfere with a ballot box or ballots.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to voting proceedings, a person must not do any of the following at or within 100 metres of a building, structure or other place where voting proceedings are being conducted at the time:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: canvass or solicit votes or otherwise attempt to influence how an elector votes;
display, distribute, post or openly leave a representation of a ballot marked for a particular result in the voting;
post, display or distribute

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: election advertising, or
any material that identifies a candidate or elector organization, unless this is done with the authorization of the chief election officer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: carry, wear or supply a flag, badge or other thing indicating that the person using it is a supporter of a particular candidate, elector organization or result in the voting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to any matter or proceeding to which this Part applies, a person must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide false or misleading information when required or authorized under this Part to provide information;
make a false or misleading statement or declaration when required under this Part to make a statement or declaration;

bcl:text: inspect or access under this Part
or use the information from any of them, except for purposes authorized under this Act;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a list of registered electors,
nomination documents,
disclosure statements or supplementary reports, or

bcl:text.in:desc: [delivery of election materials to chief election officer]
bcl:text.#text: other election materials referred to in section 143 ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be present at a place where voting or counting proceedings are being conducted, unless authorized under this Part to be present;

bcl:text.#text: interfere with, hinder or obstruct an election official or other person in the exercise or performance of the election official's or other person's powers, duties or functions under this Part or the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is an election official must not contravene this Part with the intention of affecting the result or validity of an election.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prosecution of organizations and their directors and agents

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An act or thing done or omitted by an officer, director, employee or agent of an organization within the scope of the individual's authority to act on behalf of the organization is deemed to be an act or thing done or omitted by the organization.

If an organization commits an offence under this Part, an officer, director, employee or agent of the organization who authorizes, permits or acquiesces in the offence commits the same offence, whether or not the organization is convicted of the offence.

A prosecution for an offence under this Part may be brought against an unincorporated organization in the name of the organization and, for these purposes, an unincorporated organization is deemed to be a person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit for starting prosecution
bcl:section.bcl:text: The time limit for laying an information to commence a prosecution respecting an offence under this Part is one year after the date on which the act or omission that is alleged to constitute the offence occurred.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Penalties

bcl:text.#text: A person who contravenes section 161  or 162  is guilty of an offence and is liable to one or more of the following penalties:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a fine of not more than $10 000;
imprisonment for a term not longer than 2 years;
disqualification from holding office in accordance with subsection (2) of this section for a period of not longer than 7 years.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Disqualification under subsection (1) (c) is disqualification from holding office as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a local government;

bcl:text.#text: on the council of the City of Vancouver or on the Park Board established under section 485 of the ;
as a trustee under the ;
as a trustee on a board of education, or as a regional trustee on a francophone education authority, under the .
A person or unincorporated organization who contravenes section 163  is guilty of an offence and is liable to one or both of the following penalties:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a fine of not more than $5 000;
imprisonment for a term not longer than one year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any penalty under this Division is in addition to and not in place of any other penalty provided in this Part.
A person or unincorporated organization is not guilty of an offence under this Part if the person or organization exercised due diligence to prevent the commission of the offence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ministerial orders in special circumstances

bcl:text.#text: If the minister considers that special circumstances regarding an election or assent voting require this, the minister may make any order the minister considers appropriate to achieve the purposes of this Part or Part 4 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), an order under this section may provide an exception to or modification of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this Act or a regulation or bylaw under this Act, or

bcl:text.#text: the  or a regulation under that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority under subsection (2) includes authority to

bcl:text.#text: extend a time period or establish a new date in place of a date set under this Act or the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give any other directions the minister considers appropriate in relation to this.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations respecting elections in special circumstances

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister considers that special circumstances exist that affect, or are anticipated to affect, the administration or conduct of election proceedings or proceedings for assent voting, the minister may make regulations providing an exception to or modification of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one or more provisions of this Part or Part 4,
a regulation under this Part or Part 4, or
a bylaw under this Act.
