bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may make a regulation under subsection (1) only if satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the benefit of making the regulation is proportionate to the benefit of the continued application of the enactment as it is before the making of the regulation, and
the regulation is necessary to prevent, respond to, or alleviate the effects of the special circumstances.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regulation under subsection (1) must specify a date of repeal of the regulation that is no later than one year after the date the regulation is made.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Election regulations

bcl:text.#text: In relation to this Part, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the , including regulations for any matter for which regulations are contemplated by this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:text.#text: prescribing information that must be included under section 70  in an application for registration as an elector, which may be different for resident electors and non-resident property electors;

in:desc: [how to register as a resident elector at the time of voting]
[how to register as a non-resident property elector at the time of voting]
bcl:text.#text: prescribing classes of documents that may be accepted as evidence for the purpose of section 72  or 73 ;
for the purposes of section 82 ,

bcl:text: which may be different for different specified municipalities and regional districts;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: deeming a described class of persons to be employees of a municipality or regional district, and
excepting a described class of persons as excluded from the definition of "employee",

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing information that must be included in the notice of nomination under section 85, which may be different for municipalities and regional districts and may be different for municipal elections at large and on the basis of a neighbourhood constituency;

bcl:text.in:desc: [other information to be provided by candidate]
bcl:text.#text: prescribing additional information or material required to be provided under section 90 (1) (e) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2021-5-79.]
establishing requirements, limits and conditions in relation to voting by mail ballot under section 110, which may be different for municipalities and regional districts;

bcl:text.#text: establishing requirements, limits and conditions in relation to voting under section 112 , which may be different for different specified municipalities and regional districts;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing requirements, limits and conditions in relation to municipal voting divisions under section 113, which may be different for municipalities of different population sizes;
prescribing one or more alternative forms in which a specified solemn declaration must be made.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Part

bcl:text.#text: The definitions in Part 3  apply to this Part and, in addition, in this Part:
means voting conducted for a municipality or regional district on a matter referred to in section 170;
means an area for which the applicable assent voting is to be conducted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assent voting to be conducted in same manner as election

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Part applies to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: voting on a bylaw or other matter for which assent of the electors is required;
voting on a bylaw or other matter for which the local government is authorized by this or another Act to obtain the assent of the electors, unless otherwise provided by the authorizing enactment;

bcl:text.#text: voting on a referendum under section 336 .
Except as otherwise provided, Part 3  applies in relation to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: voting referred to in subsection (1) as if the assent voting for the voting area were an election for an election area, and
non-election assent voting advertising as if it were election advertising.

bcl:text.#text: For certainty, Division 18  of Part 3 applies in relation to assent voting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How assent of the electors is obtained

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided in this Act, assent of the electors to a bylaw or other matter is obtained only if a majority of the votes counted as valid are in favour of the bylaw or question.

If a bylaw that requires the assent of the electors does not receive that assent, a bylaw for the same purpose may not be submitted to the electors within a period of 6 months from the last submission except with the minister's approval.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Who may vote at assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to vote at assent voting, a person must meet both of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person must meet the qualifications of section 65 as a resident elector, or section 66 as a non-resident property elector, in relation to the voting area for which the assent voting is to be conducted;
the person must be registered in accordance with subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To vote at assent voting, a person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be registered, on or before the date established under subsection (4) (a) if applicable, as an elector of the municipality or electoral area to which the person's qualifications referred to in subsection (1) (a) relate, or
register immediately before voting,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as an elector of the municipality or electoral area to which the person's qualifications referred to in subsection (1) (a) relate, or
as an elector for the purposes of the assent voting only.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Registration referred to in subsection (2) (b) (ii) is effective only for the assent voting being conducted at that time.

If assent voting is not being held at the same time as an election for a municipality or electoral area in which the assent voting is to be conducted and advance registration for the municipality or electoral area is available under section 71,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chief election officer must establish a date after which registration as an elector of the municipality or electoral area will not entitle the person to vote at the assent voting and the person must instead register under subsection (2) (b) of this section in order to vote, and
the following sections do not apply to the municipality or electoral area in relation to the assent voting:

bcl:text.#text: section 77 (3), (6) and (7) ;
section 79 ;
section 80 .

If subsection (4) applies, at least 6 days but not more than 30 days before the date established under paragraph (a) of that subsection, the chief election officer must give notice in accordance with section 50  of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: how a person may register in advance, and
the date after which advance registration will not apply for the purposes of the assent voting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Person may vote only once
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person may vote only once on a question submitted for assent voting, even though the voting is conducted in more than one voting area and the person is entitled to vote in relation to more than one voting area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General voting day for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An authority in or under this or any other Act for the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector to require a bylaw or other matter to be submitted for assent of the electors includes the authority to set a general voting day for obtaining that assent, subject to the restriction that general voting day must be on a Saturday.
Unless general voting day is set under subsection (1), the chief election officer must set general voting day for assent voting to be on a Saturday in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a bylaw that is directed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector to be submitted for the assent of electors, not more than 80 days after the date of the direction;

bcl:text.#text: in the case of a bylaw or other matter for which an alternative approval process was provided, not more than 80 days after the deadline for receiving elector responses under section 86  of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to paragraph (b) of this subsection, in the case of a bylaw requiring the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a minister or the inspector, not more than 80 days after the day of the approval or, if there is more than one approval required, of the last approval;
in the case of other bylaws, not more than 80 days after the day the bylaw receives third reading;
in the case of another matter, not more than 80 days after adoption of the authorizing bylaw or resolution.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Arrangements for assent voting

bcl:text.#text: In order for a bylaw under this Part or a bylaw referred to in section 56  to apply in relation to assent voting, the bylaw must be adopted at least 6 weeks before general voting day for the assent voting.
Unless subsection (3) or (4) applies, voting opportunities for the assent voting are those established under Part 3  for the assent voting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Voting opportunities in a voting area for assent voting must be the same as those for an election being held at the same time as the assent voting if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality or regional district for which the election is being held is conducting the assent voting for the voting area, and
the voting area for the assent voting is all or part of the election area for the election.

bcl:text.#text: As an exception to section 107 (1) (b)  for a voting area with a population of more than 5 000, a regional district board may, by bylaw, limit advance voting opportunities to the required advance voting opportunity under section 107 (1) (a) if all the following circumstances apply to the assent voting:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mail ballot voting is available under section 110;
[Repealed 2021-16-7.]
the voting area is part, but not all, of an electoral area;
the assent voting is not being held at the same time as an election for the electoral area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of assent voting

bcl:text.#text: In place of a notice of election under section 99 , at least 6 days but not more than 30 days before general voting day for assent voting, the chief election officer must issue a notice of assent voting under this section in accordance with section 50 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to subsection (1), throughout the period between the thirtieth day before general voting day and general voting day, the notice of assent voting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be available for public inspection in the local government offices, during their regular office hours, of each municipality or regional district in which the assent voting is to be conducted, and
may be made available at other locations and times as the chief election officer considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of voting must include the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the question that is to be voted on;
the voting area;
the qualifications required to be met in order to vote as an elector for the assent voting;

bcl:text.#text: the date of general voting day, the voting places established under section 105  for that day and the voting hours for those places;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the documents that will be required in order for a person to register as an elector at the time of voting;
[Repealed 2019-5-20.]

bcl:text.#text: if applicable, information required to be included under section 113 (5)  regarding municipal voting divisions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the assent voting is on a bylaw submitted for the assent of the electors or is authorized by a bylaw, the notice of voting must also include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: either a copy of the bylaw or, if approved by the local government, a synopsis of the bylaw in accordance with subsection (5);
if a synopsis of the bylaw is included, a statement that the synopsis is not an interpretation of the bylaw;
the dates, times and places at which the bylaw may be inspected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A synopsis under subsection (4) (a) must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in general terms, the intent of the bylaw,
the area that is the subject of the bylaw, and
if applicable, the amount of the borrowing authorized by the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If subsection (4) applies, a full copy of the bylaw must be available for inspection by electors

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the local government offices, during their regular office hours, of each municipality or regional district in which the assent voting is to be conducted, and
at each place where voting is conducted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice of voting may also include any other information the chief election officer considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ballots for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A ballot for assent voting must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indicate the appropriate mark to make a valid vote indicating assent or dissent, and
be in a question form to which the elector may indicate assent or dissent by making the appropriate mark opposite the word "Yes" or the word "No".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided under this or another Act, separate ballots must be prepared for each question that is to be voted on.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When counting for assent voting is to be done

bcl:text.in:desc: [when and where counting is to be done]
bcl:text.#text: As an exception to section 133 , the counting of the vote for assent voting may be held at a later time set by the chief election officer, as long as the ballots are counted before the date of the declaration of the assent voting results under section 146.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a later time for counting is set under subsection (1), the presiding election official must ensure that the ballots are sealed in ballot boxes in accordance with section 121 and are delivered to the chief election officer with the materials referred to in section 143.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special procedures if voting is conducted by more than one local government

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to assent voting on a regional district bylaw or other regional district matter that is to be conducted by more than one local government.
The regional district board must, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish the question to be used for all the voting, and

bcl:text.#text: if applicable, set the date for the required advance voting day under section 107 (1) (b)  for all voting areas other than a voting area referred to in section 175 (3) or (4) .

in:desc: [requirements for advance assent voting to be same as for election]
bcl:text.#text: Except for a voting area referred to in section 175 (3) , the bylaws under sections 106, 108 and 109  of a local government other than the regional district board do not apply and, instead, the regional district may, by bylaw, establish voting opportunities under those sections for one or more voting areas for the assent voting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional district board must appoint

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a regional voting officer for the assent voting, and
a deputy regional voting officer for the assent voting who, if the regional voting officer is absent or unable to act, must perform the duties and has the powers of the regional voting officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The regional voting officer has the following duties and powers:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to arrange for the coordination of the proceedings throughout the regional district;
to set the general voting day for all voting throughout the regional district;
to arrange for the preparation of the ballots for the voting;
to direct the chief election officers for the local governments regarding the form and manner of notices that are required or authorized by this Act regarding the voting;

bcl:text.#text: to make the final determination of assent voting results under section 145  and the final declaration of assent voting results under section 146  based on the results determined by the chief election officers of the local governments;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to appoint the scrutineers for the final determination of assent voting results and any judicial recount in accordance with section 184 (4) and (5);

bcl:text.#text: to apply to the minister for an order under section 167 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is a conflict between this section or an authority under this section and another provision of this Act or an authority under this Act, this section or the authority under it prevails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other general matters

bcl:text.#text: Notices under this Part may be combined with notices under Part 3 , as it applies to elections or to assent voting, as long as the requirements of all applicable sections are met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 159, requiring the publication of election results in the Gazette, does not apply to assent voting.

bcl:text.#text: Regulations under section 168 , as it applies to assent voting, may be different for different types of assent voting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scrutineers for the question and scrutineers against the question

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Scrutineers for the question in assent voting and scrutineers against the question must be appointed under section 184 if applications in accordance with section 183 are received from persons who wish to volunteer for the positions.

Only persons entitled to vote as electors in the assent voting are entitled to act as scrutineers for the assent voting, but election officials must not be appointed as scrutineers for the assent voting.

bcl:text.#text: Unless a bylaw under subsection (4) applies, only one scrutineer for the question and one scrutineer against the question may be present at each place at which scrutineers are entitled by Part 3  to be present.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, permit additional scrutineers to be present at proceedings referred to in subsection (3), subject to any restrictions and conditions in the bylaw.
As a limit on the authority under subsection (4), a bylaw under that subsection may not provide for different entitlements for scrutineers for the question and scrutineers against the question.
The absence of a scrutineer from a place where proceedings for assent voting are being conducted does not invalidate anything done in relation to the assent voting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of applications to volunteer as scrutineer

bcl:text.#text: Not more than 30 days before the application period begins, the chief election officer must issue a notice under this section in accordance with section 50 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice must include the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the question that is to be voted on;
the dates, times and places at which applications for scrutineers will be received;
how interested persons can obtain information on the requirements and procedures for making an application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice may include any other information the chief election officer considers appropriate.

In addition to subsection (1), from the sixth day before the application period begins until the close of the application period, the notice must be available for public inspection in the local government offices, during their regular office hours, of each municipality or regional district in which the assent voting is being conducted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applications to volunteer to act as scrutineer for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer must establish a 10-day time period during which applications to act as a scrutineer will be received, in order that appointments may be made before the first voting opportunity.
As an exception to subsection (1), if general voting day for assent voting is the general voting day for an election, the period for receiving applications

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be established under subsection (1), and
if it is not established under subsection (1), is the nomination period referred to in section 84.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application to act as a scrutineer for assent voting must be signed by the applicant and contain the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the full name of the person applying;
the address to which the person applying wishes to have notices sent;
if required by the chief election officer, a telephone number at which the person applying may be contacted;
a statement that the applicant is entitled to vote as an elector in the assent voting and is entitled to act as a scrutineer for the assent voting;
a statement as to whether the applicant is in favour of the question or opposed to the question;
any other information required to be included by a regulation under subsection (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to be appointed as a scrutineer, the application to volunteer as a scrutineer must be received by the chief election officer, or a person designated by the chief election officer for this purpose, before the end of the application period under subsection (1).
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing information that must be included in an application under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of scrutineers for assent voting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chief election officer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the basis of the applications received in accordance with section 183, appoint applicants in favour of the question as scrutineers for the question and applicants opposed to the question as scrutineers against the question, and

bcl:text.#text: assign scrutineers to each place at which scrutineers are entitled to be present under Part 3 .

bcl:text.in:desc: [scrutineers for the question and scrutineers against the question]
bcl:text.#text: If the number of applicants on one side of the question is fewer than the maximum allowed under section 181 ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all these applicants must be appointed as scrutineers in accordance with subsection (1) of this section, and
a scrutineer may be assigned to more than one place if the hours or days of the proceedings at which scrutineers are entitled to be present allow this.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there are more applicants on one side of the question than the maximum allowed under section 181, the following rules apply:

bcl:text.in:desc: [order of names on ballot determined by lot]
bcl:text.#text: the scrutineers for that side must be determined by lot in accordance with the procedure used in section 117 (a) to (d) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chief election officer must notify all applicants of the date, time and place of the determination by lot and these applicants are entitled to be present;
names are to be drawn until the number of names drawn is equivalent to the number of scrutineers to be appointed;
the persons whose names are drawn must be appointed as scrutineers in accordance with subsection (1) of this section;

in the discretion of the chief election officer, additional names may be drawn of persons who may be appointed if applicants appointed under paragraph (d) of this subsection are unable to act as scrutineers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the appointments under subsection (1), one scrutineer for the question and one scrutineer against the question are entitled to be present at the final determination under section 145 of the assent voting and at any judicial recount of the assent voting.
Scrutineers referred to in subsection (4) must be appointed in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appointment must be made from among those persons who acted as scrutineers under subsection (1) and who indicate that they wish to be considered for the appointment;
if, for a side of the question, more than one person wishes to be considered for appointment, the choice must be made by lot in accordance with subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A scrutineer appointment must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made in writing,
state the name and address of the person appointed,
state the proceedings to which the scrutineer has been assigned under this section and the dates, times and places where these are to be conducted, and
be signed by the chief election officer.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Regional Districts: Purposes, Principles and Interpretation

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purposes of regional districts
bcl:section.bcl:text: Recognizing that regional districts are an independent, responsible and accountable order of government within their jurisdiction, the purposes of a regional district include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: providing good government for its community,
providing the services and other things that the board considers are necessary or desirable for all or part of its community,
providing for stewardship of the public assets of its community, and
fostering the current and future economic, social and environmental well-being of its community.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Principles for regional district-provincial relations
bcl:section.bcl:text: The relationship between regional districts and the Provincial government in relation to this Act is based on the following principles:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cooperative relations between the Provincial government and regional districts are to be fostered in order to efficiently and effectively meet the needs of the citizens of British Columbia;
regional districts need the powers that allow them to draw on the resources required to fulfill their responsibilities;
notice and consultation is needed for Provincial government actions that directly affect regional district interests;
the Provincial government recognizes that different regional districts and their communities have different needs and circumstances and so may require different approaches;
the independence of regional districts is balanced by the responsibility of the Provincial government to consider the interests of the citizens of British Columbia generally.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Broad interpretation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The powers conferred on regional districts and their boards under this Act must be interpreted broadly in accordance with the purposes of this Act and in accordance with regional district purposes.

bcl:text: If

the general power must not be interpreted as being limited by that specific power, but that aspect of the general power that encompasses the specific power may only be exercised subject to any conditions and restrictions established in relation to the specific power.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an enactment confers a specific power on a regional district or board in relation to a matter, and
the specific power can be read as coming within a general power conferred under this Act,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of municipal provisions to regional districts

bcl:text.#text: If a provision of this Act or the  respecting municipalities is made applicable to regional districts, references in the provision are to be read as follows:

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: References to regional district officers
bcl:section.bcl:text: Words in an enactment referring to a regional district officer, by name of office or otherwise, also apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the officer's deputy, and
any person designated by the board to act in the officer's place.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Continuation of regional districts

bcl:text.#text: Every regional district incorporated before Part 24 of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 290, came into force on July 1, 1989 is continued as a corporation and is vested with the powers conferred on it by this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All bylaws validly adopted by a board before the Part referred to in subsection (1) came into force continue in force.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Continuation of regional parks and trails

bcl:text.#text: The repeal of the  does not alter or cancel an interest in, a right to or the park status of regional parks and regional trails set aside and dedicated under that Act.
If, at the time of repeal of the , a regional district provides a regional park or regional trail as a service under letters patent that refer to the , S.B.C. 1965, c. 43,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the regional district may continue to provide this service in accordance with this Act as if the service were provided under the authority of an establishing bylaw for a service, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [special rules in relation to continuation of older services]
bcl:text.#text: section 341 (3) to (6)  of this Act applies as if the service were a continued service under that section.

Any reserve fund established by a regional district under the  must be continued on the repeal of that Act as a reserve fund under this Act held for the purpose of acquiring regional parks or regional trails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Continuation of regulatory authority restrictions in relation to previous bylaws

bcl:text.#text: This section applies to bylaws under Part 24 of the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 323,
that were in force on August 30, 2000, being the date on which section 803 of the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 323, as it then was, was repealed by the , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that had received first reading before that date and were adopted within one year after that date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), provisions in the bylaws that are the exercise of regulatory authority do not apply within a municipality unless the bylaw expressly provides this application.

bcl:text.#text: If, on the date referred to in subsection (1), letters patent conferred exclusive jurisdiction on a board as referred to in section 803 (1) (b) of the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 323, before the repeal referred to in subsection (1) of this section, the authority of the regional district under that section 803 (1) (b) continues as if the section had not been repealed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regional district corporations
bcl:section.bcl:text: Each regional district is a corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board as governing body

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The governing body of a regional district is its board.
The powers, duties and functions of a regional district are to be exercised and performed by its board unless this or any other Act provides otherwise.
A board, in exercising or performing the powers, duties and functions conferred on it by an enactment, is acting as the governing body of the regional district.
Despite any change in its membership, the board of a regional district is a continuing body and may complete any proceedings started but not completed before the change.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Area of jurisdiction
bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may exercise or perform its powers, duties and functions only within the boundaries of the regional district unless authorized under this or another Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Composition and voting rights

bcl:text.#text: Subject to section 253 (1) , a board consists of municipal directors and electoral area directors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The number of votes to which each municipality and each electoral area is entitled is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number obtained by dividing the population of the municipality or electoral area by the voting unit specified in the letters patent, or
if the number obtained by division under paragraph (a) is not a whole number, the next greater whole number.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For purposes of voting power on a board, a change in the population of a municipality or an electoral area as established by census takes effect in the year following the year in which that census was taken.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipal directors: number of directors and assignment of votes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The number of directors to which each municipality is entitled is

bcl:text.#text: the number obtained by dividing the number of votes to which that municipality is entitled under section 196 (2)  by 5 or, if otherwise specified in letters patent for the regional district, by the other number specified, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the number obtained by division under paragraph (a) is not a whole number, the next greater whole number.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The votes of a municipality referred to in subsection (1) are to be equally distributed by the council among the directors from that municipality.
If equal distribution is not possible under subsection (2),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the council must assign the municipality's votes to each director as evenly as possible, but in no case may the difference between the maximum and minimum number of votes assigned be greater than one, and
the municipal corporate officer must notify the regional district corporate officer of the assignment made under paragraph (a).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment and term of office for municipal directors

bcl:text.#text: After the first appointment under section 41 (2) (e) , each municipal director is to be appointed at pleasure by the council from among its members.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The term of office of a municipal director

bcl:text.#text: begins when the person takes office in accordance with section 202 (3) , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: continues until the earliest of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: another director taking office in the original director's place;
the director ceasing to be a member of the council before the next general local election;
November 30 in the year of a general local election.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Election and term of office for electoral area directors

bcl:text.#text: After the first election under section 41 (2) (f) , elections for electoral area directors are to be conducted in accordance with Part 3 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The term of office of an electoral area director elected at the time of the general local election

bcl:text.#text: begins on the first Monday after November 1 following the election or when the person takes office in accordance with section 202 (3) , whichever is later, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ends immediately before the first Monday after November 1 in the year of the next general local election or when the director's successor takes office, whichever is later.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Alternate directors: municipalities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The council of a municipality may appoint a council member as an alternate director.
The alternate director may take the place of, vote and generally act in all matters for an absent municipal director, including a matter delegated to that director by the board.
If there is more than one municipal director, the authority under subsection (1) may be exercised either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by specifying, for each municipal director, the council member who is the alternate director for that municipal director, or
by appointing a number of alternate directors and establishing a system to determine which alternate director is to act in the place of any absent municipal director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a restriction on subsection (3) (b), at any one time, an alternate director may act in place of only a single municipal director.
If the council appoints an alternate director, the municipal corporate officer must notify the regional district corporate officer of the appointment in writing.

An alternate director holds office as alternate director until another council member is appointed as a replacement and the regional district corporate officer has been notified of the new appointment.

If the seat of a municipal director becomes vacant through resignation, disqualification or death, the alternate director appointed under subsection (1) becomes the municipal director in place of the director whose seat became vacant until a new director is appointed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Alternate directors: electoral areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An electoral area director must appoint an alternate director as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appointment must be made within 60 days of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the electoral area director being elected, or
the office of the alternate director becoming vacant through resignation, disqualification or death;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person appointed must have the qualifications necessary to be nominated as a director for the electoral area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appointment under subsection (1) takes effect when

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appointment has been approved in writing by 2 electors who reside in the electoral area that the director represents, and
the director notifies, in writing, the regional district corporate officer of the appointment of the alternate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an electoral area director does not appoint an alternate director in accordance with subsection (1), the board must, by resolution, appoint a person who has the qualifications necessary to be nominated as a director for that electoral area as alternate director for the electoral area director.
An appointment under subsection (3) takes effect when the resolution making the appointment is passed, and the alternate director so appointed holds office until the next general local election.
If the office of an electoral area director becomes vacant through resignation, disqualification or death,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the alternate director holds the office until that person's successor takes office following the next election for the office, or

if the alternate director is unable or unwilling to hold office as director, the board must, by resolution, appoint another person who has the qualifications to be nominated as a director for the electoral area and that person holds the office as provided in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On behalf of an absent electoral area director, the alternate director appointed under this section may take the place of, vote and generally act in all matters for the absent electoral area director, including in relation to a matter delegated to that director by the board.

The electoral area director who appointed an alternate director may appoint, as a replacement for the alternate director, another person who has the qualifications necessary to be nominated as a director for that electoral area.

An alternate director appointed by an electoral area director holds office as alternate director until a replacement is appointed under subsection (7) or until the next general local election, whichever is earlier.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Oath or affirmation of office for board members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person elected or appointed to office on a board must make an oath or solemn affirmation of office within the following applicable time limit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an electoral area director elected by acclamation, within 50 days after the date set for general voting day had an election by voting been required;
in the case of an electoral area director elected by voting, within 45 days after the declaration of the results of the election;

bcl:text.in:desc: [appointment if an insufficient number of candidates are elected]
bcl:text.#text: in the case of a person appointed to an electoral area under section 100 , within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a person appointed as municipal director, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment;

in the case of a person appointed as an alternate director, within 45 days after the effective date of the appointment or the first board meeting or board committee meeting at which the person acts in that capacity, whichever is latest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person required to make an oath or solemn affirmation of office under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must make the oath or solemn affirmation before a judge of the Court of Appeal, Supreme Court or Provincial Court, a justice of the peace, a commissioner for taking affidavits for British Columbia, the regional district corporate officer or the chief election officer, and
must obtain the completed oath or solemn affirmation, or a certificate of it, from the person administering the oath or affirmation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person takes office on a board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time the term of office begins if, at this time, the person produces or has produced the completed oath or solemn affirmation of office, or the certificate of it, to the regional district corporate officer, or
at any later time that the person produces the completed oath or solemn affirmation of office, or the certificate of it, to that officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person, other than a person appointed as an alternate director, does not make the required oath or solemn affirmation of office within the time limit established by subsection (1), the person is disqualified from holding office as follows until the next general local election:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a local government;

bcl:text.#text: on the council of the City of Vancouver or on the Park Board established under section 485 of the ;
as a trustee under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, establish an oath or solemn affirmation of office for the purposes of this section, which may be different for different types of office.
If no bylaw under subsection (5) applies, the oath or solemn affirmation of office to be made is that prescribed by regulation.
A person taking office on a board may also make an oath of allegiance.

Once a board member takes office, the member is entitled to hold that office through its term and to vote and otherwise act in the office during that time unless the member resigns or becomes disqualified.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Resignation from office

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board member may resign from office only by delivering a written resignation to the regional district corporate officer.
A resignation becomes effective when it is received by the corporate officer, even if a later date is set out in the resignation, and may not be revoked after the time it is received.

The corporate officer must notify the board of a resignation at the next meeting of the board after the resignation is received or, if there are no other board members, the corporate officer must notify the minister.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director disqualification for failure to attend meetings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a board member is disqualified from holding office in accordance with subsection (3) if the member is absent from board meetings for whichever of the following is the longer time period:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 60 consecutive days;
4 consecutive regularly scheduled board meetings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The disqualification under subsection (1) does not apply if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the absence is due to illness or injury,
the absence is with leave of the board, or

bcl:text.#text: the member is on a leave of absence under section 109.3  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Disqualification under subsection (1) is disqualification until the next general local election from holding office

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a local government,

bcl:text.#text: on the council of the City of Vancouver or on the Park Board established under section 485 of the , or
as a trustee under the .
The following provisions of the  apply to regional districts:
Division 6  of Part 4 ;
Division 6.1  of Part 4;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Challenge of Council Member Qualification for Office]
bcl:text.#text: Division 7  of Part 4;
Division 8  of Part 4;

bcl:text.in:desc: [regulations in relation to Division 6 of Part 4]
bcl:text.#text: section 282 (2) (e) ;
section 117 .
For the purpose of subsection (1), a reference to a delegate in section 102 (1) (c)  of the  is to be read as a reference to a delegate under section 229  of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Voting to be in accordance with this Division unless other rules apply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Except as otherwise provided under this or another Act, all resolutions and every reading and the adoption, amendment or repeal of regional district bylaws must be voted on and decided in accordance with this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General rules: voting on resolutions and bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A resolution or the reading, adoption, amendment or repeal of a regional district bylaw must be decided by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a majority of the votes cast, and
voting in accordance with this Division.

bcl:text: Each director who
must vote on the matter and must cast all available votes for the same objective.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is present at the time of a vote, and
is entitled to vote on the matter

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a director who is entitled to vote does not indicate how the director votes, the director is deemed to have voted in the affirmative.
If the votes on a question, including the vote of the person presiding, are equal, the question is defeated.
If, except for this subsection, only one director would be entitled to vote, each director who is present

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote, and
has one vote.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General rule: each director has one vote

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to voting on a resolution or the reading, adoption, amendment or repeal of a bylaw, each director who is present

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote, and
has one vote.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), voting on the following matters must be in accordance with that subsection:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing bylaws for services;
bylaws exercising a regulatory authority in relation to a regulatory service;
resolutions and bylaws establishing services for which no establishing bylaw is required;
resolutions and bylaws on the general conduct of the board's business, including bylaws under

bcl:text.#text: section 225 ,
section 226 (1) or (2) , or
section 227 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: resolutions dispensing with the consent of an electoral area director under

bcl:text.#text: section 347 (3) , or
that section as it applies under section 349 (2)  or 407 (3) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [appointment of representative in relation to service disputes]
bcl:text.#text: resolutions appointing a director under section 355 (2) (c) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [exclusion of property under creditor protection from apportionment]
bcl:text.#text: resolutions and bylaws to exclude the determined value of eligible property from the apportionment for an eligible service under section 382 ;
subject to section 212 , resolutions and bylaws under Part 13 ;
subject to section 213 , resolutions and bylaws under Part 14 , other than regulatory service bylaws referred to in paragraph (b) of this subsection.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special rule: weighted voting on the administration and operation of services

bcl:text.#text: On all resolutions and every reading and the adoption, amendment or repeal of all bylaws respecting the administration and operation of a service, other than the service referred to in section 338 (2) (a) , each director who is present and who represents a participating area for the service

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [weighted votes for municipalities and electoral areas]
bcl:text.#text: subject to the establishing bylaw for the service, has the number of votes assigned to that director under section 196 (2) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), voting on the following matters must be in accordance with that subsection:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bylaws imposing fees or charges;

bcl:text.#text: bylaws under section 388 (2)  providing for the preparation of an assessment roll;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bylaws exercising a regulatory authority, other than bylaws exercising a regulatory authority in relation to a regulatory service.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special rule: weighted voting on financial matters

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On all resolutions and every reading and the adoption, amendment or repeal of all bylaws referred to in subsection (2), each director who is present

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [weighted votes for municipalities and electoral areas]
bcl:text.#text: has the number of votes assigned to that director under section 196 (2) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Voting on resolutions and bylaws on the following matters must be in accordance with subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorizing persons to enter into contracts on behalf of the regional district;
authorizing the acquisition, expropriation or disposal of real property;

bcl:text.#text: adopting the financial plan under section 374 ;
authorizing borrowing and liabilities under Division 6  of Part 11 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special rule: weighted voting for Metro Vancouver

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following sections do not apply to the Metro Vancouver Regional District:

bcl:text.in:desc: [default rule: each director has one vote]
bcl:text.#text: section 208 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [exception: weighted voting on the administration and operation of services]
bcl:text.#text: section 209 ;
section 210 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the Metro Vancouver Regional District, on all resolutions and every reading and the adoption, amendment or repeal of all bylaws, except as otherwise provided, each director who is present and, if the resolution or bylaw is in respect of a service, who represents a participating area for that service,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [weighted votes for municipalities and electoral areas]
bcl:text.#text: subject to the establishing bylaw for the service, has the number of votes assigned to that person under section 196 (2) .

bcl:marginalnote.#text: Special rules in relation to Part 13

bcl:text.#text: Except as provided in subsection (2), if a resolution or bylaw under Part 13  is in relation to a regional growth strategy for an area that is less than the entire regional district, the directors who may vote are only those who represent a municipality or electoral area all or part of which is subject to the regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The voting rule in subsection (1) does not apply to votes on the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: initiation of the regional growth strategy;
boundary changes for the area to which the regional growth strategy is to apply;

bcl:text.in:desc: [coordination of activities to implement regional growth strategy]
bcl:text.#text: implementation agreements under section 451 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: acceptance of a regional growth strategy for an adjoining regional district.

bcl:marginalnote.#text: Special rules in relation to Part 14

bcl:text.in:desc: [municipality sharing in some regional district costs for Part 14 services]
bcl:text.#text: The following apply in relation to an agreement under section 381 (2) :

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the director for the municipality is not entitled to vote on the resolution or bylaw authorizing the regional district to enter into the agreement;

as soon as the agreement has been entered into, the director for that municipality is not entitled to vote on any resolution or bylaw authorizing the regional district to enter into any other agreement under that section;

bcl:text.#text: while the agreement is in force, the director for that municipality is not entitled to vote on any resolution or bylaw under Part 14  except in accordance with the agreement.
The following apply in relation to a municipality that has given notice under section 381 (3) :

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as soon as the notice has been given, the director for the municipality is not entitled to vote on any resolution or bylaw authorizing the regional district to enter into an agreement under section 381 (2);

bcl:text.#text: effective the year following the year in which the notice is given and continuing until the municipality again participates in the service, the director for that municipality is not entitled to vote on any resolution or bylaw under Part 14 except, if applicable, in relation to participation under section 381 (6) or (7) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other special voting rules
bcl:section.bcl:text: Without limiting exceptions to the voting rules established by this Division, the following are provisions establishing other voting rules that apply in specific circumstances:

bcl:text.in:desc: [waiver of special meeting notice: unanimous vote]
bcl:text.#text: section 220 (3) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [bylaw adopted at same meeting as third reading: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 228 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [delegation of board power, duty or function: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 230 (1) ;
section 233 (3) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [termination of a regional district officer: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 241 (2) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [assistance for conservation of heritage property: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 276 (2) ;
section 295 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [approval vote for entire proposed service area: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 342 (4) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [establishing bylaw approval — dispensing with electoral area director consent: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 347 (3) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment or repeal of establishing bylaw — dispensing with electoral area director consent: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 349 (2) ;
section 391 (3) ;
section 392 (2) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [repayment of heritage property tax exemptions: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 393 (5) ;
section 394 (2) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [repayment of riparian property tax exemptions: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 395 (5) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment or repeal of loan authorization bylaw — dispensing with electoral area director consent: 2/3 votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 406 (3) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Part 14 — variation of time limit to reapply for bylaw amendment or permit: 2/3 vote of eligible local government members]
bcl:text.#text: section 460 (3) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Part 15 — variation of time limit to reapply for bylaw amendment or permit: 2/3 of votes cast]
bcl:text.#text: section 590 (2) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair and vice chair of board

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the first meeting held after November 1 in each year, the board must elect a chair and a vice chair.
The vice chair has, during the absence, illness or other disability of the chair, all the powers of the chair and is subject to all rules applicable to the chair.

If the chair and the vice chair are not present at a meeting of the board, the directors present may elect an acting chair who, during that meeting, has all the powers of the chair and is subject to all rules applicable to the chair.
For the purposes of elections under this section, each director present at the meeting has one vote in each election for an office.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Responsibilities of chair

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair is the head and chief executive officer of the regional district.
In addition to the chair's powers and duties as a board member, the chair has the following duties:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to see that the law is carried out for the improvement and good government of the regional district;
to communicate information to the board;
to preside at board meetings when in attendance;

to recommend bylaws, resolutions and measures that, in the chair's opinion, may assist the peace, order and good government of the regional district in relation to the powers conferred on the board by an enactment;
to direct the management of regional district business and affairs;

in:desc: [chair to direct and inspect officers and employees]
bcl:text.#text: to direct the conduct of officers and employees in accordance with sections 239  and 240 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair may require board reconsideration of a matter

bcl:text.in:desc: [mayor may require council reconsideration of a matter]
bcl:text.#text: The chair of a regional district has the same authority as a mayor under section 131  of the .

In exercising the power under subsection (1), the chair may return the matter for reconsideration at the meeting of the board following the original vote, whether or not this is within the 30 day period referred to in section 131 (2) of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of select and standing committees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may appoint a select committee to consider or inquire into any matter and report its findings and opinion to the board.
The chair may establish standing committees for matters the chair considers would be better dealt with by committee and may appoint persons to those committees.
Subject to subsection (4), persons who are not directors may be appointed by the board to a select committee or by the chair to a standing committee.
At least one member of each select and standing committee must be a director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regular and special board meetings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board must meet

bcl:text.#text: regularly in accordance with its bylaw under section 225 , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as it decides and as provided in this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A special board meeting is a board meeting other than a statutory, regular or adjourned meeting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Calling of special board meetings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The corporate officer must call a special meeting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on request of the chair, or
on request of any 2 directors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), notice of a special meeting must be given at least 24 hours before the time of the meeting by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: posting a copy of the notice at the regular board meeting place,
posting a copy of the notice at the public notice posting places referred to in section 225 (1) (c), and
leaving one copy for each director at the place to which the director has directed notices be sent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under subsection (2) must include the date, time and place of the meeting, describe in general terms the purpose of the meeting and be signed by the chair or corporate officer.
Notice of a special meeting may be waived by unanimous vote of all directors.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Electronic meetings and participation by members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If permitted under subsection (3), a board meeting or a board committee meeting may be conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities.
Members of the board who are participating under this section in a meeting conducted in accordance with subsection (1) are deemed to be present at the meeting.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations permitting meetings under subsection (1) and prescribing conditions, limits and requirements respecting such meetings.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations establishing special rules for dealing with urgent issues

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may, by regulation applicable to one or more regional districts, make provision for obtaining and counting votes of the directors on urgent issues and adopting resolutions and bylaws on those issues without the necessity of holding a board meeting.
Regulations under subsection (1) may establish rules respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mechanisms for submitting urgent issues to the directors;
the manner in which votes will be submitted by the directors;
the counting of votes and subsequent ratification by the board of the resolutions and bylaws.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board member participating in a vote under subsection (1) is deemed to be present at a board meeting and a resolution or bylaw adopted under that subsection is deemed to have been adopted at a board meeting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minutes of board meetings and committee meetings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Minutes of board meetings must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: legibly recorded,
certified as correct by the designated regional district officer, and
signed by the chair or other member presiding at the meeting or at the next meeting at which they are adopted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Minutes of a board committee meeting must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: legibly recorded, and
signed by the chair or other member presiding at the meeting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Meetings and hearings outside regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If authorized under subsection (2), the following meetings, hearings and other proceedings may be held, and all powers, duties and functions may be exercised in relation to those proceedings, outside the boundaries of the regional district:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: board meetings;
board committee meetings;
other public meetings conducted by or on behalf of the board or a board committee;
board hearings that are required by law or authorized by an enactment;
board proceedings in which a person is entitled under this Act to make representations to the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may do either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by bylaw, provide that meetings, hearings or other proceedings referred to in subsection (1) may be held outside the boundaries of the regional district;
by resolution in a specific case, allow a meeting, hearing or other proceeding to be held outside the boundaries of the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board must, by bylaw, do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish the general procedures to be followed by the board and by board committees in conducting their business, including the manner by which resolutions may be passed and bylaws adopted;
provide for advance public notice respecting the date, time and place of board and board committee meetings and establish the procedures for giving that notice;

bcl:text.#text: identify places that are to be public notice posting places for the purposes of the application of section 94  of the  to the regional district.

A bylaw adopted under this section must not be amended, or repealed and substituted, unless the board first gives notice in accordance with section 94 of the  describing the proposed changes in general terms.
The following provisions of the  apply to regional districts in relation to meetings:
Division 3  of Part 4 ;
section 133 ;
section 282 (2) (c) .
The following provisions of the  apply to regional districts:

bcl:text.in:desc: [exercise of powers by bylaw or resolution]
bcl:text.#text: section 122 ;
section 134 .
Section 132  of the  applies to regional districts, except that a reference in that section to section 123 of the  is to be read as a reference to Division 3  of this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Electronic meetings of other bodies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If permitted under the rules governing the procedures of the body and the requirements of subsection (2) are met, meetings of the following bodies may be conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities:

bcl:text.#text: a local community commission under section 243 ;
a commission established under section 263 (1) (g) ;
an intergovernmental advisory committee established under section 450 ;
an advisory planning commission established under section 461 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following requirements apply in relation to a meeting referred to in subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the facilities must enable the meeting's participants to hear, or watch and hear, the meeting;
except for any part of the meeting that is closed to the public, the facilities must enable the public to hear, or watch and hear, the meeting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Members of a body who are participating under this section in a meeting conducted in accordance with this section are deemed to be present at the meeting.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Electronic participation of members of other bodies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If permitted under the rules governing the procedures of the body and the requirements of subsection (2) are met, a member of a body referred to in section 226.1 (1) who is unable to attend in person at a meeting of that body may participate in the meeting by means of electronic or other communication facilities.
The following requirements apply in relation to a meeting referred to in subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the facilities must enable the meeting's participants to hear, or watch and hear, the participation of the member;
except for any part of the meeting that is closed to the public, the facilities must enable the public to hear, or watch and hear, the participation of the member.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Members of a body who are participating under this section in a meeting conducted in accordance with this section are deemed to be present at the meeting.

bcl:text.#text: Subject to section 228 , Division 3  of Part 5  of the  applies to regional districts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaw adoption at same meeting as third reading
bcl:section.bcl:text: A regional district bylaw that does not require approval, consent or assent under this or any other Act before it is adopted may be adopted at the same meeting at which it passes third reading if the motion for adoption receives at least 2/3 of the votes cast.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Delegation of board authority

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the specific limitations and conditions established under this or another Act, a board may delegate its powers, duties and functions, including those specifically established by an enactment, to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a board member or board committee,
an officer or employee of the regional district, or
another body established by the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As exceptions, a board may not delegate the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the making of a bylaw;
a power or duty exercisable only by bylaw;
a power or duty to appoint, suspend or terminate a regional district officer;
a power or duty established by an enactment that the board hear an appeal or reconsider an action, decision or other matter;
a power or duty established by this or any other Act that the board give its approval or consent to, recommendations on or acceptance of an action, decision or other matter;

bcl:text.#text: the power to impose a remedial action requirement under Division 12  of Part 3 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may not delegate under subsection (1) to a corporation.
In exercising its powers under subsection (1), a board may establish any terms and conditions it considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaw required for delegation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 231, a board may delegate a power, duty or function only by bylaw adopted by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast.
A board may, by bylaw adopted by a majority of votes cast, amend or repeal a bylaw referred to in subsection (1) to reduce or revoke the delegation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Delegation of hearings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to the delegation of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: board hearings that are required by law or authorized under an enactment, other than hearings referred to in section 229 (2) (d), and
board proceedings in which a person is entitled under this Act to make representations to the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following rules apply in relation to a delegation referred to in subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the delegation may be made specifically, by class of hearings or proceedings, or generally;
the delegation may be made only to one or more directors;
if a board decision is to be made following a delegated hearing or proceeding, the authority to make the decision may be delegated only to the directors to whom the matter is delegated;

if a board decision referred to in paragraph (c) is not delegated under that paragraph, the board must not make the decision until the applicable directors report to the board the views expressed at the hearing or proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to section 230 (1), a board may delegate the holding of a hearing by bylaw or resolution adopted by a majority of votes cast.

For certainty, if a delegation has been made under this section, the board may exercise its authority under this section to revoke that delegation or change the delegation to a different delegation in relation to a specific hearing or proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reconsideration of delegate's decisions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a board delegates a power to make a decision, and
in relation to that delegation, an enactment establishes a right to have a delegated decision reconsidered by the board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board must, by bylaw, establish procedures for such a reconsideration, including how a person may apply for the reconsideration.
In undertaking a reconsideration referred to in subsection (2), a board has the same authority as that conferred on the delegate.
If there is a right of reconsideration, the person making the decision must advise the person subject to the decision of this right.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Officers and employees for regional district

bcl:text.#text: Without limiting section 263 , a board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide for the appointment of officers and other employees for the regional district, and

bcl:text.#text: subject to the  and the , establish the terms and conditions of their employment, including terms and conditions respecting their remuneration, benefits, expenses, hours of work and manner of appointment, promotion, discipline and dismissal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of a conflict between terms and conditions of employment established by bylaw, resolution or policy and those established by contract of employment or collective agreement, the contract or agreement prevails.

bcl:text.#text: A board may, by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the votes cast, provide for the inclusion of its regional district in an employers' organization under the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Officer positions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board

bcl:text.#text: must, by bylaw, establish officer positions in relation to the powers, duties and functions under sections 236  and 237 , with titles it considers appropriate,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may, by bylaw, establish other officer positions for its regional district, with titles it considers appropriate, and
may, by bylaw or resolution, assign powers, duties and functions to those officer positions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a board may assign to an officer position powers, duties and functions in addition to those required or permitted to be assigned by this Act or another enactment, and
the same person may be appointed to 2 or more officer positions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chief administrative officer
bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 234 may be assigned the chief administrative responsibility, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: overall management of the administrative operations of the regional district;
ensuring that the policies and directions of the board are implemented;
advising and informing the board on the operation and affairs of the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Corporate administration
bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 234 must be assigned the responsibility of corporate administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring that accurate minutes of the meetings of the board and board committees are prepared and that the minutes, bylaws and other records of the business of the board and board committees are maintained and kept safe;
ensuring that access is provided to records of the board and board committees, as required by law or authorized by the board;
certifying copies of bylaws and other documents, as required or requested;
administering oaths and taking affirmations, declarations and affidavits required to be taken under this or any other Act relating to regional districts;

accepting, on behalf of the board or regional district, notices and documents that are required or permitted to be given to, served on, filed with or otherwise provided to the board or regional district;
keeping the corporate seal, if any, and having it affixed to documents as required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Financial administration
bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 234 must be assigned the responsibility of financial administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receiving all money paid to the regional district;
ensuring the keeping of all funds and securities of the regional district;
expending and disbursing money in the manner authorized by the board;
investing funds, until required, in authorized investments;
ensuring that accurate records and full accounts of the financial affairs of the regional district are prepared, maintained and kept safe;
exercising control and supervision over all other financial affairs of the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Oath of office for officers
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before taking on the duties of office, a person appointed to an officer position for a regional district must swear or affirm an oath of office in the form prescribed by regulation or established by bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair to direct and inspect officers and employees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair must inspect and direct the conduct of officers and employees of the regional district.
So far as the chair's power extends, the chair must see that negligence, carelessness and violation of duty by an officer or employee is prosecuted and punished.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Suspension of officers and employees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The chair must suspend an officer or employee if the chair considers this necessary.
A suspension under subsection (1) must be reported to the board at its next meeting, and the board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reinstate the officer or employee,
confirm the suspension,
confirm and extend the suspension, or
dismiss the officer or employee.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Termination of officer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to a contract of employment and subject to providing the officer with an opportunity to be heard, the appointment of a regional district officer may be terminated by the board as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of termination for cause, by immediate termination without any period of notice;
in any other case, by termination on reasonable notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A termination under subsection (1) (b) may be made only by the affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of all directors.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prohibition against interfering with regional district officials
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not interfere with, hinder or obstruct a regional district officer or employee in the exercise or performance of the regional district officer's or employee's powers, duties or functions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Establishment of local community commissions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, establish in an electoral area one or more local communities to be administered by local community commissions.
A bylaw establishing a local community must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: name the local community;
establish the boundaries of the local community;
establish the time and manner of holding annual general meetings of the commission;
establish either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that elections for commissioners are to be held every 4 years at the time of the general local election, or
that elections for commissioners are to be held each year at a time specified in the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw establishing a local community may do one or more of the following:

bcl:text.#text: establish the manner of holding elections for commissioners, if this is to be different from that provided by the application of Part 3 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide that the number of elected commissioners is to be 6;
set terms, conditions and restrictions on activities of the commission.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided by bylaw under subsection (3) (a), Part 3 applies to the election of commissioners.
A bylaw under subsection (3) (a) must be adopted at least 8 weeks before the general voting day for the election to which it first applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement for assent of electors and inspector approval

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw establishing a local community, or a bylaw amending or repealing such a bylaw, has no effect unless it receives the assent of the electors in the area of the local community and is approved by the inspector.
As an exception to subsection (1), the minister may waive the requirement for assent of the electors to a bylaw that amends or repeals a bylaw establishing a local community.

bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of obtaining the assent of the electors as required by this section, Part 4  applies and the voting area is to be the proposed local community or the local community, as applicable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Commission membership

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The commission for a local community consists of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as applicable,

bcl:text.#text: 4 elected commissioners unless a bylaw under section 243 (3) (b)  applies, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 6 elected commissioners if such a bylaw does apply, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the director for the electoral area in which the local community is located.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A commissioner must have the qualifications to hold office as a director.
The term of office for elected commissioners is, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the bylaw establishing the local community specifies that elections are to be held every 4 years, 4 years or until their successors are elected, whichever is later, or
if the bylaw establishing the local community specifies that elections are to be held each year, one year or until their successors are elected, whichever is later.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At each annual general meeting, the commissioners must elect a chair and a vice chair.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Giving notice to regional districts
bcl:text: If an enactment requires or permits

the notice, service, filing or other provision is effected if the notice or document is, as applicable, given to, served on, filed with or otherwise provided to the regional district corporate officer.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notice to be given to a board or a regional district,
