land or improvements, or both, used or occupied by a church as tenant or licensee for the purpose of public worship or for the purposes of a church hall that the board considers necessary to the church;

bcl:text.#text: land that is owned and used exclusively by an agricultural or horticultural society and that is in excess of the area exemption under section 15 (1) (j) of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an interest held by a not-for-profit organization in school buildings that the organization uses or occupies as tenant or licensee of a board of school trustees;
an interest held by a francophone education authority in school buildings that the francophone education authority uses or occupies as licensee of a board of school trustees;
an interest held by a not-for-profit organization in school buildings that the organization uses or occupies as tenant or licensee of a francophone education authority;
land or improvements that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are owned or held by a municipality, regional district or other local authority, and
the board considers are used for a purpose of the local authority.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption under subsection (3) may be limited to a specified portion of the net taxable value of the property to which the exemption applies.

If, because of a change in the use or ownership of property exempted under subsection (3), the property no longer meets the requirements for exemption established by subsection (4), the bylaw ceases to apply to that property and the property is liable to taxation effective from the time of the change.

Assent of the electors as required by subsection (3) (b) is obtained if, by voting conducted throughout the regional district, a majority of the votes counted as valid in all voting on the bylaw is in favour of the bylaw.

bcl:text.#text: Part 4  applies to voting for the purposes of subsection (7), with voting to be conducted either, at the option of the board,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the board throughout the regional district, or

by the council of each municipality and by the board for that part of the regional district that is not in a municipality, with the results of voting in these areas totalled to determine whether assent has been obtained.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions for heritage properties

bcl:text.#text: In this section and section 393,  means property in an electoral area that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protected heritage property,
subject to a heritage revitalization agreement under section 610, or

bcl:text.#text: subject to a covenant under section 219 of the  that relates to the conservation of heritage property.

Despite section 273  but subject to subsection (3) of this section, for the purposes of supporting the conservation of an eligible heritage property, on or before October 31 in any year, a board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt from taxation under this Part all or part of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the eligible heritage property, and
if the eligible heritage property is a building or other improvement so affixed to the land as to constitute real property, an area of land surrounding the eligible heritage property;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: limit an exemption under paragraph (a) to a specified portion of the net taxable value of the property to which the exemption applies;
make an exemption under this subsection subject to specified conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (2) may provide a tax exemption

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the next calendar year, or
if the bylaw has received the approval of the electors, for a specified period not longer than 10 years.

bcl:text.#text: In addition to the information required by section 86 (2)  of the  or section 176 (3)  of this Act, the notice in relation to approval of the electors under subsection (3) (b) of this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the eligible heritage property that would be subject to the bylaw, and
describe the exemption that would be made for the eligible heritage property.

bcl:text.#text: Within 30 days after adopting a bylaw under this section, the board must give notice of the bylaw to the minister responsible for the  in accordance with section 595  of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repayment requirement in relation to heritage exemptions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 392 may provide that, if any of the following circumstances as specified in the bylaw occur, the board may require the owner of the eligible heritage property at that time to pay to the regional district the amount calculated under subsection (2) of this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the eligible heritage property is destroyed, whether with or without proper authorization under the requirements of the heritage protection of the property;
if the eligible heritage property is altered by or on behalf of the owner without proper authorization under the requirements of the heritage protection of the property;
if any other circumstances specified in the bylaw occur.

bcl:text: The amount that may be required under subsection (1) is the amount equivalent to the sum of
plus

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total taxes exempted under the bylaw under section 392

bcl:text.#text: interest from the time at which the exempt taxes would otherwise have been payable, compounded annually at the rate referred to in section 245  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 392 that includes a provision under subsection (1) may be adopted only with the consent of the current owner of the eligible heritage property to which the bylaw applies.

bcl:text.#text: If a bylaw under section 392 includes a provision under subsection (1) of this section, within 30 days after the bylaw is adopted, the board must have notice of the bylaw filed in the land title office, and for this purpose section 594  applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bylaw under section 392 includes a provision under subsection (1) of this section and a circumstance specified in the provision occurs, the board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2) of this section, or
waive the obligation of the owner to pay all or part of the amount referred to in subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board does not adopt a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within one year after it becomes aware of the circumstance in relation to which the bylaw could be adopted, the board is deemed to have waived all obligation of the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2).
If a board adopts a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within the time period referred to in subsection (6), the board may

bcl:text.in:desc: [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes]
bcl:text.#text: require the Surveyor of Taxes to add the amount referred to in subsection (2) to the taxes payable on the eligible heritage property, in which case section 399  applies, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an agreement with the current owner regarding payment of the amount referred to in subsection (2) as a personal debt to the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions for riparian property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and section 395:

bcl:text.#text: means property that meets all the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property must be riparian land;

bcl:text.#text: the property must be subject to a covenant under section 219 of the  that relates to the protection of the property as riparian property;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the regional district granting the exemption under this section must be a covenantee in whose favour the covenant referred to in paragraph (b) is made;
any other requirements prescribed under subsection (6);

bcl:text.#text: means the portion of the net taxable value of the parcel of land in relation to which an exemption under subsection (2) is made that is equivalent to the ratio of

bcl:text: to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area of the eligible riparian property that is exempted under subsection (2) (a)
the area of the parcel of land in relation to which the exemption is made.

bcl:text.#text: Despite section 273  but subject to subsections (3) and (4) of this section, for the purposes of supporting the conservation of an eligible riparian property, on or before October 31 in any year a board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt all or part of the eligible riparian property from taxation under this Part;
limit an exemption under paragraph (a) to a specified portion of the eligible value of the property to which the exemption applies;
make an exemption under this subsection subject to specified conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An exemption under subsection (2) may apply only to that part of the eligible riparian property that is a riparian area.
A bylaw under subsection (2) may provide a tax exemption

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the next calendar year, or
if the bylaw has received the approval of the electors, for a specified period not greater than 10 years.

bcl:text.#text: In addition to the information required by section 86 (2)  of the  or section 176 (3)  of this Act, the notice in relation to approval of the electors under subsection (4) (b) of this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the eligible riparian property that would be subject to the bylaw, and
describe the exemption that would be made for the eligible riparian property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish additional requirements for property to be considered eligible riparian property.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repayment requirement in relation to riparian exemptions

bcl:text: A bylaw under section 394 may provide that, if
the board may require the owner of the eligible riparian property at that time to pay to the regional district the amount referred to in subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:text.#text: there is a contravention of any of the conditions of the covenant under section 219 of the  in relation to which the exemption is given,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the covenant is discharged before the end of the period of the exemption, or
any other circumstances specified in the bylaw occur,

bcl:text: The amount that may be required under subsection (1) is the amount equivalent to the sum of
plus

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the total taxes exempted under the bylaw under section 394

bcl:text.#text: interest from the time at which the exempt taxes would otherwise have been payable, compounded annually at the rate referred to in section 245  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 394 that includes a provision under subsection (1) of this section may be adopted only with the consent of the owner of the eligible riparian property to which the bylaw applies.

bcl:text.#text: If a bylaw under section 394 includes a provision under subsection (1) of this section, within 30 days after the bylaw is adopted the board must have notice of the bylaw filed in the land title office, and for this purpose section 594  applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bylaw under section 394 includes a provision under subsection (1) of this section and a circumstance specified in the provision occurs, the board may, by bylaw adopted by at least 2/3 of the votes cast, either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2) of this section, or
waive the obligation of the owner to pay all or part of the amount referred to in subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a board does not adopt a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within one year after it becomes aware of the circumstance in relation to which the bylaw could be adopted, the board is deemed to have waived all obligations of the owner to pay the amount referred to in subsection (2).
If a board adopts a bylaw under subsection (5) (a) within the time period referred to in subsection (6), the board may

bcl:text.in:desc: [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes]
bcl:text.#text: require the Surveyor of Taxes to add the amount referred to in subsection (2) to the taxes payable on the eligible riparian property, in which case section 399  applies, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an agreement with the owner regarding payment of the amount referred to in subsection (2) as a personal debt to the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax exemptions under partnering agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, exempt from taxation under this Part all or part of the land, improvements or both owned or held by a party to a partnering agreement with the regional district, during all or part of the term of the agreement.
An exemption under this section may be provided only for that portion of the land or improvements used for a public purpose.

If the term of the exemption authorized in the bylaw is for greater than 5 years, or for a period that by exercising rights of renewal or extension could exceed 5 years, the bylaw may be adopted only with the approval of the electors.
An exemption under this section takes effect as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the bylaw under subsection (1) is adopted by October 31 in a year, the exemption takes effect for the following calendar year;
if the bylaw under subsection (1) is adopted after October 31 in a year, the exemption takes effect for the year following the next calendar year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, because of a change in the use or ownership of property exempted from taxation by bylaw under this section the property no longer meets the requirements for exemption, the bylaw ceases to apply to that property and the property is liable to taxation effective from the time of the change.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Imposition of fees and charges

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, impose a fee or charge payable in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all or part of a service of the regional district, or
the use of regional district property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), a bylaw under this section may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the bylaw is in relation to an authority to provide a service or regulate outside the regional district, apply outside the regional district;
base the fee or charge on any factor specified in the bylaw, including by establishing different rates or levels of fees in relation to different factors;
establish different classes of persons, property, businesses and activities and different fees or charges for different classes;
establish terms and conditions for payment, including discounts, interest and penalties;
provide for the reduction, waiving or refund of a fee or charge if, as specified in the bylaw, a person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has already paid towards the costs to which the fee or charge relates,
does not require the service to which the fee or charge relates,
no longer undertakes the activity or thing for which a licence, permit or approval was required, or
has prepaid towards the costs of the service to which the fee or charge relates and use of the service by the person is discontinued;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish fees for obtaining copies of records that are available for public inspection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception, a board may not establish a fee or charge under this section

bcl:text.#text: in relation to Part 3  or Part 4 , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to any other matter for which another provision of this Act specifically authorizes the imposition of a fee or charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional district must make available to the public, on request, a report respecting how a fee or charge imposed under this section was determined.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interest calculation
bcl:section.bcl:text: A regional district may, by bylaw, establish the manner in which interest is calculated if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: this or another Act provides a requirement or authority to apply interest to an amount owed to, or owing by, the regional district, and
the manner in which interest is calculated is not otherwise provided for.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regional district fees or charges imposed under this Act for work done or services provided to land or improvements;

bcl:text.#text: fees imposed under section 328 (2) (b) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amounts that a regional district is entitled to recover for work done or services provided to land or improvements under any provision of this Act that authorizes the regional district to recover amounts in the event of default by a person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an amount referred to in subsection (1) is due and payable by December 31 and is unpaid on that date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount is deemed to be taxes in arrear,
the regional district financial officer must promptly, after December 31, forward a statement showing the amount of the fee or charge

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the Surveyor of Taxes in the case of real property that is not in a municipality, or
to the applicable municipal collector in other cases, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Surveyor of Taxes or collector must add the amount of the fee or charge to the taxes payable on the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an amount is added to taxes under subsection (2) (c),

bcl:text.#text: the amount is deemed to be a Provincial or municipal tax, as applicable, and must be dealt with in the same manner as taxes against the property would be dealt with under the  or the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when it is collected, the Minister of Finance or collecting municipality must pay the amount to the regional district to which it is owed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an amount is added under subsection (2) (c) and is not paid at the time the property is sold by tax sale,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the upset price is obtained at the time of the tax sale, the minister or municipality referred to in subsection (3) must pay out of the proceeds of the sale the amount due under this section to the regional district to which it is owed, or
if the upset price is not obtained and subsequently the property is sold, the proceeds of the sale must be applied according to the respective interests in the upset price.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsections (2) to (4), the regional district to which the amount is owed may bring action in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover that amount.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Special fees and charges that are liens against property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to amounts referred to in section 399.
An amount referred to in subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a charge or lien on the land and its improvements in respect of which the charge is imposed, the work done or services provided,
has priority over any claim, lien, privilege or encumbrance of any person except the Crown, and
does not require registration to preserve it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner of land or real property aggrieved by the creation of a charge or lien under this section may, on 10 days' written notice to the regional district, apply to the Supreme Court for an order that the charge be removed or that the amount for which it was imposed be varied.

On an application under subsection (3), if the court is satisfied that any of the amount for which the charge or lien was created was imposed improperly, it may order that the charge or lien be removed or that the amount be varied, or make another order it considers proper.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limit on expenditures

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional district must not make an expenditure other than one authorized under subsection (2) or (3).
A regional district may make an expenditure that is provided for that year in its financial plan, other than an expenditure that is expressly prohibited by this or another Act.

A regional district may make an expenditure for an emergency that was not contemplated for that year in its financial plan, other than an expenditure that is expressly prohibited by this or another Act.
In relation to the authority under subsection (3), the board must establish procedures

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to authorize expenditures under that subsection, and
to provide for such expenditures to be reported to the board at a regular meeting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an expenditure is made under subsection (3), as soon as practicable, the board must amend the financial plan in respect of the service to include the expenditure and the funding source for the expenditure.
For certainty, the authority under subsection (3) does not include the authority to borrow for the purpose of making the expenditure.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limit on borrowing and other liabilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional district may incur a liability only under the authority of this or another Act.

A regional district must not incur a liability for which expenditures are required during the planning period for its financial plan unless those expenditures are included for the applicable year in the financial plan.

bcl:text.#text: Subsection (2) does not apply to a debt under section 404 .
The following provisions of the  apply to regional districts:
section 175 ;
section 176 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [loan authorization bylaws for long term borrowing]
bcl:text.#text: section 179 .

For the purposes of obtaining the approval of the electors under section 175 of the  as it applies under subsection (1) of this section, the electors are the electors of the service area in respect of which the liability is to be incurred.

In relation to section 179 (1) (g) of the  as it applies under subsection (1) of this section, the reference to carrying out works referred to in section 32 (3)  of that Act is to be read as a reference to works referred to in section 291  of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Revenue anticipation borrowing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, provide for the borrowing of money that may be necessary to meet its current lawful expenditures before its revenue, from all sources, to pay for those expenditures has been received.
Money borrowed under this section must be repaid when the anticipated revenue with respect to which the borrowing was authorized is received.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Short-term capital borrowing in relation to general administration

bcl:text.#text: A board may, by bylaw adopted with the approval of the inspector, contract a debt for any purpose of a capital nature related to the service referred to in section 338 (2) (a) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw and the debt under this section must comply with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the debt must not cause the aggregate liabilities under this section to exceed the sum of $50 000 plus the product of $2 multiplied by the population of the regional district;
the debt and securities for it must be payable no later than the lesser of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 5 years from the date on which the securities were issued, or
the reasonable life expectancy of the capital asset for which the debt is contracted;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the bylaw must set out

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount of the debt intended to be incurred, and
in brief and general terms, the purpose for which the debt is to be incurred.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (a), the regional district population is to be taken from the most recent population census but, if a population has not been established by census, it must be determined by the minister until the results of a census are known.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regional district loan authorization bylaws

bcl:text.in:desc: [loan authorization bylaws for long term borrowing]
bcl:text.#text: In addition to the requirements of section 179  of the , a regional district loan authorization bylaw must identify the service to which it relates.

bcl:text.in:desc: [grants for mountain resort business improvement areas]
bcl:text.#text: A loan authorization bylaw may not be adopted in relation to a service referred to in section 338 (2) (h) .
Section 349 (1) to (6)  applies to the amendment or repeal of a loan authorization bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Participating area approval required for some loan authorization bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a loan authorization bylaw must receive participating area approval in accordance with this section.
Participating area approval is not required for the following:

bcl:text.#text: paying compensation in respect of property expropriated or injured in carrying out works referred to in section 291  of this Act;
borrowing money for a purpose referred to in section 179 (1) (d) to (f)  of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: borrowing money for a purpose prescribed by regulation or in circumstances prescribed by regulation, subject to any conditions established by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Participating area approval under this section may be obtained as follows:

bcl:text.#text: in any case, by assent of the electors in accordance with section 344 ;
in any case, by approval given in accordance with section 345 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [consent on behalf of municipal participating area]
bcl:text.#text: for a municipal participating area that is all of the municipality, consent given in accordance with section 346 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [consent on behalf of electoral participating area]
bcl:text.#text: for an electoral participating area, by consent given in accordance with section 347 (2) to (4)  if
the borrowing is in relation to a service that was requested by petition under section 337  and the petition contemplated the borrowing, or
the borrowing was requested by petition under section 408 .
The matter put before the electors under subsection (3) (a) or (b) must include the information referred to in section 179 (2)  of the .

bcl:text.in:desc: [Regional Districts: Service Structure and Establishing Bylaws]
bcl:text.#text: Subject to this section, Part 10  applies for the purposes of obtaining approval required by subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Electoral participating area petition for borrowing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owners of parcels in an electoral participating area may sign and submit to the regional district a petition for borrowing in relation to the service.
Each page of a petition referred to in subsection (1) must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the service in relation to which the borrowing is proposed;
identify the relevant electoral participating area;
describe in brief and general terms the purpose of the proposed borrowing;
state the estimated total amount of the proposed borrowing;
state the maximum term for which the debentures for the proposed borrowing may be issued;
contain other information that the board may require.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order for a petition to be certified as sufficient and valid for the purposes of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the petition must be signed by the owners of at least 50% of the parcels liable to be charged in relation to the proposed borrowing, and
the persons signing must be the owners of parcels that in total represent 50% of the net taxable value of all land and improvements within the electoral participating area.

bcl:text.in:desc: [rules in relation to petition for local area service]
bcl:text.#text: Section 212 (4) to (6)  of the  applies to a petition under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Temporary borrowing under loan authorization bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board that has adopted a loan authorization bylaw may, by bylaw, temporarily borrow money not exceeding the difference between the total amount authorized by the loan authorization bylaw and the amount already borrowed in relation to that bylaw.

bcl:text.#text: To the extent necessary, the proceeds of the borrowing under section 411  in relation to the loan authorization bylaw must be used to repay the money temporarily borrowed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Financing municipal undertakings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional district may finance, at the request and sole cost of a municipality, an undertaking

bcl:text.#text: for which the council of the municipality has adopted a loan authorization bylaw in accordance with the , or
in the case of the City of Vancouver, for which the council has passed a bylaw or resolution authorizing the borrowing of money under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of financing under this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the board may adopt a security issuing bylaw without adopting a loan authorization bylaw, and
the security issuing bylaw must state, as its authorization, the bylaw or resolution referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:text.#text: The municipality must provide for and pay over to the regional district the amounts required to discharge its obligations in accordance with the terms of debentures issued to the regional district or agreements entered into under section 411  or under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the amounts provided for in the debentures or under the agreements, as referred to in subsection (3), are not sufficient to meet the obligations of the board, the deficiency is a liability of the municipality to the regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Security issuing bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by a security issuing bylaw, provide for the issue of debentures or other evidence of debt for all or part of the debt authorized by one or more loan authorization bylaws.
A security issuing bylaw must specify the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the loan authorization bylaws that authorize the borrowing;
the amount of borrowing authorized by each loan authorization bylaw;
the amount already borrowed under each loan authorization bylaw;
the amount remaining to be borrowed under each loan authorization bylaw;
the amount authorized by the security issuing bylaw to be issued under each loan authorization bylaw;
the term of the debt.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The proceeds of the borrowing under a security issuing bylaw must be allotted proportionally for the purposes of each loan authorization bylaw referred to in subsection (2) (a).
A security issuing bylaw must not be adopted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: while any proceeding is pending in which the validity of a loan authorization bylaw referred to in subsection (2) (a) is called into question or by which it is sought to be set aside, or
until the time for giving notice of intention to apply to set aside the loan authorization bylaw expires.

bcl:text.#text: A regional district security issuing bylaw may include borrowing under section 410 , as well as borrowing by the regional district for its own purposes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General liability provisions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Money borrowed by a regional district must be on its credit at large and, in the event of default, constitutes an indebtedness of the municipalities and electoral areas in the regional district that they are jointly and severally liable to repay.

bcl:text.#text: If a municipality defaults on the payment of money due and payable by it to the regional district, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, at the request of the board, appoint a commissioner for the municipality and, on being appointed, the commissioner has all the powers and duties of a commissioner appointed under Division 3  of Part 19 .

bcl:part.bcl:text: Regional Districts: Bylaw Enforcement and Challenge of Bylaws

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaw enforcement: fines and other penalties

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may make bylaws for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the purposes of enforcing the bylaws of the regional district by fine, by imprisonment or both, and
imposing fines, penalties and costs.

bcl:text.#text: Section 261  of the  applies to regional districts.

bcl:marginalnote.#text: Ticketing for bylaw offences: application of

bcl:text.#text: Division 3  of Part 8 of the  applies to regional districts.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a reference in section 265  of the  to a bylaw is to be read as a reference to a bylaw under section 413 (1) of this Act.

bcl:marginalnote.in:doc: Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act

bcl:link.in:doc: Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act

bcl:text.#text: Subject to the regulations under the , a regional district bylaw may be enforced by bylaw notice under and in accordance with that Act.

bcl:link.in:doc: Local Government Bylaw Notice Enforcement Act

bcl:text.#text: If a matter is prescribed for the purpose of section 4 (2)  of the , a board that adopts or has adopted a bylaw in relation to the matter may enforce the bylaw only by bylaw notice under that Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaw contraventions — offences and prosecutions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bylaw establishes a regulation or requirement to be observed in a regional district, a person who contravenes the regulation or requirement commits an offence that is punishable in the same manner as if the bylaw had expressly forbidden persons from doing or refraining from doing the act.

bcl:text.#text: A bylaw under section 413 (1)  may establish one or more of the following penalties to which a person convicted of an offence in a prosecution under the  is liable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a minimum fine;
a maximum fine of up to $50 000;
in the case of a continuing offence, for each day that the offence continues, either or both of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a minimum fine under paragraph (a), or
a maximum fine under paragraph (b);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: imprisonment for not more than 6 months.

bcl:text.#text: If no other penalties are established in relation to an offence referred to in subsection (1.1), the penalties established by section 4  of the  apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In a prosecution for an offence against a regional district bylaw, the justice or court may impose all or part of the penalties applicable in relation to the offence, together with the costs of prosecution.

If a penalty, or part of a penalty, and all costs imposed are not paid promptly, the justice or court may, by order, authorize all or part of the penalty and costs to be levied by distress and sale of the offender's goods and chattels.

If there is no distress out of which the penalty and costs or part of the penalty and all of the costs can be levied, the justice or court may commit the offender to imprisonment for the term, or part of the term, specified in the bylaw.

bcl:marginalnote.#text: Additional sentencing powers in relation to  prosecutions

bcl:text: If a person is convicted of an offence

bcl:text.#text: in addition to the penalty established under section 413 , the court may, having regard to the nature of the offence and the circumstances surrounding its commission, make an order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under subsection (3), or

bcl:text.#text: against a regional district bylaw in a prosecution commenced by an information in Form 2 under the ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibiting the person from doing any act or engaging in any activity that may, in the court's opinion, result in the continuation or repetition of the offence, and
directing the person to take any action the court considers appropriate to remedy the harm that resulted from the commission of the offence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (1) must specify the duration of the order, which may not exceed one year.

A person who fails to comply with an order under subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $10 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both.

bcl:text.in:desc: [exception from obligation for regional district to pay collected fines to government]
bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of section 43 (3)  of the , a fine imposed in a prosecution for an offence under subsection (3) of this section is deemed to be a fine imposed for the contravention of a bylaw of the regional district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is convicted of an offence referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b), on application by the regional district or another person for compensation, the court must give consideration to the application and, in addition to any penalty imposed, may order the person

bcl:text.#text: to pay to the regional district or to the other person compensation, in an amount that is not more than the monetary limit specified under the , for any damage or loss sustained by the regional district or other person because of the commission of the offence, and

in accordance with the schedule of costs prescribed under section 132 (2) (h) of the , to pay to the regional district the costs incurred by the regional district in investigating and prosecuting the person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of a dispute, the amount of compensation payable under subsection (5) (a) must be proven on a balance of probabilities by the regional district or the other person.
An order under subsection (5) may be enforced as a judgment of the court for the recovery of a debt in the amount stated against the person named.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority to fulfill requirements at defaulter's expense

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority of a board under this or another Act to require that something be done includes the authority to direct that, if a person subject to the requirement fails to take the required action, the regional district may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fulfill the requirement at the expense of the person, and
recover the costs incurred from that person as a debt.

bcl:text.in:desc: [special fees and charges that are to be collected as taxes]
bcl:text.#text: Section 399  applies to an amount recoverable under subsection (1) that is incurred for work done or services provided in relation to land or improvements.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inspections to determine whether bylaws are being followed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a board has authority to regulate, prohibit and impose requirements in relation to a matter, the board may, by bylaw, authorize officers, employees and agents of the regional district to enter, at all reasonable times, on any property to inspect and determine whether all regulations, prohibitions and requirements are being met.

bcl:marginalnote.#text: Enforcement by civil proceedings: application of

bcl:text.#text: Division 4  of Part 8 of the  applies to regional districts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Recovery of utility rates by legal remedy of distress

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to other remedies in this Act for the collection and recovery of gas rates, electrical energy rates or water rates authorized by this Act, the payment of those rates may be enforced by a regional district by distress and sale of the goods and chattels of the person owing the rates wherever those chattels are found in the regional district.

bcl:text.#text: The costs chargeable in relation to distress under this section are those payable under the , unless another scale is provided under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scale of costs in relation to legal remedy of distress
bcl:section.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, regulate and alter the scale of costs payable in cases of distress under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcement of bylaws in relation to discharge of firearms

bcl:text.#text: Despite this Act or a provision in letters patent issued to a regional district, a bylaw of a regional district regulating or prohibiting the discharge of firearms, as defined in the , is unenforceable to the extent that a regulation under section 108 (2) (n) or (o) of the  is in force in the regional district.
Section 275  of the  applies to regional districts.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Challenge of Bylaws and Other Regional District Instruments

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Challenge of bylaws and other regional district instruments

in:desc: [Challenge of Municipal Bylaws and Other Instruments]
bcl:text.#text: Division 1  of Part 16  applies to regional districts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notice of an application to set aside a regional district security issuing bylaw, stating the grounds of the application, must be served on the regional district at least 5 days before the hearing and not more than 10 days after the adoption of the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Part
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:text.#text: , in relation to a regional growth strategy,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: means a local government whose acceptance of the regional growth strategy

bcl:text.#text: is required under section 436 , or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: would be required if that section applied, and

bcl:link.in:doc: South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority Act

bcl:text.#text: in the case of a regional growth strategy for the Metro Vancouver Regional District, includes the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority continued under the ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [facilitation of agreement during development of regional growth strategy]
bcl:text.#text: , in relation to a regional growth strategy, means the facilitator designated by the minister under section 435 ;
, in relation to a regional growth strategy, means initiation under section 433 ;
includes the City of Vancouver;
includes
an official settlement plan under section 809 (3) of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 290, before that section was repealed by section 4 of the ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 1 of a rural land use bylaw, and

bcl:text.#text: an official development plan under the ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirement for regional context statement in municipal official community plans]
bcl:text.#text: means a regional context statement under section 446 ;
means a matter that involves coordination between or affects more than one municipality, more than one electoral area, or at least one of each, in a regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Part also applies to amendment and repeal of regional growth strategy
bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part, as it applies to the initiation, development and adoption of a regional growth strategy, applies to the amendment and repeal of a regional growth strategy.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Application and Content of Regional Growth Strategy

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose of regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The purpose of a regional growth strategy is to promote human settlement that is socially, economically and environmentally healthy and that makes efficient use of public facilities and services, land and other resources.
Without limiting subsection (1), to the extent that a regional growth strategy deals with these matters, it should work towards but not be limited to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: avoiding urban sprawl and ensuring that development takes place where adequate facilities exist or can be provided in a timely, economic and efficient manner;
settlement patterns that minimize the use of automobiles and encourage walking, bicycling and the efficient use of public transit;
the efficient movement of goods and people while making effective use of transportation and utility corridors;
protecting environmentally sensitive areas;
maintaining the integrity of a secure and productive resource base, including the agricultural land reserve;
economic development that supports the unique character of communities;
reducing and preventing air, land and water pollution;
adequate, affordable and appropriate housing;
adequate inventories of suitable land and resources for future settlement;
protecting the quality and quantity of ground water and surface water;
settlement patterns that minimize the risks associated with natural hazards;
preserving, creating and linking urban and rural open space, including parks and recreation areas;
planning for energy supply and promoting efficient use, conservation and alternative forms of energy;
good stewardship of land, sites and structures with cultural heritage value.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Content of regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may adopt a regional growth strategy for the purpose of guiding decisions on growth, change and development within its regional district.
A regional growth strategy must cover a period of at least 20 years from the time of its initiation and must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a comprehensive statement on the future of the region, including the social, economic and environmental objectives of the board in relation to the regional district;
population and employment projections for the period covered by the regional growth strategy;
to the extent that these are regional matters, actions proposed for the regional district to provide for the needs of the projected population in relation to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: housing,
transportation,
regional district services,
parks and natural areas, and
economic development;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the extent that these are regional matters, targets for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the regional district, and policies and actions proposed for the regional district with respect to achieving those targets.

in:desc: [when and how housing needs report must be received]
bcl:text.#text: Unless a board is exempted, or is in a class of local governments exempted, under section 585.11 , the board must consider the most recent housing needs report the board received under section 585.31 , and the housing information on which the report is based,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when developing a regional growth strategy,
when amending a regional growth strategy in relation to actions proposed under subsection (2) (c) (i) of this section, or
when considering a regional growth strategy under section 452 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the requirements of subsection (2), a regional growth strategy may deal with any other regional matter.
A regional growth strategy may include any information, maps, illustrations or other material.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Area to which regional growth strategy applies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless authorized under subsection (2) or required by regulation under section 431, a regional growth strategy must apply to all of the regional district for which it is adopted.
On request by the applicable board or boards, the minister may authorize a regional growth strategy that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: applies to only part of a regional district, or
is developed jointly by 2 or more regional districts to apply to all or parts of those regional districts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may establish terms and conditions for a regional growth strategy authorized under subsection (2) or required under section 431.

If the minister considers it necessary or advisable for a regional district service in relation to a regional growth strategy referred to in subsection (3), the minister may, by order, give directions respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: operation of the service;
sharing of costs;
voting on bylaws and resolutions relating to the service;
the intergovernmental advisory committee;
other matters relating to the regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To the extent of any inconsistency between this Act and an order under subsection (4), the order prevails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulation requiring regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the recommendation of the minister, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, do one or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designate areas for which a regional growth strategy must be developed and adopted;
specify a time period within which the regional growth strategy must be adopted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must not make a recommendation referred to in subsection (1) unless, in the opinion of the minister, the area to which the regional growth strategy is proposed to apply has been experiencing significant change in its population, its economic development or an aspect of growth or development that involves coordination between local governments or affects more than one local government.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements for adoption

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are required before a regional growth strategy is adopted:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the regional growth strategy must be initiated in accordance with section 433;
consultation must be conducted in accordance with section 434;

bcl:text.#text: the regional growth strategy must be accepted by affected local governments in accordance with section 436, except in relation to an amendment under section 437 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to subsection (1) (c), a regional growth strategy may be adopted without acceptance in relation to a specific provision if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provision is included on the basis that it is not binding on the jurisdiction of an affected local government that has refused to accept it, and
the board considers that it is not essential to the regional growth strategy that the provision apply to that jurisdiction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A provision included under subsection (2) becomes binding on a jurisdiction if, at any time after adoption of the regional growth strategy, the affected local government for the jurisdiction indicates to the board that it accepts the provision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initiation of regional growth strategy process

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The preparation of a regional growth strategy must be initiated by resolution of the board.

bcl:text.#text: If a regional growth strategy is to apply to less than the entire regional district or is to be prepared jointly with another regional district, this must be authorized under section 430 (2)  or required under section 431  before the regional growth strategy is initiated.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, at the time of initiation, the board proposes to deal with an additional regional matter under section 429 (3), the initiating resolution must identify the matter.
The proposing board must give written notice of an initiation under this section to affected local governments and to the minister.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consultation during development of regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the development of a regional growth strategy,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposing board must provide opportunity for consultation with persons, organizations and authorities that the board considers will be affected by the regional growth strategy, and
the board and the affected local governments must make all reasonable efforts to reach agreement on a proposed regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1) (a), as soon as practicable after the initiation of a regional growth strategy, the board must adopt a consultation plan that, in the opinion of the board, provides opportunities for early and ongoing consultation with, at a minimum, the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: its citizens;
affected local governments;
first nations;
boards of education, greater boards and improvement district boards;
the Provincial and federal governments and their agencies.

bcl:text.#text: In adopting a consultation plan under subsection (2), the board must consider whether the plan should include the holding of a public hearing to provide an opportunity for persons, organizations and authorities to make their views known before the regional growth strategy is submitted for acceptance under section 436 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may make regulations respecting the procedure to be used for hearings under subsection (3).
A failure to comply with a consultation plan under subsection (2) does not invalidate the regional growth strategy as long as reasonable consultation has been conducted.
For certainty, at any time during the development of a regional growth strategy, additional regional matters may be included under section 429 (3).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Facilitation of agreement during development of regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may appoint facilitators for the purposes of this Part, whose responsibilities are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to monitor and assist local governments in reaching agreement on the acceptance of regional growth strategies during their development by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: facilitating negotiations between the local governments,
facilitating the resolution of anticipated objections,
assisting local governments in setting up and using non-binding resolution processes, and
facilitating the involvement of the Provincial and federal governments and their agencies, first nations, boards of education, greater boards and improvement district boards, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to assist local governments in entering into implementation agreements under section 451.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On being notified that a regional growth strategy has been initiated, the minister may designate a person appointed under subsection (1) as the facilitator responsible in relation to the regional growth strategy.

At any time until the end of the period for acceptance or refusal of the proposed regional growth strategy under section 436 (4) (b), the facilitator is to provide assistance referred to in subsection (1) (a) of this section if requested to do so

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the proposing board or an affected local government, or
by an electoral area director of the proposing board, if the request is supported by at least 2 other directors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Once a facilitator becomes involved under subsection (3), the proposing board and affected local governments must provide information as requested by the facilitator and must otherwise cooperate with the facilitator in fulfilling the facilitator's responsibilities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Acceptance by affected local governments

bcl:text.in:desc: [settlement of regional growth strategy in acceptance not otherwise reached]
bcl:text.#text: Before it is adopted, a regional growth strategy must be accepted by the affected local governments or, failing acceptance, become binding on the affected local governments under section 440 (6) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Acceptance of a regional growth strategy by an affected local government must be done by resolution of the local government.
For the purposes of this section, before third reading of the bylaw to adopt a regional growth strategy, the board must submit the regional growth strategy to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the council of each municipality all or part of which is covered by the regional growth strategy;
the board of directors of the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority if the regional growth strategy is for the Metro Vancouver Regional District;
the board of each regional district that is adjoining an area to which the regional growth strategy is to apply;
the facilitator or, if no facilitator for the regional growth strategy has been designated, the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After receiving a proposed regional growth strategy under subsection (3), each affected local government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: review the regional growth strategy in the context of any official community plans and regional growth strategies for its jurisdiction, both those that are current and those that are in preparation, and in the context of any other matters that affect its jurisdiction, and
subject to an extension by the facilitator under section 438 (3), within 60 days of receipt either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: accept the regional growth strategy, or
respond, by resolution, to the proposing board indicating that the local government refuses to accept the regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An acceptance under subsection (4) (b) becomes effective

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when all affected local governments have accepted the regional growth strategy, or
at the end of the period for acceptance or refusal under that subsection if, at the end of that period, all affected local governments have not accepted the regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an affected local government fails to act under subsection (4) (b) within the period for acceptance or refusal, the local government is deemed to have accepted the regional growth strategy.
In the resolution under subsection (4) (b) (ii), the affected local government must indicate

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each provision to which it objects,
the reasons for its objection, and

whether it is willing that a provision to which it objects be included in the regional growth strategy on the basis that the provision will not apply to its jurisdiction, as referred to in section 432 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An affected local government is deemed to have accepted any provision of the regional growth strategy to which it does not indicate an objection under subsection (7).
All affected local governments are entitled to participate in any non-binding resolution processes used to resolve an objection or anticipated objection by an affected local government.

If an area in a regional district is incorporated as a new municipality and the regional district has adopted a regional growth strategy for all or part of the area of the new municipality, the regional growth strategy is binding on that new municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minor amendments to regional growth strategies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As exceptions to the requirements of section 436 that would otherwise apply to the amendment of a regional growth strategy, a regional growth strategy may be amended

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with provisions under subsection (2) of this section, or
if the regional growth strategy does not include provisions under subsection (2) of this section, in accordance with subsection (3) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional growth strategy may include provisions that establish a process for minor amendments to the regional growth strategy, which must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: criteria for determining whether a proposed amendment is minor for the purposes of allowing the process to apply;
a means for the views of affected local governments respecting a proposed minor amendment to be obtained and considered;
a means for providing notice to affected local governments respecting a proposed minor amendment;
procedures for adopting the minor amendment bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may proceed with a proposed amendment to a regional growth strategy as a minor amendment in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the board must give notice, including notice that the proposed amendment may be determined to be a minor amendment and the date, time and place of the board meeting at which the amending bylaw is to be considered for first reading, to each affected local government at least 30 days before the meeting;
before first reading of the amending bylaw, the board must allow an affected local government that is not represented on the board an opportunity to make representations to the board;

bcl:text.#text: if, at first reading, the amending bylaw receives an affirmative vote of all board members attending the meeting, the bylaw may be adopted in accordance with the procedures that apply to the adoption of a regional growth strategy bylaw under Division 3  of Part 6  and the board's procedure bylaw;

if, at first reading, the amending bylaw does not receive an affirmative vote of all board members attending the meeting, the bylaw may be adopted only in accordance with the procedure established by section 436 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following may not be considered a minor amendment for the purposes of this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amendment to a regional growth strategy to establish or amend a process referred to in subsection (2);
an amendment to anything that the minister has established or directed under section 430 (3) or (4) or the Lieutenant Governor in Council has required under section 431;
an amendment to a regional growth strategy proposed as a result of a non-binding resolution process under section 439 (2) (a);
a type of amendment prescribed by regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Resolution of anticipated objections

bcl:text.#text: Before the end of the 60 days referred to in section 436 (4) (b) , the facilitator may require the proposing board and the affected local governments to identify any issues on which they anticipate that acceptance may not be reached.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an issue is identified under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the facilitator may require the proposing board and the affected local governments to send representatives to a meeting convened by the facilitator for the purpose of clarifying the issues involved and encouraging their resolution, and

the proposing board and the affected local governments must provide information as requested by the facilitator and must otherwise cooperate with the facilitator in fulfilling the facilitator's responsibilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, the facilitator may extend the period for acceptance or refusal under section 436 (4) (b) before or after the end of that period.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Resolution of refusal to accept

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The proposing board must notify the minister in writing if an affected local government refuses to accept a proposed regional growth strategy.
After being notified under subsection (1), the minister must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a non-binding resolution process to attempt to reach acceptance on the regional growth strategy, or
if satisfied that resolution using a non-binding resolution process under paragraph (a) is unlikely, direct that the regional growth strategy is to be settled under section 440.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If requiring a non-binding resolution process under subsection (2) (a), the minister

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must, at the time of requiring the non-binding resolution process, specify a time period within which the parties must begin the resolution process, and
may, before or after the resolution process has begun, specify a time period within which the parties must conclude the resolution process.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The choice of non-binding resolution process under subsection (2) (a) is to be determined by agreement between the proposing board and the affected local government or governments that refused to accept the regional growth strategy but, if the minister considers that these parties will not be able to reach agreement, the minister must direct which process is to be used.
Any affected local government may participate in a non-binding resolution process under this section.

Unless otherwise agreed by these parties, the fees of any neutral person participating in the non-binding resolution process and the administrative costs of the process, other than the costs incurred by the parties participating in the process, are to be shared proportionally between the proposing board and the affected local governments that participate in the process on the basis of the converted value of land and improvements in their jurisdictions.
An affected local government is deemed to have accepted the provisions of the regional growth strategy that were not changed as a result of a resolution process under subsection (2) (a).
The following apply if changes to a regional growth strategy are proposed as a result of a resolution process under subsection (2) (a):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the regional growth strategy must be submitted again to the affected local governments for acceptance, subject to paragraph (b) of this subsection, in accordance with section 436;

bcl:text.#text: an affected local government may not indicate an objection to a provision it is deemed to have accepted under section 436 (8)  or subsection (7) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If acceptance is not reached within 60 days after a non-binding resolution process under this section is concluded, the regional growth strategy must be settled in accordance with section 440 unless the proposing board and the affected local governments can reach agreement on the provisions of the regional growth strategy before the settlement process is completed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement of regional growth strategy if acceptance not otherwise reached

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If acceptance by affected local governments cannot otherwise be reached under this Part, the regional growth strategy is to be settled by one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: peer panel settlement in accordance with section 441 (1);
final proposal arbitration in accordance with section 441 (2);
full arbitration in accordance with section 441 (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If more than one affected local government has refused to accept a regional growth strategy, whether the refusals are in relation to the same or different issues, the regional growth strategy is to be settled for all affected local governments in the same settlement proceedings.

The choice of process for settlement is to be determined by agreement between the proposing board and the affected local government or governments that refused to accept the regional growth strategy but, if the minister considers that these parties will not be able to reach agreement, the minister must direct which process is to be used.
Any affected local government may participate in a settlement process under section 441.

During the 60 days after the provisions of a regional growth strategy are settled under section 441, the proposing board and the affected local governments may agree on the acceptance of a regional growth strategy that differs from the one settled.

At the end of the period under subsection (5), unless agreement is reached as referred to in that subsection, the provisions of a regional growth strategy as settled under section 441 become binding on the proposing board and all affected local governments, whether or not they participated in the settlement process.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Options for settlement process

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As one option, the provisions of a regional growth strategy may be settled by a peer panel as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the panel is to be composed of 3 persons selected from the applicable list prepared under section 442 (1);

the selection of the panel is to be done by agreement between the proposing board and the affected local government or governments that refused to accept the regional growth strategy or, if the minister considers that these parties will not be able to reach agreement, by the minister;
subject to the regulations, the panel may conduct the proceedings in the manner it determines;

the panel must settle the disputed issues of the regional growth strategy and may make any changes to the provisions of the regional growth strategy that it considers necessary to resolve those issues;
the panel must give written reasons for its decision if this is requested by the proposing board or an affected local government before the panel retires to make its decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a second option, the provisions of a regional growth strategy may be settled by final proposal arbitration by a single arbitrator as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the arbitrator is to be selected from the applicable list prepared under section 442 (1);

the selection of the arbitrator is to be done by agreement between the proposing board and the affected local government or governments that refused to accept the regional growth strategy or, if the minister considers that these parties will not be able to reach agreement, by the minister;

subject to the regulations, the arbitrator must conduct the proceedings on the basis of a review of written documents and written submissions only, and must determine each disputed issue by selecting one of the final written proposals for resolving that issue submitted by one of the participating parties;
the provisions of the regional growth strategy will be as settled by the arbitrator after incorporation of the final proposals selected by the arbitrator under paragraph (c);
no written reasons are to be provided by the arbitrator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a third option, the provisions of a regional growth strategy may be settled by full arbitration by a single arbitrator as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the arbitrator is to be selected from the applicable list prepared under section 442 (1);

the selection of the arbitrator is to be done by agreement between the proposing board and the affected local government or governments that refused to accept the regional growth strategy or, if the minister considers that these parties will not be able to reach agreement, by the minister;
subject to the regulations, the arbitrator may conduct the proceedings in the manner the arbitrator determines;
the provisions of the regional growth strategy will be as settled by the arbitrator, who is not restricted in a decision to submissions made by the parties on the disputed issues;
the arbitrator must give written reasons for the decision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General provisions regarding settlement process

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Lists of persons who may act on a panel under section 441 (1), as an arbitrator under section 441 (2) or as an arbitrator under section 441 (3) are to be prepared by the minister in consultation with representatives of the Union of British Columbia Municipalities.

Persons who may be included on a list for a panel under section 441 (1) are persons who are or have been elected officials of a local government or who, in the opinion of the minister, have appropriate experience in relation to local government matters.

In the case of a specific regional growth strategy, a person may not be appointed to a panel or as an arbitrator if the person is, or was at any time since the regional growth strategy was initiated, an elected official of the proposing board or of an affected local government for the regional growth strategy.

Subject to a direction by the panel or arbitrator or to an agreement between the parties, the fees and reasonable and necessary expenses of the members of a peer panel or arbitrator and the administrative costs of the process, other than the costs incurred by the parties participating in the process, are to be shared proportionally between the proposing board and the affected local governments that participate in the process on the basis of the converted value of land and improvements in their jurisdictions.

The directors of the electoral areas to which the regional growth strategy is proposed to apply and the Provincial government may make representations in the settlement process, subject to any conditions set by the panel or arbitrator.

bcl:text.in:desc: [60 days after provisions settled by panel or arbitrator]
bcl:text.#text: The time limit for bringing any judicial review of a decision of a panel or arbitrator under section 441 is the end of the period for agreement under section 440 (5) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may make regulations regarding settlement processes under section 441, which may be different for different settlement processes, including regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting matters that a panel or arbitrator may or must consider,
respecting the authority of a panel or arbitrator to settle a regional growth strategy, and
respecting the authority of a panel or arbitrator to require the cooperation of local governments in relation to the settlement processes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Adoption of regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional growth strategy must be adopted by bylaw.
As soon as practicable after adopting a regional growth strategy, the board must send a copy of the regional growth strategy to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the affected local governments,
any greater boards and improvement districts within the regional district, and
the minister.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement to adopt finalized regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a proposed regional growth strategy has been accepted by the affected local governments or has become binding under section 440 (6), but has not been adopted by the proposing board, on the recommendation of the minister, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, specify a time period within which the board must adopt the regional growth strategy.

If the board does not adopt the regional growth strategy within the time period specified under subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, deem the regional growth strategy to have been adopted by the board, in which case it applies as if it had been adopted by a valid bylaw of the board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regional district must conform with regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All bylaws adopted by a regional district board after the board has adopted a regional growth strategy, and all services undertaken by a regional district after the board has adopted a regional growth strategy, must be consistent with the regional growth strategy.

All bylaws adopted by a greater board or an improvement district board after the adoption of a regional growth strategy applicable to its jurisdiction, and all works and services provided by a greater board or an improvement district board after the adoption of a regional growth strategy applicable to its jurisdiction, must be consistent with the regional growth strategy.

A regional growth strategy does not commit or authorize a regional district, municipality, greater board or improvement district to proceed with any project that is specified in the regional growth strategy.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement for regional context statements in municipal official community plans

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a regional growth strategy applies to all or part of the same area of a municipality as an official community plan, the official community plan must include a regional context statement that is accepted in accordance with this Division by the board of the regional district for which the regional growth strategy is adopted.

After a regional growth strategy is adopted, the requirement under subsection (1) must be fulfilled by the applicable council submitting a proposed regional context statement to the board within 2 years after the regional growth strategy is adopted.

bcl:text.#text: If a regional growth strategy is binding on a new municipality under section 436 (10)  and the regional growth strategy applies to all or part of the same area of the municipality as an official community plan, the requirement under subsection (1) of this section must be fulfilled by the council submitting a proposed regional context statement to the board within the earlier of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the period established by the Lieutenant Governor in Council by letters patent;
2 years after the municipality was incorporated.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Content of regional context statement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional context statement must specifically identify

bcl:text.#text: the relationship between the official community plan and the matters referred to in section 429 (2)  and any other regional matters included under section 429 (3) , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if applicable, how the official community plan is to be made consistent with the regional growth strategy over time.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional context statement and the rest of the official community plan must be consistent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board acceptance of proposed regional context statement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The council must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit a proposed regional context statement required under this Division for acceptance by the board,
submit any amendments to the regional context statement for acceptance by the board, and

review the regional context statement at least once every 5 years after its latest acceptance by the board and, if no amendment is proposed, submit the statement to the board for its continued acceptance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of subsection (1), the board must respond by resolution within 120 days after receipt indicating whether or not it accepts the regional context statement or amendment and, if the board refuses to accept the regional context statement or amendment, indicating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each provision to which it objects, and
the reasons for its objection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the board fails to act under subsection (2) within the period for acceptance or refusal under that subsection, the board is deemed to have accepted the regional context statement or amendment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement of proposed regional context statement
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following sections, as they apply to acceptance of a regional growth strategy by an affected local government and adoption by the regional district board, apply to the acceptance of a regional context statement by the board and adoption by the municipal council:

bcl:text.#text: section 435 ;
section 438 ;
section 439 ;
section 440 ;
section 441 ;
section 442 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirement to adopt finalized regional growth strategy]
bcl:text.#text: section 444 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Intergovernmental advisory committees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may establish an intergovernmental advisory committee for its regional district,
must establish an intergovernmental advisory committee for its regional district when a regional growth strategy is initiated, and
must establish an intergovernmental advisory committee for its regional district if

bcl:text.#text: there is a proposed amendment to the regional growth strategy, except in relation to an amendment under section 437 , and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the committee established under paragraph (a) or (b) of this subsection no longer exists.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The role of an intergovernmental advisory committee is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to advise the applicable local governments on the development and implementation of the regional growth strategy, and
to facilitate coordination of Provincial and local government actions, policies and programs as they relate to the development and implementation of the regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The membership of an intergovernmental advisory committee is to include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the planning director of the regional district, or another official appointed by the board;
