the planning director, or another official appointed by the applicable council, of each municipality all or part of which is covered by the regional growth strategy;

for the purposes of an intergovernmental advisory committee established in the Metro Vancouver Regional District, the planning director of the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority or another official appointed by the board of directors of that authority;
senior representatives of the Provincial government and Provincial government agencies and corporations, determined by the minister after consultation with the board;
representatives of other authorities and organizations if invited to participate by the board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Implementation agreements

bcl:text.#text: Without limiting section 263  of this Act or section 8 (1)  of the , a local government may enter into agreements respecting the coordination of activities relating to the implementation of a regional growth strategy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, the Provincial government may enter into agreements under subsection (1) respecting Provincial commitments to act consistently with a regional growth strategy and to take actions necessary to implement a regional growth strategy.

In addition to agreements with the Provincial government and its agencies, agreements under subsection (1) may be made with the federal government and its agencies, other local governments, first nations, boards of education, greater boards, the South Coast British Columbia Transportation Authority, improvement district boards and other local authorities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regular reports and review of regional growth strategy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regional district that has adopted a regional growth strategy must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish a program to monitor its implementation and the progress made towards its objectives and actions, and
prepare an annual report on that implementation and progress.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At least once every 5 years, a regional district that has adopted a regional growth strategy must consider whether the regional growth strategy must be reviewed for possible amendment.

bcl:text.in:desc: [required consultations during development of regional growth strategy]
bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of subsection (2), the regional district must provide an opportunity for input on the need for review from the persons, organizations and authorities referred to in section 434 (2) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provincial policy guidelines

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may establish policy guidelines regarding the process of developing and adopting regional growth strategies.
The minister, or the minister together with other ministers, may establish policy guidelines regarding the content of regional growth strategies.
Guidelines under subsection (1) or (2) may be established only after consultation by the minister with representatives of the Union of British Columbia Municipalities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minister may require official community plans and land use bylaws
bcl:section.bcl:text: After a regional growth strategy has been adopted, the minister may require a municipality or regional district to adopt, within a time period specified by the minister, an official community plan, a zoning bylaw or a subdivision servicing bylaw for an area that is covered by the regional growth strategy and to which no such plan or bylaw currently applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Area of authority for municipalities and regional districts
bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless express authority is given by another provision of this Part,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the authority of a municipality under this Part is limited to the municipality, and
the authority of a regional district under this Part is limited to that part of the regional district that is not in a municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rural land use bylaws

bcl:text.#text: A rural land use bylaw adopted under section 886 of the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 323, before that section was repealed by the , is deemed to be a general bylaw under section 138  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The provisions of a rural land use bylaw are deemed to be provisions of an official community plan, zoning bylaw or subdivision servicing bylaw, as applicable depending on their nature, included in a general bylaw.
The following provisions do not apply to a rural land use bylaw:

bcl:text.#text: section 472 (2) (a) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Not in force.]

bcl:text.in:desc: [restrictions on zoning authority in relation to transit-oriented areas]
bcl:text.#text: section 481.01 ;
section 481.3 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limits on use of this Part and Part 15

bcl:text.#text: The following powers must not be exercised in a manner that unreasonably prohibits or restricts the use or density of use required to be permitted under section 481.3 :
a power under section 488 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a power in relation to a land use regulation bylaw or land use permit;

bcl:text.#text: a power in relation to a heritage alteration permit, as defined in section 586 ;
a power under section 614 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limit on compensation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Compensation is not payable to any person for any reduction in the value of that person's interest in land, or for any loss or damages that result from any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the adoption of an official community plan;
the adoption of a bylaw under

bcl:text.#text: Division 5 ,
Division 12 , or
Division 13 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the issue of a land use permit;

bcl:text.in:desc: [termination of all remaining land use contracts in 2024]
bcl:text.#text: the termination of a land use contract under section 547 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [process for early termination of land use contract]
bcl:text.#text: the adoption of a bylaw under section 548 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a bylaw referred to in paragraph (b) of that subsection that restricts the use of land to a public use.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information that must be available to the public

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must maintain a current list of the following:

bcl:text.#text: every bylaw in effect under this Part or Part 15  and a general description of the purpose of the bylaw;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every bylaw under this Part or Part 15 that has been given first reading, a general description of the bylaw and its current status;
every permit issued under this Part or Part 15.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A list under subsection (1) must be available for public inspection at the local government offices during their regular office hours.
Non-compliance with subsection (1) or (2), or any inaccuracy in a list, does not affect the validity of a bylaw or permit referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development approval procedures

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government that has adopted an official community plan bylaw or a zoning bylaw must, by bylaw, define procedures under which an owner of land may apply for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amendment to the plan or bylaw, or
the issue of a permit under this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must consider every application for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amendment referred to in subsection (1) (a), or
the issue of a permit referred to in subsection (1) (b) that requires a resolution of the council or board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bylaw under subsection (1) establishes a time limit for reapplication, the time limit may be varied in relation to a specific reapplication by an affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of the local government members eligible to vote on the reapplication.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Advisory planning commission

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw, establish an advisory planning commission to advise council on all matters respecting land use, community planning or proposed bylaws and permits under Divisions 4 to 14 of this Part and section 546 that are referred to the commission by the council.

A board may, by bylaw, establish an advisory planning commission for one or more electoral areas or portions of an electoral area to advise the board, or a regional district director representing the electoral area, on all matters referred to the commission by the board or by that director respecting land use, the preparation and adoption of an official community plan or a proposed bylaw or permit that may be enacted or issued under this Part.
The bylaw establishing an advisory planning commission must provide for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the composition of and the manner of appointing members to the commission,
the procedures governing the conduct of the commission, and
the referral of matters to the commission.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At least 2/3 of the members of an advisory planning commission must be residents of the municipality or the electoral area.
The following are not eligible to be a member of an advisory planning commission, but may attend a meeting of the commission in a resource capacity:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a council member;
a regional district director;
an employee or officer of the local government;
an approving officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The members of an advisory planning commission must serve without remuneration, but may be paid reasonable and necessary expenses that arise directly out of the performance of their duties.
If an advisory planning commission is established, minutes of all of its meetings must be kept and, on request, made available to the public.

bcl:text: If an advisory planning commission is considering
the applicant for the amendment or permit is entitled to attend meetings of the commission and be heard.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amendment to an official community plan or a bylaw, or
the issue of a permit,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Fees related to applications and inspections

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, impose one or more of the following types of fees:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: application fees for an application to initiate changes to the provisions of

bcl:text.#text: an official community plan or bylaw under Division 4  of this Part,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a land use regulation bylaw,

bcl:text.in:desc: [Subdivision and Development: Requirements and Related Matters]
bcl:text.#text: a bylaw under Division 11  of this Part, or
a bylaw under Part 15 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: application fees for the issue of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a land use permit under this Part, or
a heritage alteration permit under section 617;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: application fees for an amendment to

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment and discharge of land use contract by agreement]
bcl:text.#text: a land use contract under section 546 , or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a heritage revitalization agreement under section 610;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: application fees for an application to a board of variance;
fees to cover the costs of administering and inspecting works and services under this Part that are costs additional to those related to fees under paragraphs (a) to (d);
subdivision application fees, which may vary with the number, size and type of parcels involved in a proposed subdivision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A fee imposed under subsection (1) must not exceed the estimated average costs of processing, inspection, advertising and administration that are usually related to the type of application or other matter to which the fee relates.
The minister may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the minister considers necessary or advisable respecting the imposition of fees under subsection (1), and
prescribing fees for applications referred to in subsection (1) (f).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regulation under subsection (3) prevails over a bylaw under subsection (1) to the extent of any conflict.
No other fee, charge or tax may be imposed in addition to a fee under subsection (1) as a condition of the matter referred to in that subsection to which the fee relates.

A local government, the City of Vancouver or an approving officer must not do either of the following unless authorized by this Act, by another Act or by a bylaw made under the authority of this Act or another Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose a fee, charge or tax;
require a work or service to be provided.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Withholding building permits and business licences that conflict with bylaws in preparation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may direct that a building permit be withheld for a period of 30 days, beginning on the day the application for the permit was made, if it passes a resolution identifying what it considers to be a conflict between a development proposed in the application for a building permit and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official community plan that is under preparation, or
a bylaw, under any of the following, that is under preparation:

bcl:text.#text: Division 5 ;
Division 12 ;
section 523 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirements in relation to flood plain areas]
bcl:text.#text: section 524 ;
section 525 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply unless a local government has, by resolution at least 7 days before the application for a building permit, begun the preparation of a plan or bylaw that is in conflict with the application.
During the 30 day period referred to in subsection (1), the local government must consider the application for the permit and may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct the permit be withheld for a further 60 days, or
grant the permit, but impose conditions in it that would be in the public interest, having regard to the plan or bylaw that is under preparation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the local government does not adopt a plan or bylaw referred to in subsection (1) within the 60 day period, the owners of the land for which a building permit was withheld under this section are entitled to compensation for damages arising from the withholding of the building permit.
For the purposes of subsection (4),

bcl:text.#text: Division 7  of Part 8  of this Act applies in relation to a regional district, and
Division 4  of Part 3  of the  applies in relation to a municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to land that is subject to a resolution under subsection (1), the council may direct that a business licence in respect of the same land be withheld for a period not longer than 90 days, if the council considers that the use to which the land would be put and to which the business licence application relates would be contrary to the use that would be permitted by the bylaw that is under preparation.

bcl:text.#text: Any requirement to approve a permit or licence under this section is subject to section 557 .

bcl:division.bcl:text: Public Hearings on Planning and Land Use Bylaws

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When public hearing is required

bcl:text: Subject to this section, a local government must not adopt
without holding a public hearing on the bylaw for the purpose of allowing the public to make representations to the local government respecting matters contained in the proposed bylaw.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official community plan bylaw,
a zoning bylaw, or

bcl:text.#text: a bylaw under section 548

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a local government is not required to hold a public hearing on a proposed zoning bylaw if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official community plan is in effect for the area that is the subject of the zoning bylaw, and
the bylaw is consistent with the official community plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must not hold a public hearing on a proposed zoning bylaw if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official community plan is in effect for the area that is the subject of the zoning bylaw,
the bylaw is consistent with the official community plan,
the sole purpose of the bylaw is to permit a development that is, in whole or in part, a residential development, and
the residential component of the development accounts for at least half of the gross floor area of all buildings and other structures proposed as part of the development.

bcl:text.#text: A local government must not hold a public hearing on a zoning bylaw proposed for the sole purpose of complying with section 481.3 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Public hearing procedures

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A public hearing referred to in section 464 must be held after first reading of the bylaw and before third reading.
Subject to subsection (1.2), a public hearing referred to in section 464 may be conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities.
The facilities referred to in subsection (1.1) must enable the public hearing's participants to hear, or watch and hear, each other.

At the public hearing, all persons who believe that their interest in property is affected by the proposed bylaw must be afforded a reasonable opportunity to be heard or to present written submissions respecting matters contained in the bylaw that is the subject of the hearing.
Subject to subsection (2), the chair of the public hearing may establish procedural rules for the conduct of the hearing.
More than one bylaw may be considered at a public hearing and more than one bylaw may be included in a notice of public hearing.

A written report of each public hearing, containing a summary of the nature of the representations respecting the bylaw that were made at the hearing, must be prepared and maintained as a public record.
A report under subsection (5) must be certified as being fair and accurate by the person preparing the report and, if applicable, by the person to whom the hearing was delegated under section 469.
A public hearing may be adjourned and no further notice of the hearing is necessary if the following are stated to those in attendance at the time the hearing is adjourned:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time and date of the resumption of the hearing;
the place of the resumed hearing, if applicable;
the way in which the hearing is to be conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities, if applicable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of public hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a public hearing referred to in section 464 is to be held, the local government must give notice of the hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with this section, and

bcl:text.#text: in the case of a public hearing on an official community plan that includes a schedule under section 614 (3) (b) , in accordance with section 592 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice must state the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time and date of the hearing;
the place of the hearing, if applicable;
if the hearing is conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities, the way in which the hearing is to be conducted by those means;
in general terms, the purpose of the bylaw;
the land or lands that are the subject of the bylaw;
the place where and the times and dates when copies of the bylaw may be inspected.

bcl:text.#text: The notice must be published in accordance with section 94  of the .

bcl:text.in:desc: [bylaw to provide for alternative means of publication]
bcl:text.#text: If the local government has adopted a bylaw under section 94.2  of the , the notice must be published by at least one of the means of publication specified in the bylaw not less than 3 days and not more than 10 days before the public hearing.
If the local government has not adopted a bylaw under section 94.2 of the , the last publication of the notice must be not less than 3 days and not more than 10 days before the public hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the bylaw in relation to which the notice is given alters the permitted use or density of any area or the residential rental tenure in any area, or limits the form of tenure to residential rental tenure in any area, the notice must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (6), include a sketch that shows the area that is the subject of the bylaw alteration, including the name of adjoining roads if applicable, and

bcl:text: be mailed or otherwise delivered at least 10 days before the public hearing
of all parcels, any part of which is the subject of the bylaw alteration or is within a distance specified by bylaw from that part of the area that is subject to the bylaw alteration.

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the owners, as shown on the assessment roll as at the date of the first reading of the bylaw, and
to any tenants in occupation, as at the date of the mailing or delivery of the notice,

bcl:text.#text: If the bylaw in relation to which the notice is given is a bylaw under section 548 , the notice must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (6), include a sketch that shows the area subject to the land use contract that the bylaw will terminate, including the name of adjoining roads if applicable, and

bcl:text: be mailed or otherwise delivered at least 10 days before the public hearing

of all parcels, any part of which is subject to the land use contract that the bylaw will terminate or is within a distance specified by bylaw from that part of the area that is subject to that land use contract.

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to the owners, as shown on the assessment roll as at the date of the first reading of the bylaw, and
to any tenants in occupation, as at the date of the mailing or delivery of the notice,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the location of the land can be clearly identified in the notice in a manner other than a sketch, it may be identified in that manner.
Subsection (4) does not apply if 10 or more parcels owned by 10 or more persons are the subject of the bylaw alteration.
The obligation to deliver a notice under subsection (4) or (5) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice if public hearing not held

bcl:text.in:desc: [public hearing not required, or prohibited, for certain zoning bylaws]
bcl:text.#text: If a local government decides not to hold, or is prohibited from holding, a public hearing referred to in section 464 (2), (3) or (4)  on a proposed zoning bylaw, it must give notice in accordance with this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice must state the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in general terms, the purpose of the zoning bylaw;
the land or lands that are the subject of the bylaw;
the date of the first reading of the bylaw;
the place where and the times and dates when copies of the bylaw may be inspected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 466 (3) to (4) and (6) to (8) applies to a notice under this section, except that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reference in that section to a public hearing is to be read as a reference to the first reading of the bylaw, and
the reference in subsection (4) (b) (i) of that section to the date of the first reading of the bylaw is to be read as a reference to the date of the mailing or delivery of the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Posted notices respecting proposed bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting the obligations to give notice under sections 466 and 467, a local government may, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the posting of a notice on land that is the subject of a bylaw, and
specify the size, form and content of the notice and the manner in which and the locations where it must be posted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Specifications under subsection (1) (b) may be different for different areas, zones, uses within a zone and parcel sizes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Delegation of public hearings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government makes a delegation in relation to one or more public hearings,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that delegation does not apply to a hearing unless the notice of hearing under section 466 includes notice that the hearing is to be held by a delegate, and
the resolution or bylaw making the delegation must be available for public inspection along with copies of the bylaw referred to in section 466 (2) (e).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the holding of a public hearing is delegated, the local government must not adopt the bylaw that is the subject of the hearing until the delegate reports to the local government, either orally or in writing, the views expressed at the hearing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure after public hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a public hearing, the council or board may, without further notice or hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adopt or defeat the bylaw, or
alter and then adopt the bylaw, provided that the alteration does not

bcl:text: do any of the following:
of any area from that originally specified in the bylaw, or

bcl:clause.bcl:text: without the owner's consent, decrease the density

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: alter the bylaw in relation to residential rental tenure in any area.

bcl:text: A member of a council or board who
may vote on the adoption of the bylaw if an oral or written report of the public hearing has been given to the member in accordance with subsection (3).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to vote on a bylaw that was the subject of a public hearing, and
was not present at the public hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The report referred to in subsection (2) must be given to the member by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an officer or employee of the local government, or
if applicable, the delegate who conducted the public hearing.

bcl:text.#text: After a public hearing referred to in section 464 or third reading following notice under section 467 , a court must not quash or declare invalid the bylaw on the grounds that an owner or occupier

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not see or receive the notice under section 466 or 467, if the court is satisfied that there was a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the notice, or
who attended the public hearing or who can otherwise be shown to have been aware of the hearing, did not see or receive the notice, and was not prejudiced by not seeing or receiving it.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purposes of official community plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan is a statement of objectives and policies to guide decisions on planning and land use management, within the area covered by the plan, respecting the purposes of local government.

bcl:text.#text: To the extent that it deals with these matters, an official community plan should work towards the purpose and goals referred to in section 428 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaw to adopt official community plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, adopt one or more official community plans.
Despite subsection (1), the following must adopt one or more official community plans:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the council of a municipality;
a prescribed board of a regional district or a board in a prescribed class of regional districts.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be included in the adopting bylaw as a schedule, and
must designate the area covered by the plan.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Content and process requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan must include statements and map designations for the area covered by the plan respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approximate location, amount, type and density of residential development required to meet anticipated housing needs over a period of at least 5 years;
the approximate location, amount and type of present and proposed commercial, industrial, institutional, agricultural, recreational and public utility land uses;
the approximate location and area of sand and gravel deposits that are suitable for future sand and gravel extraction;
restrictions on the use of land that is subject to hazardous conditions or that is environmentally sensitive to development;
the approximate location and phasing of any major road, sewer and water systems;
the approximate location and type of present and proposed public facilities, including schools, parks and waste treatment and disposal sites;
other matters that may, in respect of any plan, be required or authorized by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan must include housing policies of the local government respecting affordable housing, rental housing and special needs housing.

in:desc: [when and how housing needs report must be received]
bcl:text.#text: Unless a local government is exempted, or is in a class of local governments exempted, under section 585.11 , the local government must consider the most recent housing needs report the local government received under section 585.31 , and the housing information on which the report is based,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when developing an official community plan,
when amending an official community plan in relation to statements and map designations under subsection (1) (a) of this section, or
when amending an official community plan in relation to housing policies under subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan must include targets for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the area covered by the plan, and policies and actions of the local government proposed with respect to achieving those targets.

in:desc: [provincial policy guidelines related to transit-oriented areas]
bcl:text.#text: In developing or amending an official community plan, the local government must consider applicable guidelines, if any, under sections 582  and 585.5 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Policy statements that may be included

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan may include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: policies of the local government relating to social needs, social well-being and social development;

bcl:text.#text: a regional context statement, consistent with the rest of the plan, of how matters referred to in section 429 (2) (a) to (c) , and other matters dealt with in the plan, apply in a regional context;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: policies of the local government respecting the maintenance and enhancement of farming on land in a farming area or in an area designated for agricultural use in the plan;
policies of the local government relating to the preservation, protection, restoration and enhancement of the natural environment, its ecosystems and biological diversity.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government proposes to include a matter in an official community plan, the regulation of which is not within the jurisdiction of the local government, the plan may state only the broad objective of the local government with respect to that matter unless the minister has, under section 473 (1) (g), required or authorized the local government to state a policy with respect to that matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consultation during development of official community plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the development of an official community plan, or the repeal or amendment of an official community plan, the proposing local government must provide one or more opportunities it considers appropriate for consultation with persons, organizations and authorities it considers will be affected.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the local government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider whether the opportunities for consultation with one or more of the persons, organizations and authorities should be early and ongoing, and
specifically consider whether consultation is required with the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the board of the regional district in which the area covered by the plan is located, in the case of a municipal official community plan;
the board of any regional district that is adjacent to the area covered by the plan;
the council of any municipality that is adjacent to the area covered by the plan;
first nations;
boards of education, greater boards and improvement district boards;
the Provincial and federal governments and their agencies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Consultation under this section is in addition to the public hearing required under section 477 (3) (c).

If the development of an official community plan, or the repeal or amendment of an official community plan, might affect agricultural land, the proposing local government must consult with the Agricultural Land Commission.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consultation on planning for school facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government has adopted, or proposes to adopt or amend, an official community plan for an area that includes the whole or any part of one or more school districts, the local government must consult with the boards of education for those school districts

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time of preparing or amending the official community plan, and
in any event, at least once in each calendar year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For consultation under subsection (1), the local government must seek the input of the boards of education on the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the actual and anticipated needs for school facilities and support services in the school districts;
the size, number and location of the sites anticipated to be required for the school facilities referred to in paragraph (a);
the type of school anticipated to be required on the sites referred to in paragraph (b);
when the school facilities and support services referred to in paragraph (a) are anticipated to be required;
how the existing and proposed school facilities relate to existing or proposed community facilities in the area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Adoption procedures for official community plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan must be adopted by bylaw in accordance with this section.
Each reading of a bylaw under subsection (1) must receive,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a municipal bylaw, an affirmative vote of a majority of all council members, and

bcl:text.#text: in the case of a regional district bylaw, an affirmative vote of a majority of all directors entitled under Division 3  of Part 6  to vote on the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After first reading of a bylaw under subsection (1), the local government must do the following in the indicated order:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: first, consider the proposed official community plan in conjunction with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: its financial plan, and

bcl:text.#text: any waste management plan under Part 3  of the  that is applicable in the municipality or regional district;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: next, if the proposed official community plan applies to agricultural land, refer the plan to the Provincial Agricultural Land Commission for comment;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Public Hearings on Planning and Land Use Bylaws]
bcl:text.#text: next, hold a public hearing on the proposed official community plan in accordance with Division 3  of this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the requirements under subsection (3), a local government may consider a proposed official community plan in conjunction with any other land use planning and with any social, economic, environmental or other community planning and policies that the local government considers relevant.
The minister may make regulations in relation to subsection (3) (b)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: defining areas for which and describing circumstances in which referral to the Agricultural Land Commission under that subsection is not required, and
providing that an exception under paragraph (a) is subject to the terms and conditions specified by the minister.

bcl:text.in:desc: [at least one day between third reading and adoption]
bcl:text.#text: Despite section 135 (3)  of the , a council may adopt an official community plan at the same meeting at which the plan passed third reading.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of official community plan

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan does not commit or authorize a municipality, regional district or improvement district to proceed with any project that is specified in the plan.

bcl:text: All bylaws enacted or works undertaken by a council, board or greater board, or by the trustees of an improvement district, after the adoption of
must be consistent with the relevant plan.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official community plan, or

bcl:text.#text: an official community plan under section 711 of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 290, or an official settlement plan under section 809 of that Act, before the repeal of those sections became effective,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Zoning bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: divide the whole or part of the municipality or regional district into zones, name each zone and establish the boundaries of the zones;
limit the vertical extent of a zone and provide other zones above or below it;
regulate the following within a zone:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the use of land, buildings and other structures;
the density of the use of land, buildings and other structures;
the siting, size and dimensions of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: uses that are permitted on the land;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the location of uses on the land and within buildings and other structures;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: limit the form of tenure in accordance with section 481.1;
regulate the shape, dimensions and area, including the establishment of minimum and maximum sizes, of all parcels of land that may be created by subdivision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority under subsection (1) may be exercised by incorporating in the bylaw maps, plans, tables or other graphic material.
The power to regulate under subsection (1) includes the power to prohibit any use or uses in a zone.
A bylaw under this section may make different provisions for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different zones;
different uses within a zone;
different locations within a zone;
different standards of works and services provided;
different siting circumstances;
different protected heritage properties;

bcl:text.in:desc: [restrictions on zoning authority in relation to transit-oriented areas]
bcl:text.#text: different matters prescribed for the purposes of section 481.01 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the authority under subsection (4),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provisions under subsection (1) (d) may be different for different areas, and
the boundaries of those areas need not be the same as the boundaries of zones created under subsection (1) (a).

bcl:text.in:desc: [provincial policy guidelines related to transit-oriented areas]
bcl:text.#text: In developing or adopting a bylaw under this section, a local government must consider applicable guidelines, if any, under section 585.5 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Adoption of municipal zoning bylaw

bcl:text.in:desc: [at least one day between third reading and adoption]
bcl:text.#text: Despite section 135 (3)  of the , a council may adopt a zoning bylaw at the same meeting at which the bylaw passed third reading.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on zoning authority in relation to farming

bcl:text.in:desc: [authority and restrictions apply as declared by regulation]
bcl:text.#text: This section does not apply unless a regulation under section 553  declares that it applies.

bcl:link.in:doc: Farm Practices Protection (Right to Farm) Act

bcl:text.#text: Despite section 479  but subject to this section, a local government must not exercise the powers under that section to prohibit or restrict the use of land for a farm business in a farming area unless the local government receives the approval of the minister responsible for the administration of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister referred to in subsection (2) may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: defining areas for which and describing circumstances in which approval under that subsection is not required, and
providing that an exception under paragraph (a) is subject to the terms and conditions specified by that minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations under subsection (3) may be different for different regional districts, different municipalities, different areas and different circumstances.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on zoning authority in relation to transit-oriented areas
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 479 but subject to an exemption set out in the regulations, a local government must not exercise the powers under that section to prohibit or restrict a density of use, or a size or dimension of buildings or other structures, set out in the regulations in relation to land that is in a transit-oriented area and zoned to permit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any residential use, or
a prescribed use other than residential use.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Residential rental tenure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A zoning bylaw may limit the form of tenure to residential rental tenure within a zone or part of a zone for a location in relation to which multi-family residential use is permitted.
A limit under subsection (1) may limit the form of tenure to residential rental tenure in relation to a specified number, portion or percentage of housing units in a building.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Strata rental bylaws and housing cooperative rules
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a local government adopts a zoning bylaw that limits the form of tenure to residential rental tenure, the zoning bylaw in relation to residential rental tenure does not affect the following:

bcl:text.#text: any lawful bylaw that a strata corporation may pass under Part 8  of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any lawful rule that a housing cooperative may adopt in relation to the rental of housing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Zoning bylaws and small-scale multi-family housing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means a zone in respect of which the only permitted residential use is for manufactured homes as defined in section 673 ;
means,

bcl:text: but does not include a manufactured home zone.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purposes of subsection (3), a zone in respect of which the permitted residential use would, but for this section, be restricted to detached single-family dwellings, and
for the purposes of subsections (4) and (5), a zone in respect of which the permitted residential use would, but for this section, be restricted to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: detached single-family dwellings,

detached single-family dwellings with one additional housing unit located within the detached single-family dwelling or on the same parcel or parcels of land on which the detached single-family dwelling is located,
duplexes, or

duplexes with one additional housing unit located within each dwelling comprising the duplex or no more than 2 additional housing units on the same parcel or parcels of land on which the duplex is located,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to an exemption under section 481.4 or set out in the regulations, a zoning bylaw adopted on or after June 30, 2024 must permit the use of land, buildings and other structures, and the density of use, required under this section to be permitted.
A local government must exercise the powers under section 479 to permit the use and density of use necessary to accommodate one or both of the following on land within a restricted zone:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least one additional housing unit within a detached dwelling that would otherwise be a single-family dwelling;
at least one additional housing unit within another building on the same parcel or parcels of land on which a detached single-family dwelling is located.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must exercise the powers under section 479 to permit the use and density of use necessary to accommodate at least the prescribed number of housing units on the following land within a restricted zone:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each parcel of land wholly or partly within an urban containment boundary established by a regional growth strategy applicable to the municipality or regional district, as the case may be;
if paragraph (a) does not apply, each parcel of land that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within a municipality the population of which is greater than the prescribed population, and
wholly or partly within an urban containment boundary established by an official community plan of the local government;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if neither paragraph (a) nor paragraph (b) applies, each parcel of land within a municipality the population of which is greater than the prescribed population.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (4), the minimum number of housing units that must be permitted by the council of a municipality on a parcel of land referred to in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of that subsection is the greater number prescribed for the purposes of this subsection if the parcel of land is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wholly or partly within a prescribed distance from a bus stop in relation to which the prescribed requirements are met, and
at least the prescribed size.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the Lieutenant Governor in Council makes regulations respecting the siting, size, dimension, location or type of housing unit required to be permitted under this section, a local government must exercise the powers under section 479 in accordance with those regulations.

bcl:text.in:desc: [provincial policy guidelines related to small-scale multi-family housing]
bcl:text.#text: In developing or adopting a zoning bylaw to permit the use and density of use required under this section to be permitted, a local government must consider applicable guidelines, if any, under section 582.1 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions related to small-scale multi-family housing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 481.3 (4) and (5) does not apply in relation to any of the following land:

bcl:text.#text: land that is protected under section 12.1 (2) of the ;
land that is, on the date this section comes into force, designated as protected under a bylaw made under section 611  of this Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land that is not connected to a water or sewer system provided as a service by a municipality or regional district;

bcl:text.#text: land within a zone in respect of which the minimum lot size that may be created by subdivision is 4 050 m;
a parcel of land that is larger than 4 050 m.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as practicable after a local government adopts a zoning bylaw in respect of which an exemption under this section or the regulations applies, the local government must give to the minister a written notice that identifies

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the land in respect of which the exemption applies, and
the provision under which the exemption is exercised.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Density benefits related to small-scale multi-family housing

bcl:text.in:desc: [density benefits for amenities, affordable housing and special needs housing]
bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a density rule established under section 482 (1)  to apply for a zone only on applicable conditions being met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 482 (1) but subject to subsection (3) of this section, a zoning bylaw must not establish conditional density rules for the purpose of achieving the minimum number of housing units required to be permitted under section 481.3 (4) or (5).

A zoning bylaw may, under section 482 (1), establish conditional density rules for only one of the minimum number of housing units required to be permitted under section 481.3 (5) but, despite section 482 (1) (b), may establish applicable conditions in relation to that single housing unit only in accordance with section 482 (2) (b) and (c).

This section does not prohibit a zoning bylaw from establishing, under section 482, conditional density rules, or applicable conditions, in relation to any number of housing units in excess of the minimum number of housing units required to be permitted under section 481.3 (4) or (5).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations related to small-scale multi-family housing
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:text.#text: for the purposes of paragraph (b) (iii) and (iv) of the definition of "restricted zone" in section 481.3 (1) , respecting what constitutes a duplex;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting exemptions from all or part of section 481.3;
for the purposes of section 481.3 (4), respecting what constitutes an urban containment boundary;
for the purposes of section 481.3 (5) (a), respecting requirements in relation to bus stops;
for the purposes of section 481.3 (6), respecting the siting, size, dimension, location or type of housing units;
respecting any other matter for which regulations are contemplated by section 481.3.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Density benefits for amenities, affordable housing and special needs housing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A zoning bylaw may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish different density rules for a zone, one generally applicable for the zone and the other or others to apply if the applicable conditions under paragraph (b) are met, and
establish conditions in accordance with subsection (2) that will entitle an owner to a higher density under paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are conditions that may be included under subsection (1) (b):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (2.1), conditions relating to the conservation or provision of amenities, including the number, kind and extent of amenities;
conditions relating to the provision of affordable and special needs housing, as such housing is defined in the bylaw, including the number, kind and extent of the housing;
a condition that the owner enter into a housing agreement under section 483 before a building permit is issued in relation to property to which the condition applies.

bcl:text.in:desc: [amenities receiving funding from amenity cost charge]
bcl:text.#text: A zoning bylaw must not establish conditions relating to the conservation or provision of an amenity that is specified in an amenity cost charge bylaw under section 570.7 (1) (b) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A zoning bylaw may designate an area within a zone for affordable or special needs housing, as such housing is defined in the bylaw, if the owners of the property covered by the designation consent to the designation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Housing agreements for affordable housing and special needs housing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, enter into a housing agreement under this section.

A housing agreement may include terms and conditions agreed to by the local government and the owner regarding the occupancy of the housing units identified in the agreement, including but not limited to terms and conditions respecting one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the form of tenure of the housing units;
the availability of the housing units to classes of persons identified in the agreement or the bylaw under subsection (1) for the agreement;
the administration and management of the housing units, including the manner in which the housing units will be made available to persons within a class referred to in paragraph (b);

rents and lease, sale or share prices that may be charged, and the rates at which these may be increased over time, as specified in the agreement or as determined in accordance with a formula specified in the agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A housing agreement may not vary the use or density from that permitted in the applicable zoning bylaw.
A housing agreement may be amended only by bylaw adopted with the consent of the owner.
If a housing agreement is entered into or amended, the local government must file in the land title office a notice that the land described in the notice is subject to the housing agreement.

Once a notice is filed under subsection (5), the housing agreement and, if applicable, the amendment to it is binding on all persons who acquire an interest in the land affected by the agreement, as amended if applicable.
On filing under subsection (5), the registrar of land titles must make a note of the filing against the title to the land affected.
In the event of any omission, mistake or misfeasance by the registrar of land titles or the staff of the registrar in relation to the making of a note of the filing under subsection (7),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: neither the registrar, nor the Provincial government nor the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia is liable vicariously,

bcl:text.#text: neither the assurance fund nor the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia, as a nominal defendant, is liable under Part 19.1 of the , and
neither the assurance fund nor the minister charged with the administration of the , as a nominal defendant, is liable under Part 20 of the .
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe fees for the filing of notices under subsection (5), and section 386 of the  applies in respect of those fees.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development approval information

bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of this Division,  means information on the anticipated impact of a proposed activity or development on the community, including, without limiting this, information regarding impact on such matters as the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: transportation patterns including traffic flow;
local infrastructure;
public facilities including schools and parks;
community services;
the natural environment of the area affected.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development approval information areas or circumstances

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan may do one or more of the following for the purposes of this Division:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify circumstances in which development approval information may be required under this Division;
designate areas for which development approval information may be required under this Division;
designate areas for which, in specified circumstances, development approval information may be required under this Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan that specifies circumstances or designates areas under subsection (1) must describe the special conditions or objectives that justify the specification or designation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaw authority in relation to development approval information

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an official community plan includes a provision under section 485 (1), the local government must, by bylaw, establish procedures and policies on the process for requiring development approval information under this Division and the substance of the information that may be required.
A bylaw under subsection (1) may authorize an officer or employee to require development approval information under this Division.

A bylaw under subsection (1) that authorizes an officer or employee to require development approval information under this Division must establish procedures regarding applying for and dealing with a reconsideration under section 487 (4).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement to provide development approval information

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), if a bylaw under section 486 is adopted, the local government or an officer or employee authorized by the bylaw may require an applicant for any of the following to provide development approval information to the local government:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an amendment to a zoning bylaw;
a development permit;
a temporary use permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Development approval information required under subsection (1) must be provided at the applicant's expense and in accordance with the procedures and policies established under section 486 (1).

bcl:text.#text: Development approval information is not required under this Division if the proposed activity or development is a reviewable project as defined in section 1 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant subject to a decision of an officer or employee under section 486 (2) is entitled to have the local government reconsider the matter without charge.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Designation of development permit areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An official community plan may designate development permit areas for one or more of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: protection of the natural environment, its ecosystems and biological diversity;
protection of development from hazardous conditions;
protection of farming;
revitalization of an area in which a commercial use is permitted;
establishment of objectives for the form and character of intensive residential development;
establishment of objectives for the form and character of commercial, industrial or multi-family residential development;
in relation to an area in a resort region, establishment of objectives for the form and character of development in the resort region;
establishment of objectives to promote energy conservation;
establishment of objectives to promote water conservation;
establishment of objectives to promote the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: With respect to areas designated under subsection (1), the official community plan must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe the special conditions or objectives that justify the designation, and
specify guidelines respecting the manner by which the special conditions or objectives will be addressed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to subsection (2) (b), the guidelines referred to in that subsection may be specified by zoning bylaw but, in this case, the designation is not effective until the zoning bylaw has been adopted.

If an official community plan designates areas under subsection (1), the plan or a zoning bylaw may, with respect to those areas, specify conditions under which a development permit under section 489 would not be required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Activities that require a development permit
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an official community plan designates areas under section 488 (1), the following prohibitions apply unless an exemption under section 488 (4) applies or the owner first obtains a development permit under this Division:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land within the area must not be subdivided;
construction of, addition to or alteration of a building or other structure must not be started;

bcl:text.#text: land within an area designated under section 488 (1) (a) or (b)  must not be altered;

bcl:text.in:desc: [revitalization, energy conservation, water conservation, greenhouse gas reduction]
bcl:text.#text: land within an area designated under section 488 (1) (d), (h), (i) or (j) , or a building or other structure on that land, must not be altered.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development permits: general authority

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a local government may, by resolution, issue a development permit that does one or more of the following:

bcl:text.in:desc: [Subdivision and Development: Requirements and Related Matters]
bcl:text.#text: varies or supplements a land use regulation bylaw or a bylaw under Division 11 ;
includes requirements and conditions or sets standards under section 491 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: imposes conditions respecting the sequence and timing of construction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority under subsection (1) must be exercised only in accordance with the applicable guidelines specified under section 488 in an official community plan or zoning bylaw.
A development permit must not

bcl:text.in:desc: [variation in relation to health, safety or protection of property]
bcl:text.#text: vary the use or density of the land from that permitted in the bylaw except as authorized by section 491 (3) , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vary the application of a zoning bylaw in relation to residential rental tenure.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A development permit must not vary a flood plain specification under section 524 (3).

If a local government delegates the power to issue a development permit under this section, the owner of land that is subject to the decision of the delegate is entitled to have the local government reconsider the matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development permits: specific authorities

bcl:text.#text: For land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (a) , a development permit may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify areas of land that must remain free of development, except in accordance with any conditions contained in the permit;
require specified natural features or areas to be preserved, protected, restored or enhanced in accordance with the permit;
require natural water courses to be dedicated;
require works to be constructed to preserve, protect, restore or enhance natural water courses or other specified natural features of the environment;
require protection measures, including that vegetation or trees be planted or retained in order to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: preserve, protect, restore or enhance fish habitat or riparian areas,
control drainage, or
control erosion or protect banks.

bcl:text.#text: For land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (b) , a development permit may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify areas of land that may be subject to flooding, mud flows, torrents of debris, erosion, land slip, rock falls, subsidence, tsunami, avalanche or wildfire, or to another hazard if this other hazard is specified under section 488 (1) (b), as areas that must remain free of development, except in accordance with any conditions contained in the permit;

require, in an area that the permit designates as containing unstable soil or water which is subject to degradation, that no septic tank, drainage and deposit fields or irrigation or water systems be constructed;

in relation to wildfire hazard, include requirements respecting the character of the development, including landscaping, and the siting, form, exterior design and finish of buildings and other structures;
in relation to wildfire hazard, establish restrictions on the type and placement of trees and other vegetation in proximity to the development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Conditions and requirements under subsection (2) may vary the use or density of land, but only as they relate to health, safety or protection of property from damage.

Before issuing a development permit for land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (b), a local government may require the applicant to provide a report to assist the local government in determining what conditions or requirements it will impose under subsection (2) of this section.
A report required under subsection (4) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be provided by the applicant at the applicant's expense, and
be certified by a professional engineer with experience relevant to the applicable matter.

bcl:text.#text: For land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (c) , a development permit may include requirements for screening, landscaping, fencing and siting of buildings or other structures, in order to provide for the buffering or separation of development from farming on adjoining or reasonably adjacent land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For land within a development permit area designated under any of the following, a development permit may include requirements respecting the character of the development, including landscaping, and the siting, form, exterior design and finish of buildings and other structures:

bcl:text.#text: section 488 (1) (d) ;
section 488 (1) (e) ;
section 488 (1) (f) ;
section 488 (1) (g) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (f), a development permit may include requirements respecting the character of the development, as referred to in subsection (7) of this section, but only in relation to the general character of the development and not to particulars of the landscaping or of the exterior design and finish of buildings and other structures.

bcl:text.in:desc: [energy conservation, water conservation, greenhouse gas reduction]
bcl:text.#text: For land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (h), (i) or (j) , a development permit may include requirements respecting the following in order to provide for energy and water conservation and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: landscaping;
siting of buildings and other structures;
form and exterior design of buildings and other structures;
specific features in the development;
machinery, equipment and systems external to buildings and other structures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For land within a development permit area designated under section 488 (1) (h), (i) or (j), a development permit may establish restrictions on the type and placement of trees and other vegetation in proximity to the buildings and other structures in order to provide for energy and water conservation and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Designation of temporary use permit areas
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 493, an official community plan or a zoning bylaw may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designate areas where temporary uses may be allowed, and
specify general conditions regarding the issue of temporary use permits in those areas.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Temporary use permits for designated areas and other areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by an owner of land, a local government may issue a temporary use permit as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by resolution, in relation to land within an area designated under section 492;
by bylaw, in relation to land within an area outside a municipality, if there is no official community plan in effect for the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A temporary use permit may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allow a use not permitted by a zoning bylaw;
specify conditions under which the temporary use may be carried on;
allow and regulate the construction of buildings or structures in respect of the use for which the permit is issued.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government delegates the power to issue a temporary use permit under this section, the owner of land that is subject to the decision of the delegate is entitled to have the local government reconsider the matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Public notice and hearing requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government proposes to pass a resolution under section 493 (1) (a), it must give notice in accordance with subsections (2) to (4) of this section.
The notice must state

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in general terms, the purpose of the proposed permit,
the land or lands that are the subject of the proposed permit,
the place where and the times and dates when copies of the proposed permit may be inspected,
the time and date when and, if applicable, the place where the resolution will be considered, and
if the meeting at which the resolution will be considered is conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities, the way in which the meeting is to be conducted by those means.

bcl:text.#text: The notice must be published in accordance with section 94  of the  at least 3 days and not more than 14 days before the adoption of the resolution to issue the permit.

bcl:text.in:desc: [bylaw to provide for alternative means of publication]
bcl:text.#text: If the local government has adopted a bylaw under section 94.2  of the , the notice must be published by at least one of the means of publication specified in the bylaw not less than 3 days and not more than 14 days before the adoption of the resolution to issue the permit.

If the local government has not adopted a bylaw under section 94.2 of the , the last publication of the notice must be not less than 3 days and not more than 14 days before the adoption of the resolution to issue the permit.

bcl:text.in:desc: [specific requirements in relation to notice of public hearing]
bcl:text.#text: Section 466 (4) to (8)  applies to the notice as if the resolution were a bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government proposes to adopt a bylaw under section 493 (1) (b), the following sections apply:

bcl:text.#text: section 464 ;
section 465 ;
section 466 ;
section 469 ;
section 470 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permit conditions: undertakings respecting land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a condition of issuing a temporary use permit, a local government may require the owner of the land to give an undertaking to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: demolish or remove a building or other structure, and
restore land described in the permit to a condition specified in the permit by a date specified in the permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An undertaking under subsection (1) must be attached to and forms part of the permit.

If the owner of the land fails to comply with all of the undertakings given under subsection (1), the local government may enter on the land and carry out the demolition, removal or restoration at the expense of the owner.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permit conditions: additional security requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to any security required under section 502, a local government may require, as a condition of issuing a temporary use permit, that the owner of the land give to the local government security to guarantee the performance of the terms of the permit.
If there is a requirement for security under subsection (1), the permit may provide for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the form of the security, and
the means for determining

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: when there is default under the permit, and
the amount of the security that forfeits to the local government in the event of default.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Term of permit and renewal of permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of land in respect of which a temporary use permit has been issued has the right to put the land to the use described in the permit until the earlier of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date that the permit expires;
3 years after the permit was issued.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person to whom a temporary use permit has been issued may apply to have the permit renewed, subject to the restriction that a temporary use permit may be renewed only once.

bcl:text.#text: Subsection (1) and sections 495  and 496  apply in relation to a renewal under subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development variance permits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by an owner of land, a local government may, by resolution, issue a development variance permit that varies, in respect of the land covered in the permit, the provisions of a bylaw under any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following Divisions of this Part:

bcl:text.#text: Division 5 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Subdivision and Development: Requirements and Related Matters]
bcl:text.#text: Division 11 ;
Division 13 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Regulation of Farm Businesses in Farming Areas]
bcl:text.#text: Division 17 ;
section 298 (1) (j) ;

in:desc: [fundamental powers — protection of persons and property]
bcl:text.#text: section 8 (3) (g)  of the  in relation to matters referred to in section 63 (e)  of that Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As restrictions on subsection (1), a development variance permit must not vary the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the use or density of land from that specified in the bylaw;
the application of a zoning bylaw in relation to residential rental tenure;

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirements in relation to flood plain areas]
bcl:text.#text: a flood plain specification under section 524 (3) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of conflict, the provisions of a development variance permit prevail over any provision of the bylaw.

bcl:text.#text: As a restriction on section 229  of this Act and section 154  of the , a local government may not delegate the power to issue a development variance permit except in accordance with section 498.1.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Delegation of power to issue development variance permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, delegate to an officer or employee of the local government the power under section 498 to issue a development variance permit if the proposed variance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a minor variance, and
varies the provisions of a bylaw under any of the following:

bcl:text.in:desc: [zoning bylaws respecting siting, size and dimensions of buildings, structures and permitted uses]
bcl:text.#text: section 479 (1) (c) (iii) ;
section 525 ;
section 526 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [screening and landscaping to mask or separate uses or to preserve, protect, restore and enhance natural environment]
bcl:text.#text: section 527 (1) (a) or (b) ;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a provision of this Act prescribed by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw delegating the power to issue a development variance permit under this section must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: criteria for determining whether a proposed variance is minor for the purposes of subsection (1) (a), and
guidelines the delegate must consider in deciding whether to issue a development variance permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The bylaw may also include any terms and conditions the local government considers appropriate.

If a local government delegates the power to issue a development variance permit, an owner of land that is subject to a decision of the delegate is entitled to have the local government reconsider the matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice to affected property owners and tenants

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government proposes to pass a resolution to issue a development variance permit, it must give notice in accordance with this section.
For certainty, the obligation to give notice under this section does not apply if a delegate, under section 498.1, exercises the power to issue the development variance permit.
The notice must state the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in general terms, the purpose of the proposed permit;
the land or lands that are the subject of the proposed permit;
the place where and the times and dates when copies of the proposed permit may be inspected.

bcl:text: The notice must be mailed or otherwise delivered at least 10 days before adoption of the resolution to issue the permit
of each parcel, any part of which is the subject of the permit or is within a distance specified by bylaw from that part of the land that is subject to the permit.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to the owners, as shown on the assessment roll as at the date of application for the permit, and
to any tenants in occupation, as at the date of the mailing or delivery of the notice,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The obligation to give notice under this section is satisfied if the local government made a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tree cutting permits in relation to areas affected by flooding or other hazards

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board may, by bylaw, designate areas of land that it considers may be subject to flooding, erosion, land slip or avalanche as tree cutting permit areas.
A bylaw may, in respect of an area designated under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulate or prohibit the cutting down of trees, and
require an owner to obtain, on payment of a fee set by the bylaw, a permit before cutting down a tree.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The bylaw may allow the board, at its discretion, to require an applicant to provide a report in accordance with subsection (4) that the proposed cutting of trees will not create a danger from flooding or erosion.
A report required under subsection (3) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provided at the applicant's expense, and
certified by a qualified person agreed on by the applicant and the board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General land use permit matters

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may issue more than one land use permit for an area of land.
Land must be developed strictly in accordance with the land use permit or permits issued.
A land use permit is binding on the local government as well as on the holder of the permit.
A local government may, by bylaw, designate the form of land use permits.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement for security as condition of land use permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes only of subsections (2) and (3), a local government may, as a condition of the issue of a land use permit, require that the applicant for the permit provide security in an amount stated in the permit by whichever of the following the applicant chooses:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an irrevocable letter of credit;
the deposit of securities in a form satisfactory to the local government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) applies if a local government considers that any of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a condition in a permit respecting landscaping has not been satisfied;
an unsafe condition has resulted as a consequence of a contravention of a condition in a permit;
damage to the natural environment has resulted as a consequence of a contravention of a condition in a permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstance referred to in subsection (2), the local government may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: undertake, at the expense of the holder of the permit, the works, construction or other activities required to satisfy the landscaping condition, correct the unsafe condition or correct the damage to the environment, and
apply the security under subsection (1) in payment of the cost of the works, construction or other activities, with any excess to be returned to the holder of the permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Interest earned on the security provided under subsection (1) accrues to the holder of the permit and must be paid to the holder immediately on return of the security or, on default, becomes part of the amount of the security.
If a local government delegates the power to require security under subsection (1), the delegation bylaw must include guidelines for the delegate as to how the amount of security is to be determined.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of permit on land title

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government issues any of the following, it must file in the land title office a notice that the land described in the notice is subject to the permit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a development permit;
a temporary use permit;
a development variance permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On filing of a notice under subsection (1), the registrar of land titles must make a note of the filing against the title to the land affected.
