If a permit referred to in subsection (1) is amended or cancelled, the local government must file a notice of the amendment or cancellation in the manner prescribed by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, and, on filing, the registrar of land titles must make a note of the filing against the title to the land affected.
If a notice is filed under subsection (1) or (3), the terms of the permit or any amendment to it are binding on all persons who acquire an interest in the land affected by the permit.

In the event of any omission, mistake or misfeasance by the registrar of land titles or the employees of the registrar in relation to the making of a note of the filing under subsection (1) or (3) after the notice is received by the land title office,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: neither the registrar, nor the Provincial government nor the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia is liable vicariously,

bcl:text.#text: the assurance fund or the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 19.1 of the , and
the assurance fund or the minister charged with the administration of the  as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 20 of the .
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing fees for the filing of notices under this section, and section 386 of the  applies in respect of those fees.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Permit lapses if relevant construction not substantially started

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the terms of the permit, if the holder of a land use permit does not substantially start any construction with respect to which the permit was issued within 2 years after the date it is issued, the permit lapses.

bcl:text: Subject to

bcl:text.in:desc: [requirement for security as condition of land use permit]
bcl:text.#text: if a land use permit lapses, the local government must return any security provided under section 502 (1)  to the person who provided it.

bcl:text.in:desc: [additional security requirements in relation to temporary use permits]
bcl:text.#text: section 496 , and

bcl:text.in:desc: [local government action to satisfy permit condition]
bcl:text.#text: section 502 (3) ,

bcl:marginalnote.#text: : permits in relation to development near controlled access highway

bcl:text.in:desc: [zoning bylaw does not apply to controlled access area unless transportation minister approves]
bcl:text.#text: If a zoning bylaw is subject to section 52 (3)  of the , this section applies in relation to land use permits in respect of property within the area covered by the bylaw.

Unless exempted under subsection (4), a land use permit for the construction of commercial or industrial buildings exceeding 4 500 square metres in gross floor areas must not be issued unless a site plan of the buildings, including traffic circulation and parking areas and facilities, has been approved by the minister responsible for the administration of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In considering whether to approve a site plan under subsection (2), the minister referred to in that subsection must consider only the effect of the proposed development on the controlled access highway.
The minister referred to in subsection (2) may make regulations

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment or discharge of land use contracts]
bcl:text.#text: defining areas for which and describing circumstances in which approval under that subsection or under section 546 (4)  is not required, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: providing that an exception under paragraph (a) is subject to the terms and conditions specified by that minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations under subsection (4) may be different for different regional districts, different municipalities, different areas and different circumstances.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Subdivision and Development: Requirements and Related Matters

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Subdivision servicing requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, regulate and require the provision of works and services in respect of the subdivision of land, and for that purpose may, by bylaw, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulate and prescribe minimum standards for the dimensions, locations, alignment and gradient of highways in connection with subdivisions of land;

require that, within a subdivision, highways, sidewalks, boulevards, boulevard crossings, transit bays, street lighting or underground wiring be provided, located and constructed in accordance with the standards established by the bylaw;

require that, within a subdivision, a water distribution system, a fire hydrant system, a sewage collection system, a sewage disposal system, a drainage collection system or a drainage disposal system be provided, located and constructed in accordance with the standards established in the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may be different in relation to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different circumstances;
different areas;
different land uses;
different zones;
different classes of highways.

bcl:text.#text: A local government must not impose a requirement under subsection (1) (b) or (c) in respect of a subdivision under the .

The minister responsible for the administration of the  may make regulations requiring approval of that minister before the adoption of a bylaw under subsection (1) (a) or (b) that establishes standards or requirements in relation to highways in an area outside a municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A regulation under subsection (4) may be different in relation to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different bylaws;
different classes of bylaws;
different regional districts;
different areas;
different circumstances.

bcl:text: If a local government, an improvement district or greater board operates

the local government may, by bylaw, require that a system referred to in subsection (1) (c) be connected to the local government, improvement district or greater board system, in accordance with standards established in the bylaw.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a community water or sewer system, or
a drainage collection or disposal system,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is no community water system, the local government may, by bylaw, require that each parcel to be created by the subdivision have a source of potable water having a flow capacity at a rate established in the bylaw.

bcl:text: As a condition of

a local government may require that the owner of the land provide works and services, in accordance with the standards established in a bylaw under this section, on that portion of a highway immediately adjacent to the site being subdivided or developed, up to the centre line of the highway.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approval of a subdivision, or
the issue of a building permit,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a condition of the issue of a building permit, a local government may require that the owner of the land provide, on the site being developed, works and services in accordance with the standards established in a bylaw under this section.
Requirements under subsections (8) and (9)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be made only to the extent that they are directly attributable to the subdivision or development, and
must not include specific services that are included in the calculations used to determine the amount of a development cost charge, unless the owner agrees to provide the services.

bcl:text.#text: If the owner agrees to provide the services referred to in subsection (10) (b), the calculation of the development cost charge is subject to section 565 (2) to (5) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements for excess or extended services

bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of this section and section 508,  means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a portion of a highway system that will provide access to land other than the land being subdivided or developed, and
a portion of a water, sewage or drainage system that will serve land other than the land being subdivided or developed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may require that the owner of land that is to be subdivided or developed provide excess or extended services.
If a local government makes a requirement under subsection (2), the cost of providing the excess or extended services must be paid for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the municipality or regional district, or
if the local government considers its costs to provide all or part of these services to be excessive, by the owner of the land being subdivided or developed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Latecomer charges and cost recovery for excess or extended services

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the owner is required under section 507 (3) (b) to pay all or part of the costs of excess or extended services, the municipality or regional district must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determine the proportion of the cost of providing the highway or water, sewage or drainage facilities that it considers constitutes the excess or extended services,
determine which part of the excess or extended services that it considers will benefit each of the parcels of land that will be served by the excess or extended services, and
impose, as a condition of an owner connecting to or using the excess or extended services, a charge related to the benefit determined under paragraph (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the owner pays all or part of the costs of excess or extended services, the municipality or regional district must pay the owner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the latecomer charges collected under subsection (1) (c), if the owner pays all the costs, or
a corresponding proportion of all latecomer charges collected, if the owner pays a portion of the costs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the municipality or regional district pays all or part of the costs of excess or extended services, it may recover costs

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by a latecomer charge under subsection (1) (c),

bcl:text.#text: by a tax imposed in accordance with Division 5  of Part 7 of the , other than section 211 (1) of that Act, or
by fee imposed in accordance with section 397  of this Act or section 194  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A latecomer charge must include interest calculated annually at a rate established by bylaw, payable for the period beginning when the excess or extended services were completed, up to the date that the connection is made or the use begins.
Subject to subsection (6), latecomer charges must be collected during the period beginning when the excess or extended services are completed, up to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a date to be agreed on by the owner and the local government, or

bcl:text.#text: if there is no agreement, a date determined under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No latecomer charges are payable as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if there is a phased development agreement that is directly related to the construction and installation of the excess or extended services, beyond 15 years from the date the services are completed or the end of the phased development agreement, whichever is later;
in any other case, beyond 15 years from the date the services are completed.

bcl:text.#text: If an owner, in accordance with a bylaw under section 506 , provides a highway or water, sewage or drainage facilities that serve land other than the land being subdivided or developed, this section applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Completion of required works and services

bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsection (2), all works and services required to be constructed and installed at the expense of the owner of the land being subdivided or developed must be constructed and installed to the standards established in the bylaw under section 506  before the approving officer approves of the subdivision or the building inspector issues the building permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Approval may be given or the permit issued if the owner of the land

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deposits, with the municipality or regional district, security

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the form and amount established in the bylaw under section 506, or

if no amount and form is established in the bylaw, in a form and amount satisfactory to the approving officer or building inspector having regard to the cost of installing and paying for all works and services required under the bylaw, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enters into an agreement with the municipality or regional district to construct and install the required works and services by a specified date or forfeit to the municipality or regional district the amount secured under paragraph (a).

bcl:text.#text: As a restriction, security may not be provided under subsection (2) to a regional district in relation to the construction of a highway unless a designated highways official, as defined in the , approves the provision of security for that purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement for provision of park land or payment for parks purposes

bcl:text.#text: Subject to this section and section 516 (3) (h) and (4) , an owner of land being subdivided must, at the owner's option,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide, without compensation, park land of an amount and in a location acceptable to the local government, or

pay to the municipality or regional district an amount that equals the market value of the land that may be required for park land purposes under this section as determined under subsection (6) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a regional district does not provide a community parks service, the option under subsection (1) (b) does not apply and the owner must provide land in accordance with subsection (1) (a), and

subject to paragraph (a), if an official community plan contains policies and designations respecting the location and type of future parks, the local government may determine whether the owner must provide land under subsection (1) (a) or money under subsection (1) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (4), a subdivision by which fewer than 3 additional lots would be created;
a subdivision by which the smallest lot being created is larger than 2 hectares;
a consolidation of existing parcels.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does apply to a subdivision by which fewer than 3 additional lots would be created if the parcel proposed to be subdivided was itself created by subdivision within the past 5 years.

The amount of land that may be required under subsection (1) (a) or used for establishing the amount that may be paid under subsection (1) (b) must not exceed 5% of the land being proposed for subdivision.
If an owner is to pay money under subsection (1) (b), the value of the land is whichever of the following is applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the local government and the owner agree on a value for the land, the value on which they have agreed;
the average market value of all the land in the proposed subdivision calculated

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as that value would be on the date of preliminary approval of the subdivision or, if no preliminary approval is given, a date within 90 days before the final approval of the subdivision,
as though the land is zoned to permit the proposed use, and
as though any works and services necessary to the subdivision have not been installed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an owner and a local government do not agree on the average market value for the purpose of subsection (6), it must be determined in the manner prescribed in the regulations that the minister may make for this purpose.

If an area of land has been used to calculate the amount of land or money provided or paid under this section, that area must not be taken into account for a subsequent entitlement under subsection (1) in respect of any future subdivision of the land.
Subject to subsection (11), the land or payment required under subsection (1) must be provided or paid to a municipality or regional district as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to paragraph (b), before final approval of the subdivision is given;

if the owner and the local government enter into an agreement that the land or payment be provided or paid by a date specified in the agreement, after final approval of the subdivision has been given.

bcl:text.#text: Notice of an agreement under subsection (9) (b) must be filed with the registrar of land titles in the same manner as a notice of a permit may be filed and section 503  applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (9), the minister may, by regulation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorize the payment that may be required by this section to be made by instalments, and
prescribe the conditions under which instalments may be paid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If land is provided for park land under this section, the land must be shown as park on the plan of subdivision.

bcl:text.in:desc: [deposit in land title office operates to dedicate and vest park land]
bcl:text.#text: Section 107  of the  applies to park land referred to in subsection (12), except that,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of land within a municipality, title vests in the municipality, and
in the case of land outside a municipality, title vests in the regional district if it provides a community parks service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an owner pays money for park land under this section, the municipality or regional district must deposit this in a reserve fund established for the purpose of acquiring park lands.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bylaws adopted after application for subdivision submitted

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies in relation to a bylaw under this Part that is adopted after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for a subdivision of land located outside a municipality has been submitted to a district highway manager in a form satisfactory to that official, or
an application for a subdivision of land within a municipality has been submitted to a designated municipal officer and the applicable subdivision fee has been paid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the bylaw would otherwise be applicable to the subdivision, the bylaw has no effect with respect to that subdivision for a period of 12 months after the bylaw is adopted.
Subsection (2) does not apply if the applicant agrees in writing that the bylaw should have effect with respect to the subdivision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Minimum parcel frontage on highway

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a parcel being created by a subdivision fronts on a highway, the minimum frontage on the highway must be the greater of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 10% of the perimeter of the lot that fronts on the highway, and
the minimum frontage that the local government may, by bylaw, provide.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may exempt a parcel from the statutory or bylaw minimum frontage provided for in subsection (1).

bcl:text.#text: As a limitation on section 229  of this Act or section 154  of the , a local government may delegate its powers under subsection (2) only to an approving officer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement to provide land for new highway or widening existing highway

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An approving officer may require that the owner of the land being subdivided provide, without compensation, a portion of that land for highway use as referred to in subsection (2).
Subject to subsection (3), the land required under this section must not be greater than the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a highway within the subdivision, 20 metres in depth;
for widening an existing local highway that borders or is within the subdivision, the lesser of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 10 metres in depth, and
the difference between the current width of a local highway and 20 metres.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the approving officer considers that, due to terrain and soil conditions, a roadway of a width of 8 metres cannot, within the 20-metre limit referred to in subsection (2), be adequately supported, protected or drained, the approving officer may determine that the owner provide, without compensation, land of a greater width than that referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (b) that, in the approving officer's opinion, would permit the local highway to be supported, protected or drained.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Subdivision to provide residence for a relative

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the requirements of this section are met, an approving officer may approve the subdivision of a parcel of land that would otherwise be prevented from subdivision by a provision of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bylaw under this Act, other than a bylaw under subsection (4), that establishes a minimum parcel size, or

bcl:text.#text: a regulation under the  that establishes a minimum parcel size.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for subdivision of a parcel under this section may be made only if all the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person making the application has owned the parcel for at least 5 years before making the application;
the application is made for the purpose of providing a separate residence for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the owner,
a parent of the owner or of the owner's spouse,
the owner's child or the spouse of the owner's child, or
the owner's grandchild;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proposed subdivision is not a subdivision that an approving officer is prevented from approving by subsection (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), an approving officer must not approve a subdivision under this section in any of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the parcel proposed to be subdivided is classified as farm land for assessment and taxation purposes, and
after creation of the parcel subdivided for the purpose of providing a residence as stated in subsection (2) (b), the remainder of the parcel proposed to be subdivided would be less than 2 hectares;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the parcel proposed to be subdivided

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is land that is not agricultural land, and

bcl:text.#text: was created by subdivision under this section, including subdivision under section 996 of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 290, as it read before it was repealed and replaced by section 13 of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the parcel proposed to be subdivided

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is agricultural land, and

bcl:text.#text: was within the previous 5 years created by subdivision under this section, including subdivision under section 996 of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 290, as it read before it was repealed and replaced by section 13 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (5) and (6), a local government may, by bylaw, establish the minimum size for a parcel that may be subdivided under this section, and different sizes may be specified for different areas specified in the bylaw.

bcl:text.#text: A bylaw under subsection (4) does not apply to agricultural land, with the exception of agricultural land to which section 23 (1) or (2)  of the  applies.
Any parcel created by subdivision under this section must be at least 1 hectare unless a smaller area, in no case less than 2 500 m, is approved by the medical health officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For 5 years after subdivision under this section, unless the applicable use is changed by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the use of the parcel subdivided for the purpose of providing a residence as stated in subsection (2) (b) must be residential use only, and
the use of the remainder of the original parcel must not be changed from the use of the original parcel.

bcl:text.#text: For a parcel of land that is not agricultural land, or that is agricultural land to which section 23 (1) or (2) of the  applies, approval of subdivision under this section may be given only on the condition that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner of the original parcel covenants with the local government, in respect of each of the parcels being created by the subdivision, that the parcel

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: will be used as required by subsection (7) of this section, and
will not be subdivided under this section, and

bcl:text.#text: the covenants referred to in paragraph (a) be registered under section 219 of the  at the same time that application is made to deposit the subdivision plan.

If a subdivision referred to in subsection (8) is approved, the approving officer must state on the note of approval required by section 88 of the  that the approval is subject to conditions established by subsection (8).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Division
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: means an owner of land who enters into, or who by assignment becomes a party to, a phased development agreement;
means a development on land owned by a developer and described in a phased development agreement;
means a provision of a subdivision servicing bylaw that is specified under section 516 (2) for a phased development agreement;
means a provision of a zoning bylaw that is specified under section 516 (2) for a phased development agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Phased development agreements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, enter into a phased development agreement with an owner of land.

A phased development agreement must identify the land that is being developed and specify the provisions of a zoning bylaw and a subdivision servicing bylaw to which subsection (5) applies while the agreement is in effect.

A phased development agreement may include additional terms and conditions agreed to by the local government and the developer, including but not limited to terms and conditions respecting one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the inclusion of specific features in the development;
the provision of amenities;
the phasing and timing of the development and of other matters covered by the agreement;

bcl:text.#text: the registration of covenants under section 219 of the ;
subject to section 519 (3) , minor amendments to the agreement, including a definition of "minor amendment" for the purpose of the agreement;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dispute resolution between the parties;
early termination of the agreement, either automatically in the event that terms and conditions are not met or by mutual agreement;

bcl:text.#text: the amount and location of park land to be provided under section 510  in respect of land being subdivided that is subject to the phased development agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a phased development agreement includes additional terms and conditions under subsection (3) (h), the amount of park land to be provided

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may exceed 5% of the land being proposed for subdivision in respect of an individual subdivision application within the land to which the phased development agreement applies, and
must not exceed 5% of the land being proposed for subdivision in respect of all of the land to which the phased development agreement applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), if the specified zoning bylaw provisions or the specified subdivision servicing bylaw provisions are amended or repealed while the agreement is in effect, those changes do not apply to the development unless the developer agrees in writing that the changes apply.
The following changes to the specified zoning bylaw provisions or the specified subdivision servicing bylaw provisions apply to the development without the written agreement of the developer:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: changes to enable the local government to comply with an enactment of British Columbia or of Canada;
changes to comply with the order of a court or arbitrator or another direction in respect of which the local government has a legal requirement to obey;

changes that, in the opinion of the local government, are necessary to address a hazardous condition of which the local government was unaware at the time it entered into the phased development agreement.

bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsection (8), if a specified zoning bylaw provision is a provision under section 479 (1) (c) (iii) , a development permit that

bcl:text: does not apply to the development unless the developer agrees in writing that the development permit will apply.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: varies the siting, size or dimensions of buildings and other structures, or
varies the siting, size or dimensions of uses that are permitted on the land

bcl:text.#text: Subsection (7) does not apply to a development permit for land designated under section 488 (1) (a) to (c) and (h) to (j) , if the development permit is approved by the inspector.

For certainty, if a matter included in a phased development agreement is specifically authorized under another section of this Part or Part 15 , the requirements that would apply in relation to that matter under those sections continue to apply.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Term and assignment of phased development agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the maximum term for a phased development agreement is 10 years.
With the approval of the inspector, a local government may enter into a phased development agreement for a term not exceeding 20 years.

Subject to subsection (2), a phased development agreement may be renewed or extended, as long as the renewal or extension will not make the agreement effective for a period that could exceed 20 years.
A phased development agreement may not require the local government to renew or extend a phased development agreement or enter into a subsequent phased development agreement for the same development.
The developer may assign a phased development agreement to a subsequent owner of the land identified in the agreement only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subsequent owner is identified in the agreement,
the subsequent owner is a member of a class of persons identified in the agreement, or
the local government agrees to the assignment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Process for phased development agreement bylaw

in:desc: [Public Hearings on Planning and Land Use Bylaws]
bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4), the local government must hold a public hearing in accordance with Division 3  before adopting a bylaw under section 516 .
In addition to the notice requirements of section 466 (2) , the notice of the public hearing must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the developer;
a general description of the specified zoning bylaw provisions for the phased development agreement;
the term of the phased development agreement;
a general description of the nature of the development that will be the subject of the phased development agreement;

if the phased development agreement provides for the assignment of the agreement to a subsequent owner of the land that is identified in the agreement, the conditions under which the assignment may occur;
any other information required by regulation.

bcl:text.in:desc: [public hearing not required if bylaw consistent with official community plan]
bcl:text.#text: Section 464 (2)  does not apply to a public hearing under subsection (1) of this section.

bcl:text.in:desc: [at least one day between third reading and adoption]
bcl:text.#text: Despite section 135 (3)  of the , a local government may adopt a phased development agreement bylaw at the same meeting at which the bylaw passed third reading.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendments to phased development agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) to (4), if the local government and the developer agree, a phased development agreement may be amended in accordance with this section.
If the phased development agreement provides for minor amendments, the local government may agree to a minor amendment by resolution.
The following matters may not be dealt with as minor amendments to the phased development agreement:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the specified zoning bylaw provisions;
the specified subdivision servicing bylaw provisions;
provisions regarding the assignment of the agreement to a subsequent owner;
the term of the agreement, unless the amendment will reduce the length of the term;
renewal or extension of the agreement;
the land that is the subject of the agreement;
the definition of "minor amendment" for the purpose of the agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amendment to a phased development agreement, other than a minor amendment, must be adopted by bylaw, and sections 515 to 518 apply to the bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Subdivision approval for land subject to phased development agreement

bcl:text.in:desc: [time limit for approval and consideration of public interest]
bcl:text.#text: This section applies in relation to an application for subdivision approval under section 85  of the  in respect of land that is subject to a phased development agreement.
In determining if the deposit of the subdivision plan is against the public interest under section 85 (3) of the , an approving officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must take account of the phased development agreement, and
must not consider any of the following:

bcl:text.#text: amendments to or repeals of specified zoning bylaw provisions and specified subdivision servicing bylaw provisions that have not been agreed to by the developer under section 516 (5) ;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a resolution passed by a local government that has entered into the phased development agreement about substantially the same subject matter as a specified zoning bylaw provision or a specified subdivision servicing bylaw provision in that agreement that may affect the intent of the specified zoning bylaw provision or specified subdivision servicing bylaw provision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of phased development agreement on land title

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a phased development agreement is entered into under section 516, a notice that the land described in the notice is subject to the phased development agreement must be filed with the registrar of land titles in the same manner as a notice of a permit may be filed.

bcl:text.#text: Section 503  applies to a notice under subsection (1) of this section but there is no requirement to file a notice of a minor amendment described in section 519 (2) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Phased development agreement and other information that must be available for public inspection
bcl:section.bcl:text: In relation to a phased development agreement, the following must be available for public inspection at the local government offices during regular office hours:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the phased development agreement;
any amendments to the phased development agreement;
any agreements, permits, plans or other documents that are incorporated into the phased development agreement, whether directly or by reference.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Runoff control requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, require that an owner of land who carries out construction of a paved area or roof area manage and provide for the ongoing disposal of surface runoff and storm water in accordance with the requirements of the bylaw.
A local government may, by bylaw, establish the maximum percentage of the area of land that can be covered by impermeable material.
A bylaw under subsection (1) or (2) may make different provisions for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different zones;
different uses in zones;
different areas in zones;
different sizes of paved or roof areas;
different terrain and surface water or groundwater conditions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements in relation to flood plain areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means the minister charged with the administration of the ;

means the policies, strategies, objectives, standards, guidelines and environmental management plans, in relation to flood control, flood hazard management and development of land that is subject to flooding, prepared and published by the environment minister under section 5 of the ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [general authority to make regulations — flood hazard management]
bcl:text.#text: means, in relation to a local government, any applicable regulations enacted under section 138 (3) (e)  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government considers that flooding may occur on land, the local government may, by bylaw, designate the land as a flood plain.
If land is designated as a flood plain under subsection (2), the local government may, by bylaw, specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the flood level for the flood plain, and
the setback from a watercourse, body of water or dike of any landfill or structural support required to elevate a floor system or pad above the flood level.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making bylaws under this section, a local government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider the Provincial guidelines, and
comply with the Provincial regulations and a plan or program the local government has developed under those regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (3) may make different provisions for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different areas of a flood plain;
different zones;
different uses within a zone or an area of a flood plain;
different types of geological or hydrological features;
different standards of works and services;
different siting circumstances;
different types of buildings or other structures and different types of machinery, equipment or goods within them;
different uses within a building or other structure.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a bylaw under subsection (3) applies,

bcl:text: the underside of any floor system, or the top of any pad supporting any space or room, including a manufactured home, that is used for
must be above the applicable flood level specified by the bylaw, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: dwelling purposes,
business, or
the storage of goods that are susceptible to damage by floodwater

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any landfill required to support a floor system or pad must not extend within any applicable setback specified by the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the Provincial regulations and a plan or program a local government has developed under those regulations, the local government may exempt a person from the application of subsection (6), or a bylaw under subsection (3), in relation to a specific parcel of land or a use, building or other structure on the parcel of land, if the local government considers it advisable and either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: considers that the exemption is consistent with the Provincial guidelines, or
has received a report that the land may be used safely for the use intended, which report is certified by a person who is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a professional engineer or geoscientist and experienced in geotechnical engineering, or
a person in a class prescribed by the environment minister under subsection (9).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The granting of an exemption, and the exemption, under subsection (7) may be made subject to the terms and conditions the local government considers necessary or advisable, including, without limitation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: imposing any term or condition contemplated by the Provincial guidelines in relation to an exemption,
requiring that a person submit a report described in subsection (7) (b), and

bcl:text.#text: requiring that a person enter into a covenant under section 219 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The environment minister may make regulations prescribing a class of persons the minister considers qualified, for the purposes of this section, to certify reports referred to in subsection (7) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Off-street parking and loading space requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require owners or occupiers of any land, or of any building or other structure, to provide off-street parking and loading spaces, including spaces for use by disabled persons,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for the building or other structure, or
for the use of the land, building or other structure;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish design standards for spaces required under paragraph (a), including standards respecting the size, surfacing, lighting and numbering of the spaces;
permit off-street parking spaces required under paragraph (a) to be provided, other than on the site of the building or other structure or use, under conditions that are specified in the bylaw;

as an alternative to complying with a requirement to provide off-street parking spaces under paragraph (a), permit, at the option of the owner or occupier of the land or the building or other structure, the payment to the municipality or regional district of an amount of money specified in the bylaw.

bcl:text.#text: Despite subsection (1), the council of a municipality must not, on or after June 30, 2024, require an owner or occupier of any land, or of any building or other structure, to provide off-street parking or loading spaces for the residential use of a housing unit required to be permitted under section 481.3 (5) .

bcl:text.in:desc: [provincial policy guidelines related to small-scale multi-family housing]
bcl:text.#text: In developing or adopting a bylaw under this section, a local government must consider applicable guidelines, if any, under section 582.1 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Money referred to in subsection (1) (d) is payable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the time the building permit is issued for the applicable building or other structure, or
if no building permit is required, at the time the use that requires the parking space specified in the bylaw begins.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under this section may make different provisions for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different classes of uses, or of buildings or other structures as established by the bylaw;

bcl:text: subject to subsection (4), different activities and circumstances relevant to transportation needs that are related to
as established by the bylaw;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a use,
a building or other structure, or
a class of use or of buildings or other structures

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different areas;
different zones;
different uses within a zone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A provision under subsection (3) (b) must not increase the number of off-street parking spaces required under subsection (1) (a).

bcl:text: A provision under subsection (3) that establishes requirements with respect to the amount of space for different classes does not apply with respect to

so long as the land, or the building or other structure, continues to be put to a use that does not require more off-street parking or loading spaces than were required for the use existing at the time the bylaw came into force.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land, or
a building or other structure existing at the time the bylaw came into force,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under this section may exempt one or more of the following from any provisions of such a bylaw:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a class of use, or of buildings or other structures, as established by the bylaw;

bcl:text: an activity or circumstance relevant to transportation needs that is related to
as established by the bylaw;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a use,
a building or other structure, or
a class of use or of buildings or other structures

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a use, or a building or other structure, existing at the time of the adoption of a bylaw under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If money is received by a municipality or regional district under subsection (2), the municipality or regional district must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish a reserve fund for the purpose of providing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: new and existing off-street parking spaces, or
transportation infrastructure that supports walking, bicycling, public transit or other alternative forms of transportation, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: place the money to the credit of the reserve fund.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If reserve funds are established for both the purpose of subsection (7) (a) (i) and the purpose of subsection (7) (a) (ii), the reserve funds must be separate.

Before June 30 in each year, a local government must prepare and consider a report respecting the previous year in relation to the reserve funds required under this section, including the following information separately for each of the purposes established under subsection (7):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amounts received under subsection (2) in the applicable year;
the expenditures from the reserve funds in the applicable year;
the balance in the reserve funds at the start and at the end of the applicable year;
the projected timeline for future projects to be funded from the reserve funds.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The local government must make a report under subsection (9) available to the public from the time it considers the report until June 30 in the following year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Off-street parking in transit-oriented areas

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 525 (1) (a) but subject to the regulations, if any, a local government must not require an owner or occupier of any land in a transit-oriented area, or of any building or other structure on the land, to provide off-street parking spaces for the residential use of the land, building or other structure, other than off-street parking spaces for use by disabled persons.

If an owner or occupier of land, buildings or other structures in a transit-oriented area provides, despite not being required to do so, off-street parking spaces, other than off-street parking spaces for use by disabled persons, for the residential use of the land, buildings or other structures, a local government may, by bylaw, establish for those spaces design standards referred to in section 525 (1) (b).

If the Lieutenant Governor in Council makes regulations requiring an owner or occupier of any land in a transit-oriented area, or of any building or other structure on the land, to provide off-street parking spaces for the residential use of the land, building or other structure, section 525 (1) (b) to (d) and (2) to (10) applies in relation to those spaces as if they were required to be provided by a bylaw under section 525.

bcl:text.in:desc: [provincial policy guidelines related to transit-oriented areas]
bcl:text.#text: In developing or adopting a bylaw under section 525, a local government must consider applicable guidelines, if any, under section 585.5 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulation of signs

bcl:text.#text: Subject to the  and section 135 of the , a local government may, by bylaw, regulate the number, size, type, form, appearance and location of any signs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may make different provisions for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different zones;
different uses within a zone;
different classes of highways.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The power in subsection (1) to regulate includes the power to prohibit, except that a sign that is located on a parcel and relates to or identifies a use on that parcel must not be prohibited.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Screening and landscaping to mask or separate uses

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, require, set standards for and regulate the provision of screening or landscaping for one or more of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: masking or separating uses;
preserving, protecting, restoring and enhancing the natural environment;
preventing hazardous conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may set different requirements, standards and regulations for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different zones;
different uses within a zone;
different locations within a zone.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Non-conforming uses: authority to continue use

bcl:text: Subject to this section, if, at the time a land use regulation bylaw is adopted,
the use may be continued as a non-conforming use.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land, or a building or other structure, to which that bylaw applies is lawfully used, and
the use does not conform to the bylaw,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a non-conforming use authorized under subsection (1) is discontinued for a continuous period of 6 months, any subsequent use of the land, building or other structure becomes subject to the land use regulation bylaw.
The use of land, a building or other structure, for seasonal uses or for agricultural purposes, is not discontinued as a result of normal seasonal or agricultural practices, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seasonal, market or production cycles,
the control of disease or pests, or
the repair, replacement or installation of equipment to meet standards for the health or safety of people or animals.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A building or other structure that is lawfully under construction at the time of the adoption of a land use regulation bylaw is deemed, for the purpose of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to be a building or other structure existing at that time, and
to be then in use for its intended purpose as determined from the building permit authorizing its construction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If subsection (1) authorizes a non-conforming use of part of a building or other structure to continue, the whole of that building or other structure may be used for that non-conforming use.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Non-conforming structures: restrictions on maintenance, extension and alteration

bcl:text: If the use and density of buildings and other structures conform to a land use regulation bylaw but
the building or other structure or spaces may be maintained, extended or altered to the extent authorized by subsection (2).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the siting, size or dimensions of a building or other structure constructed before the bylaw was adopted does not conform with the bylaw, or
the siting, size, dimensions or number of off-street parking or loading spaces constructed or provided before the bylaw was adopted does not conform with the bylaw,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A building or other structure or spaces to which subsection (1) applies may be maintained, extended or altered only to the extent that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the repair, extension or alteration would, when completed, involve no further contravention of the bylaw than that existing at the time the repair, extension or alteration was started, and
in the case of protected heritage property, the repair, extension or alteration is permitted or authorized in accordance with the provisions governing the heritage protection of the property.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on increasing non-conforming use of land

bcl:text.#text: In relation to land, section 528  does not authorize the non-conforming use of land to be continued on a scale or to an extent or degree greater than that at the time of the adoption of the land use regulation bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on alteration or addition to building or other structure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a structural alteration or addition must not be made in or to a building or other structure while a non-conforming use is continued in all or any part of it.

bcl:text.in:desc: [authority for variance or exemption to relieve hardship]
bcl:text.#text: Subsection (1) does not prohibit a structural alteration or addition that is required by an enactment or is permitted by a board of variance under section 542 (1) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to alterations or additions in or to a protected heritage property if the alteration or addition is authorized by a heritage alteration permit under section 617.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on repair or reconstruction of non-conforming structures

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a building or other structure, the use of which does not conform to the provisions of a land use regulation bylaw, is damaged or destroyed to the extent of 75% or more of its value above its foundations, as determined by the building inspector, the structure must not be repaired or reconstructed except for a conforming use in accordance with the bylaw.

in:desc: [zoning rules for land subject to the agreement]
bcl:text.#text: If the use of a building or other structure that is on land identified in a phased development agreement under Division 12  complies with a zoning bylaw provision specified under section 516 (2)  for the phased development agreement, subsection (1) of this section does not apply to the building or other structure while the phased development agreement is in effect, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the provision has been repealed or amended, and
either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the developer has agreed in writing under section 516 (5) that the changes to the zoning bylaw apply, or
the changes to the zoning bylaw apply under section 516 (6) without the written agreement of the developer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to repair or reconstruction of a protected heritage property if the repair or reconstruction is authorized by a heritage alteration permit under section 617.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Non-conforming uses in relation to terminated land use contracts

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

in:desc: [termination of all remaining land use contracts]
bcl:text.#text: means, in relation to a land use contract, the date of termination under section 547  or 548 , as applicable;

bcl:text.in:term: end of land use contract authority
bcl:text.#text: means, in relation to a land use contract, the later of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contract termination date;

bcl:text.in:desc: [board of variance exemption to relieve hardship from early termination]
bcl:text.#text: if an order under section 543  is made in respect of the land, the expiry of the period of time specified in the order.

bcl:text: Subject to this section, if, at the end of land use contract authority,
the use may be continued as a non-conforming use.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land, or a building or other structure, is lawfully used, and
the use does not conform to a land use regulation bylaw that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is in force at the end of land use contract authority, and
would not apply to the land, building or other structure but for the end of the land use contract authority,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the non-conforming use authorized under subsection (2) is discontinued for a continuous period of 6 months, any subsequent use of the land, building or other structure becomes subject to the land use regulation bylaw.
The following provisions apply in relation to a use described in subsection (2):

bcl:text.in:desc: [non-conforming uses in relation to new land use regulation rules]
bcl:text.#text: section 528 (3) to (5) ;
section 529 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [restrictions on increasing non-conforming use of land]
bcl:text.#text: section 530 ;
section 531 ;
section 532 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (4), a reference in a provision referred to in that subsection to the adoption of a bylaw is to be read as a reference to the applicable end of contract authority.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Change in ownership, tenants or occupants in relation to use
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Division, a change of owners, tenants or occupants of any land, or of a building or other structure, does not, by reason only of the change, affect the use of the land or building or other structure.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Non-conforming use and subdivision in relation to expropriation of land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the use of land or the siting of existing buildings and other structures on the land ceases, as a result of expropriation of land, to conform to a land use regulation bylaw, the remainder of the property is deemed to conform.

Subsection (1) does not apply if compensation was paid to the owner or occupant of the land in an amount that is directly attributable to the loss, if any, suffered by the owner or occupant as a result of the non-conformity.

bcl:text: If, as a result of an expropriation,
the parcel is, to the extent authorized under subsection (4), deemed to conform to the applicable zoning bylaw for the purposes of the subdivision as though the expropriation had not occurred.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a parcel of land could have been subdivided into 2 or more parcels under the applicable zoning bylaw in effect when the land expropriated was vested in the expropriating authority, and
the parcel, as a result of the expropriation, can no longer be subdivided into the same number of parcels,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The deemed conformance under subsection (3) applies only to the extent that none of the parcels that would be created by the subdivision would be less than 90% of the area that would otherwise be permitted by the applicable zoning bylaw.

Subsection (3) does not apply if the owner of the parcel being subdivided has received compensation that is directly attributable to the reduction in the market value of the land that results from the inability to subdivide the parcel in the manner that would have been permitted under the applicable zoning bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Non-conforming form of tenure: authority to continue tenure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, at the time a zoning bylaw that limits the form of tenure to residential rental tenure is adopted, a housing unit to which the bylaw applies has a form of tenure other than residential rental tenure, the other form of tenure continues as a non-conforming form of tenure.

If, at the time a zoning bylaw that limits the form of tenure to residential rental tenure is adopted, a local government has issued a building permit or a development permit in relation to a building that will contain housing units to which the bylaw would otherwise apply, and the housing units have or may have a form of tenure other than residential rental tenure, the other form of tenure continues as a non-conforming form of tenure.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Non-conforming form of tenure: repair, extension and alteration

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), if a non-conforming form of tenure is authorized, under section 535.1, to continue in relation to a housing unit in a building and the building is maintained, extended or altered, the non-conforming form of tenure continues if the repair, extension or alteration would, when completed, involve no further contravention of the bylaw than that existing at the time the repair, extension or alteration was started.
If the repair, extension or alteration includes the construction of additional housing units, the additional housing units are subject to the zoning bylaw in relation to residential rental tenure.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Change in ownership, tenants or occupants in relation to form of tenure
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Division and subject to section 535.4, a change of owners, tenants or occupants of a housing unit does not, by reason only of the change, affect the authority to continue a non-conforming form of tenure of the housing unit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissolution of strata corporations
bcl:text: If
the non-conforming form of tenure is no longer authorized to continue.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a non-conforming form of tenure is authorized to continue under section 535.1 in relation to a housing unit in a building,
the building includes strata lots,

bcl:text.#text: the strata corporation for the owners of the strata lots is wound up under Part 16 of the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is a disposition of all of the land and the building of that strata corporation,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulation-making powers

bcl:text.#text: In relation to this Division, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting non-conforming forms of tenure, including, without limitation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulations prescribing circumstances in which a non-conforming form of tenure is authorized, or is no longer authorized, to continue, and
regulations in relation to when a non-conforming form of tenure is no longer authorized.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement for board of variance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government that has adopted a zoning bylaw must, by bylaw, establish a board of variance.
A person is not eligible to be appointed to a board of variance if the person is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of the local government or the advisory planning commission, or
an officer or employee of the local government.

bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsections (4) and (5) and to the rules established under section 538 (2) (b) (i) , an appointment to a board of variance is for a 3 year period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If no successor has been appointed at the end of the 3 year period referred to in subsection (3), the appointment continues until the time that a successor is appointed.
A local government may rescind an appointment to a board of variance at any time.

If a member of a board of variance ceases to hold office, the person's successor is to be appointed in the same manner as the member who ceased to hold office, and, until the appointment of the successor, the remaining members constitute the board of variance.

Members of a board of variance must not receive compensation for their services as members, but must be paid reasonable and necessary expenses that arise directly out of the performance of their duties.
A local government must provide in its annual budget for the necessary funds to pay for the costs of the board of variance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board of variance for municipality or regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the population of a municipality is 25 000 or less, the municipal board of variance is to consist of 3 persons appointed by the council.
If the population of a municipality is more than 25 000, the municipal board of variance is to consist of 5 persons appointed by the council.
A regional district board of variance is to consist of 3 persons appointed by the board.

The board of a regional district may establish one or more boards of variance for the regional district, but, if more than one board of variance is established, the bylaw establishing them must specify the area of the regional district over which each board of variance has jurisdiction and those areas must not overlap.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Joint board of variance

bcl:text.#text: Two or more local governments may satisfy the obligation under section 536 (1)  by jointly establishing a board of variance by bylaw adopted by all participating local governments.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specify the area of jurisdiction for the board of variance, which may be all or part of the participating local governments, but must not overlap with the area of jurisdiction of any other board of variance, and

bcl:text.#text: establish rules for the following that apply in place of those established by sections 536  and 539 :

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: appointment and removal of members of the board of variance;
appointment and removal of a chair of the board of variance.

bcl:text.#text: As exceptions to section 537 , the following apply to a board of variance established under this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a municipality is one of the participating local governments, the board of variance is to consist of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 3 persons, if the population of the area of the jurisdiction of the board of variance is 25 000 or less, and
5 persons, if the population of the area of the jurisdiction of the board of variance is more than 25 000;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a municipality is not one of the participating local governments, the board of variance is to consist of 3 persons.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair and procedures for board of variance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The members of a board of variance must elect one of their number as chair.
The chair may appoint a member of the board of variance as acting chair to preside in the absence of the chair.

in:desc: [notice of application in relation to early termination of land use contract]
bcl:text.#text: A bylaw establishing a board of variance must set out the procedures to be followed by the board of variance, including the manner in which appeals are to be brought and notices under section 541  or 543 (2)  are to be given.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A board of variance must maintain a record of all its decisions and must ensure that the record is available for public inspection during regular office hours.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for variance or exemption to relieve hardship

bcl:text.#text: A person may apply to a board of variance for an order under section 542  if the person alleges that compliance with any of the following would cause the person hardship:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bylaw respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the siting, size or dimensions of a building or other structure, or
the siting of a manufactured home in a manufactured home park;

bcl:text.in:desc: [provision of water, sewer and other systems]
bcl:text.#text: a subdivision servicing requirement under section 506 (1) (c)  in an area zoned for agricultural or industrial use;

bcl:text.in:desc: [restrictions on alteration or addition while non-conforming use continued]
bcl:text.#text: the prohibition of a structural alteration or addition under section 531 (1) ;

a bylaw under section 8 (3) (c)  of the , other than a bylaw that has an effect referred to in section 50 (2)  of that Act if the council has taken action under subsection (3) of that section to compensate or mitigate the hardship that is caused to the person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of application for variance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person makes an application under section 540, the board of variance must notify all owners and tenants in occupation of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the land that is the subject of the application, and
the land that is adjacent to land that is the subject of the application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under subsection (1) must state the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subject matter of the application;
the time and date when and, if applicable, the place where the application will be heard;
if the meeting at which the application is heard is conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities, the way in which the meeting is to be conducted by those means.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The obligation to give notice under subsection (1) is satisfied if the board of variance made a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board powers on application

bcl:text.in:desc: [alteration or addition while non-conforming use continued]
bcl:text.#text: On an application under section 540, the board of variance may order that a minor variance be permitted from the requirements of the applicable bylaw, or that the applicant be exempted from section 531 (1) , if the board of variance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has heard the applicant and any person notified under section 541,
finds that undue hardship would be caused to the applicant if the bylaw or section 531 (1) is complied with, and
is of the opinion that the variance or exemption does not do any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: result in inappropriate development of the site;
adversely affect the natural environment;
substantially affect the use and enjoyment of adjacent land;
vary permitted uses and densities under the applicable bylaw;
defeat the intent of the bylaw;
vary the application of an applicable bylaw in relation to residential rental tenure.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board of variance must not make an order under subsection (1) that would do any of the following:

bcl:text.#text: be in conflict with a covenant registered under section 219 of the  or section 24A of the , R.S.B.C. 1960, c. 208;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deal with a matter that is covered in a land use permit or covered in a land use contract;

bcl:text.#text: deal with a matter that is covered by a phased development agreement under Division 12 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deal with a flood plain specification under section 524 (3);
apply to a property

bcl:text.#text: for which an authorization for alterations is required under Part 15 ,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for which a heritage revitalization agreement under section 610 is in effect, or

bcl:text.#text: that is scheduled under section 614 (3) (b)  or contains a feature or characteristic identified under section 614 (3) (c) .

bcl:text: In relation to an order under subsection (1),
the permission or exemption terminates and the bylaw or section 531 (1), as the case may be, applies.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the order sets a time within which the construction of the building, structure or manufactured home park must be completed and the construction is not completed within that time, or
if that construction is not substantially started within 2 years after the order was made, or within a longer or shorter time period established by the order,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision of the board of variance under subsection (1) is final.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemption to relieve hardship from early termination of land use contract

bcl:text.#text: The owner of land subject to a land use contract that will be terminated by a bylaw adopted under section 548  may apply to a board of variance for an order under subsection (5) of this section if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner alleges that the timing of the termination of the land use contract by the bylaw would cause the owner hardship, and
the application is received by the board of variance within 6 months after the adoption of the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an application is made under subsection (1), the board of variance must notify all owners and tenants in occupation of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the land that is the subject of the application, and
the land that is adjacent to land that is the subject of the application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under subsection (2) must state the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the subject matter of the application;
the time and date when and, if applicable, the place where the application will be heard;
if the meeting at which the application is heard is conducted by means of electronic or other communication facilities, the way in which the meeting is to be conducted by those means.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The obligation to give notice under subsection (2) must be considered satisfied if the board of variance made a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

On an application under subsection (1), the board of variance may order that, despite the termination of the land use contract and despite any zoning bylaw, the provisions of that land use contract continue to apply in relation to the applicant for a specified period of time ending no later than June 30, 2024, if the board of variance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has heard the applicant, and
finds that the timing of the termination of the land use contract by the bylaw would cause undue hardship to the applicant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order under subsection (5) does not run with the land.
The board of variance must make a decision on an application under subsection (1) within 6 months after the application is received by the board of variance.
A decision of the board of variance under subsection (5) is final.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Extent of damage to non-conforming use property

bcl:text.in:desc: [end of non-conforming use protection if building of other structure is seriously damaged]
bcl:text.#text: A person may apply to a board of variance for an order under subsection (2) if the person alleges that the determination by a building inspector of the amount of damage under section 532 (1)  is in error.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an application under subsection (1), the board of variance may set aside the determination of the building inspector and make the determination under section 532 (1) in its place.
The applicant or the local government may appeal a decision of the board of variance under subsection (2) to the Supreme Court.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Discharge and Termination of Land Use Contracts

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application to land use contracts under previous legislation

bcl:text.#text: This Division applies to land use contracts within the meaning of section 702A of the , R.S.B.C. 1960, c. 255, before that section was repealed under section 13 of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment and discharge of land use contract

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means modify, vary or discharge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), a land use contract that is registered in a land title office may be amended as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by bylaw, with the agreement of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the local government, and
the owner of any parcel that is described in the bylaw as being covered by the amendment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to subsection (3), by a development permit or a development variance permit, if the amendment does not affect the permitted use or density of use of any parcel against which the contract is registered;
in the manner specified in the land use contract.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A land use contract must not be discharged in the manner provided for in subsection (2) (b).

in:desc: [approval required for development near controlled access highway]
bcl:text.#text: Unless exempted by regulation under section 505 (4) , if a parcel affected by an amendment under this section is subject to section 52 (3)  of the ,
until it has been approved by the minister responsible for the administration of the .

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a bylaw under subsection (2) (a) must not be adopted, or
a development permit or development variance permit under subsection (2) (b) must not be issued

bcl:text.in:desc: [Public Hearings on Planning and Land Use Bylaws]
bcl:text.#text: If a local government proposes to amend a land use contract under subsection (2) (a) respecting any matter in it relating to density or use of an area covered by the contract, Division 3  applies.
If a land use contract is amended by bylaw, a development permit or a development variance permit, the local government must register the amendment in the land title office in accordance with the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On registration under subsection (6), the registrar of land titles may require

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a certified copy of the bylaw under this section be registered together with the amendment to the land use contract, and
that a certified copy of the development variance permit or development permit be registered together with the land use contract as amended by it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar of land titles is not required to inquire whether the land use contract amendment has been made in accordance with this Part or whether it is a valid amendment before permitting registration of an amendment under subsection (6).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Termination of all land use contracts in 2024

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All land use contracts are terminated on June 30, 2024.
A local government that has jurisdiction over land subject to a land use contract must, by June 30, 2022, adopt a zoning bylaw that will apply to the land on June 30, 2024.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Process for early termination of land use contract

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means, in relation to a land use contract that is registered as a charge against a title to land, the serial number assigned to the land use contract by the registrar of land titles;
means a permanent parcel identifier assigned under section 58 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 547, a local government may, by bylaw, terminate a land use contract that applies to land within the jurisdiction of the local government.
A bylaw under subsection (2)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must not be adopted after June 30, 2022,
must provide that the bylaw comes into force on a date that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least one year after the date the bylaw is adopted, and
not later than June 30, 2024, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must not be adopted unless the local government has adopted a zoning bylaw that will apply to the land on the date the bylaw under subsection (2) comes into force.

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment and discharge of land use contracts]
bcl:text.#text: Section 546  does not apply in relation to a bylaw adopted under subsection (2).

bcl:text.in:desc: [at least one day between third reading and adoption]
bcl:text.#text: Despite section 135 (3)  of the , a council may adopt a bylaw under subsection (2) at the same meeting at which the bylaw passed third reading.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 30 days after adopting a bylaw under subsection (2), a local government must give written notice of the bylaw to the proper land title office for each parcel of land subject to a land use contract that the bylaw will terminate.
A notice under subsection (6) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in a form satisfactory to the registrar of land titles,
include a certified copy of the bylaw, and
identify the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by charge number, each land use contract that the bylaw will terminate;
by legal description and parcel identifier, each parcel of land subject to a land use contract that the bylaw will terminate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of termination

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must give written notice of the termination of a land use contract to the owners of land that is within the jurisdiction of the local government and subject to the land use contract.
A notice under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be mailed or otherwise delivered as follows:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the local government adopts a bylaw under section 548 that will terminate the land use contract, by the date that is 10 days after the adoption of the bylaw to the owners as shown on the assessment roll as at the date of the first reading of the bylaw;
if subparagraph (i) does not apply, by June 30, 2022 to the owners as shown on the assessment roll as at a date no more than one month before the notice is mailed or delivered,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the place where and the times and dates when zoning bylaws are available for public inspection, and
