bcl:text.#text: if the local government adopts a bylaw under section 548 that will terminate the land use contract, inform the owners that they may apply to a board of variance for an exemption under section 543 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The obligation to deliver a notice under subsection (2) (a) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Discharge of terminated land use contract

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies despite any enactment or law to the contrary.

bcl:text.#text: If a land use contract is registered as a charge against a title to land and the land use contract is terminated under section 547  or 548 , the charge is deemed to be discharged as of the date of the termination of that land use contract.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are conclusive proof that a land use contract is terminated:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before June 30, 2024,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: this Act, and
a certified copy of the bylaw under section 548 that terminates the land use contract;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on or after June 30, 2024, this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar of land titles is not required to inquire whether a bylaw under section 548 has been made in accordance with this Part before cancelling registration of a charge that is discharged by operation of that bylaw and subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Regulation of Farm Businesses in Farming Areas

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Agriculture minister may set standards for farm bylaws

bcl:link.in:doc: Farm Practices Protection (Right to Farm) Act

bcl:text.#text: In this Division,  means the minister responsible for the administration of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The agriculture minister may establish, publish and distribute standards in relation to farming areas for the guidance of local governments in the preparation of zoning bylaws and bylaws under this Division.
Standards under subsection (2) may differ for different parts of British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Farming area bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section does not apply unless a regulation under section 553 declares that it applies.
A local government may make bylaws in relation to farming areas as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the conduct of farm operations as part of a farm business;

respecting types of buildings, structures, facilities, machinery and equipment that are prerequisite to conducting farm operations specified by the local government and that must be utilized by farmers conducting the specified farm operations;
respecting the siting of stored materials, waste facilities and stationary equipment;
prohibiting specified farm operations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (2) may be different for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different sizes or types of farms;
different types of farm operations;
different site conditions;
different uses of adjoining land;
different areas.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless exempted under subsection (5), a bylaw under subsection (2) may be adopted only with the approval of the agriculture minister.
The agriculture minister may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: defining areas for which and describing circumstances in which approval under subsection (4) is not required, and
providing that an exception under paragraph (a) is subject to the terms and conditions specified by that minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Regulations under subsection (5) may be different for different regional districts, different municipalities, different areas and different circumstances.

bcl:text.#text: A local government may not exercise a power under this or any other Part of this Act or the  to do anything that the local government is specifically authorized to do under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority and restrictions apply as declared by regulation

in:desc: [restrictions on zoning authority in relation to farming]
bcl:text.#text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, declare that, generally or for some or all of the geographic area specified in the regulation, on and after the date specified in the regulation, section 481 (2)  or 552  applies to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the board of a regional district specified in the regulation,
the council of a municipality specified in the regulation, or

bcl:text.#text: the local trust committee under the  of a local trust area specified in the regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Three year review of zoning bylaws affecting farming areas

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a regulation under section 553 respecting the application of section 481 (2)  to a board, council or local trust committee.

A board, council or local trust committee to which an agriculture regulation applies must review all its zoning bylaws in order to identify to what extent, if any, the provisions of those bylaws, relating to any farming areas within the geographic area to which the regulation applies, are inconsistent with the standards established under section 551  by the agriculture minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the first 3 years after an agriculture regulation applies to a board, council or local trust committee, or during any extension to that 3 year period that the agriculture minister may grant, the board, council or local trust committee may, by bylaw, amend its zoning bylaws, in order to achieve consistency between the bylaws as they relate to any farming areas within the geographic area to which the regulation applies and the standards established under section 551 by the agriculture minister.
As an exception to the usual requirements regarding zoning bylaws, a bylaw that makes an amendment authorized under subsection (3) may be adopted without public hearing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Intensive agriculture

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means the use of land, buildings and other structures by a commercial enterprise or an institution for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the confinement of poultry, livestock or fur bearing animals, or
the growing of mushrooms.

bcl:text.#text: Despite a zoning bylaw, intensive agriculture is permitted as a use on agricultural land that is not subject to section 23 (1)  of the .
Subsections (1) and (2) cease to have effect in an area after a zoning bylaw for that area is approved under section 481 (2) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: has the same meaning as in the ;
has the same meaning as in section 39 of the ;
has the same meaning as in section 39 of the ;
means an application for a building permit for which a site disclosure statement must be provided under section 40 (1) (b) of the ;
means an application for a development permit for which a site disclosure statement must be provided under section 40 (1) (b) of the ;
means an application for zoning for which a site disclosure statement must be provided under section 40 (1) (b) of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A municipality or regional district must not approve a specified zoning application, specified development permit application or specified building permit application with respect to a site, unless both of the following are satisfied:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality or regional district has

bcl:text.#text: received the site disclosure statement required under section 40 (1) (b) of the  for the application, and
in accordance with section 40 (4) of the , assessed the site disclosure statement and forwarded it to the registrar;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality or regional district has received one of the following:

in:desc: [investigations required with provision of site disclosure statement]
bcl:text.#text: notice from a director that an investigation of the site is not required under section 40.1 (2)  or 41  of the ;
a final determination under section 44  of the  that the site is not a contaminated site;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: notice from a director that the municipality or regional district may approve the application because, in the opinion of the director, the site would not present a significant threat or risk if the application were approved;
notice from a director that the director has received a remediation plan supporting independent remediation of the site;
notice from a director that the director has entered into a voluntary remediation agreement with respect to the site;

bcl:text.in:desc: [approvals in principle and certificates of compliance]
bcl:text.#text: a valid and subsisting approval in principle or certificate of compliance under section 53  of the  with respect to the site.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (4) applies if a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: makes a specified zoning application for a proposed development at a site, and
makes one or both of the following applications for the same proposed development at the same site:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a specified development application;
a specified building permit application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (2) and in the circumstances referred to in subsection (3), a municipality or regional district may approve the specified zoning application if the municipality or regional district has

bcl:text.#text: received the site disclosure statement required under section 40 (1) (b) of the  for the specified development permit application or specified building permit application, as applicable, and
in accordance with section 40 (4) of the , assessed the site disclosure statement and forwarded it to the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Division
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: planning, engineering and legal costs directly related to the work for which a capital cost may be incurred under this Division, and
interest costs directly related to the work that are approved by the inspector to be included as capital costs;

bcl:text.#text: means those items referred to in section 559 (1) (a) and (b) for which a development cost charge may be imposed;
includes a greater board other than the Board of the Greater Vancouver Sewerage and Drainage District.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development cost charges: imposition and collection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, for the purpose described in subsection (2) or (3), impose development cost charges on every person who obtains

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approval of a subdivision, or
a building permit authorizing the construction, alteration or extension of a building or structure.

bcl:text: Development cost charges may be imposed under subsection (1) for the purpose of providing funds to assist the local government to pay the capital costs of
to service, directly or indirectly, the development for which the charge is being imposed.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: providing, constructing, altering or expanding sewage, water, drainage, fire protection, police, highway and solid waste and recycling facilities, other than off-street parking facilities, and
providing and improving park land

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (a) and section 566 (2) (a), a reference to a highway facility includes highway facilities that serve provincial and municipal interests if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the municipality and the province have entered into an arrangement to share the costs of the highway facilities,
the highway facilities directly or indirectly enable the integrated functioning of the provincial and municipal highway systems, and
the highway facilities, in whole or in part, directly or indirectly service the development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount of the development cost charges imposed for a purpose referred to in subsection (2) respecting highway facilities must not exceed the amount of the costs of the highway facilities to be paid by the municipality.

Development cost charges may be imposed under subsection (1) in a resort region for the purpose of providing funds to assist the local government to pay the capital costs of providing, constructing, altering or expanding employee housing to service, directly or indirectly, the operation of resort activities in the resort region in which the charge is being imposed.
Subject to subsection (5), a development cost charge that is payable under a bylaw under this section must be paid at the time of the approval of the subdivision or the issue of the building permit.

The minister may, by regulation in respect of all or different classes of developments, authorize the payment of development cost charges in instalments and prescribe conditions under which the instalments may be paid.

If a board or greater board has the responsibility of providing a service or park land referred to in subsection (2) in a participating municipality, the board or greater board may, by bylaw under subsection (1), impose a development cost charge that is applicable within that municipality.

The municipality must collect and remit a development cost charge imposed under subsection (6) to the regional district or greater board in the manner provided for in the applicable development cost charge bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inspector approval required for development cost charge bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw that imposes a development cost charge must not be adopted until it has been approved by the inspector.
The inspector may refuse to grant approval under subsection (1) if the inspector determines that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the development cost charge is not related to capital costs attributable to projects included in the financial plan for the municipality or the regional district, as the case may be,

in relation to a development cost charge imposed for a purpose referred to in section 559 (2) respecting highway facilities, the charge does not relate to highway facilities that meet the conditions in section 559 (2.1),

bcl:text.#text: in relation to a development cost charge imposed for the purpose referred to in section 559 (3) , the charge does not relate to resort activities in the resort region, or
the local government has not properly considered the matters referred to in section 564 (4) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The inspector may revoke an approval under subsection (1) in respect of all or part of a bylaw that imposes a development cost charge.

If the inspector revokes an approval, the part of the bylaw in respect of which the revocation applies has no effect until the local government amends the bylaw and obtains the inspector's approval of the amendment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Circumstances in which development cost charges are not payable

bcl:text.#text: A development cost charge is not payable in relation to a development authorized by a building permit that authorizes the construction, alteration or extension of a building or part of a building that is, or will be, after the construction, alteration or extension, exempt from taxation under either of the following provisions of the :

bcl:text.in:desc: [statutory exemption for places of public worship]
bcl:text.#text: section 220 (1) (h) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [permissive exemptions in relation to places of public worship]
bcl:text.#text: section 224 (2) (f) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A development cost charge is not payable if a development cost charge has previously been paid for the same development unless, as a result of further development, new capital cost burdens will be imposed on the municipality, regional district or greater board.
Subject to subsection (4), a development cost charge is not payable if the development does not impose new capital cost burdens on the municipality, regional district or greater board.

bcl:text.#text: Subsection (3) does not apply to a development cost charge imposed for the purpose referred to in section 559 (3) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to a bylaw under subsection (6), a development cost charge is not payable in relation to a development authorized by a building permit that authorizes the construction, alteration or extension of a building that will, after the construction, alteration or extension,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contain fewer than 4 self-contained dwelling units, and
be put to no other use other than the residential use in those dwelling units.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, in a development cost charge bylaw, provide that a development costs charge is payable under the bylaw in relation to a building permit referred to in subsection (5).

Subject to a bylaw under subsection (8) or a regulation under subsection (11) (a), a development cost charge is not payable in relation to the construction, alteration or extension of self-contained dwelling units in a building authorized under a building permit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each unit is no larger in area than 29 square metres, and
each unit is to be put to no other use other than the residential use in those dwelling units.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, in a development cost charge bylaw, establish an area for the purposes of subsection (7) (a) that is greater than the area otherwise applicable, subject to the maximum area permitted by regulation under subsection (11) (b).
A development cost charge is not payable in relation to a development authorized by a building permit if the value of the work authorized by the permit does not exceed, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $50 000, if no bylaw under subsection (10) or regulation under subsection (11) (c) applies,
the amount prescribed by regulation under subsection (11) (c), if no bylaw under subsection (10) applies, or
the amount established by bylaw under subsection (10).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, in a development cost charge bylaw, establish an amount for the purposes of subsection (9) (c) that is greater than the amount otherwise applicable under that subsection, subject to the maximum value permitted by regulation under subsection (11) (d).
The minister may, by regulation, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribe an area for the purpose of subsection (7) (a);
prescribe a maximum area that may be established under subsection (8);
prescribe an amount for the purposes of subsection (9) (b);
prescribe a maximum value that may be established under subsection (10).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General prohibition against waiving or reducing charges

bcl:text.in:desc: [development for which charges may be waived or reduced]
bcl:text.#text: Except as authorized under section 563 , a local government must not provide assistance by waiving or reducing a development cost charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section operates as a restriction on

bcl:text.#text: sections 263 (1) (c)  and 274  of this Act, and
sections 8 (1)  and 21  of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development for which charges may be waived or reduced

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a development that is eligible in accordance with an applicable bylaw or regulation under this section as being for one or more of the following categories:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not-for-profit rental housing, including supportive living housing;
for-profit affordable rental housing;
a subdivision of small lots that is designed to result in low greenhouse gas emissions;
a development that is designed to result in a low environmental impact.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to a bylaw under subsection (3) and an applicable regulation under subsection (6), a local government may waive or reduce a development cost charge for an eligible development.
For the purposes of subsection (2), the local government, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must establish what constitutes an eligible development or a class of eligible development for the purposes of one or more categories of eligible development described in subsection (1),

must establish the amount or rates of reduction for an eligible development, which may be different for different categories of eligible development described in subsection (1) or different classes of eligible development established in the bylaw, and
may establish the requirements that must be met in order to obtain a waiver or reduction under subsection (2) and the conditions on which such a waiver or reduction may be granted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority under subsection (2) is an exception to

bcl:text.#text: section 273  of this Act, and
section 25 (1)  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government delegates the power under subsection (2), the person who is subject to the decision of the delegate is entitled to have the local government reconsider the matter.

bcl:text: The minister may make regulations in relation to subsection (3)
what constitutes an eligible development or a class of eligible development for the purposes of one or more categories of eligible development described in subsection (1).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing,
restricting, or
establishing criteria for determining

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amount of development cost charges to be specified in bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A development charge bylaw must specify the amount of the charge or charges imposed in a schedule or schedules of development cost charges.
Development cost charges may vary as provided in subsection (3), but must be similar for all developments that impose similar capital cost burdens on the local government.
Development cost charges may vary with respect to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different zones or different defined or specified areas;
different uses;
different capital costs as they relate to different classes of development;
different sizes or different numbers of lots or units in a development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In setting development cost charges, a local government must take the following into consideration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: future land use patterns and development;
the phasing of works and services;
the provision of park land described in an official community plan;

bcl:text.#text: how development designed to result in a low environmental impact may affect the capital costs of infrastructure referred to in section 559 (2) and (3) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether the charges are excessive in relation to the capital cost of prevailing standards of service in the municipality or regional district;
whether the charges will, in the municipality or regional district,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: deter development,
discourage the construction of reasonably priced housing or the provision of reasonably priced serviced land, or
discourage development designed to result in a low environmental impact.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must make available to the public, on request, the considerations, information and calculations used to determine the schedule or schedules referred to in subsection (1), but any information respecting the contemplated acquisition costs of specific properties need not be provided.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Deductions from development cost charges

bcl:text: Despite a development cost charge bylaw, if

the amount of the fee or charge imposed or the value of the requirement made, as referred to in paragraph (a), must be deducted from those classes of development cost charges that are applicable to the park land or the types of services for which the fee or charge was imposed or the requirement was made.
a local government has imposed a fee or charge or made a requirement under
for park land or for specific services outside the boundaries of land being subdivided or developed, and

bcl:text.#text: section 397 ,
section 194  of the ,

bcl:text.in:desc: [Subdivision and Development: Requirements and Related Matters]
bcl:text.#text: Division 11  of this Part, or
section 729  of the , R.S.B.C. 1979, c. 290, before the repeal of that section became effective,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the park land or services referred to in paragraph (a) are included in the calculations used to determine the amount of a development cost charge,

bcl:text: Despite a development cost charge bylaw, if
the cost of the service must be deducted from the class of development cost charge that is applicable to the service.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an owner has, with the approval of the local government, provided or paid the cost of providing a specific service, outside the boundaries of land being subdivided or developed, and
that cost is included in the calculations used to determine the amount of a development cost charge,

bcl:text.#text: Despite a development cost charge bylaw, if a work required to be provided under a development works agreement under section 570 (2)  is included in the calculations used to determine the amount of a development cost charge, the applicable amount calculated under subsection (4) or (5) is to be deducted from the development cost charge that would otherwise be payable for that class of work.

bcl:text: For a development cost charge payable by a developer for a work provided by the developer under the agreement, the amount deducted under subsection (3) is to be calculated as
less

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the cost of the work
the amount to be paid by the municipality to the developer under section 570 (3) (b), other than an amount that is an interest portion under section 570 (6) (c).

bcl:text: For a development cost charge payable by a person other than the developer referred to in subsection (4), the amount deducted under subsection (3) is to be calculated as
less

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount charged under section 570 (2) (b) to the owner of the property
any interest portion of that charge under section 570 (6) (c).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of development cost charges

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A development cost charge paid to a local government must be deposited by the local government in a separate special development cost charge reserve fund established for each purpose for which the local government imposes the development cost charge.
Money in development cost charge reserve funds, together with interest on it, may be used only for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to pay the capital costs of providing, constructing, altering or expanding sewage, water, drainage, fire protection, police, highway and solid waste and recycling facilities, other than off-street parking, that relate directly or indirectly to the development in respect of which the charge was collected;

bcl:text: to pay the capital costs of
subject to the restriction that the capital costs must relate directly or indirectly to the development in respect of which the charge was collected;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: acquiring park land or reclaiming land as park land, or
providing fencing, landscaping, drainage and irrigation, trails, restrooms, changing rooms and playground and playing field equipment on park land,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to pay the capital costs of providing, constructing, altering or expanding employee housing that relates to servicing, directly or indirectly, the operation of resort activities in the resort region in respect of which the charge was collected;
to pay principal and interest on a debt incurred by a local government as a result of an expenditure under paragraph (a), (b) or (c);
to pay a person subject to a development cost charge for some or all of the capital costs the person incurred in completing a project described in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the project was completed under an agreement between the person and the local government, and
the project is included in the calculations used to determine the amount of that development cost charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Authority to make payments under subsection (2) must be authorized by bylaw.

The inspector may require a municipality, regional district or greater board to provide the inspector with a report on the status of development cost charge collections, expenditures and proposed expenditures for a time period the inspector specifies.

After reviewing a report under subsection (4), the inspector may order the transfer of funds from a development cost charge reserve fund under this section to a reserve fund established for a capital purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provision of park land in place of all or part of charge

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a development cost charge bylaw provides for a charge to acquire or reclaim park land, all or part of the charge may be paid by providing land in accordance with subsection (2).
Land to be provided for the purposes of subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a location and character acceptable to the local government, and
on the day the charge is payable, have a market value that is at least equal to the amount of the charge.

bcl:text.in:desc: [provision of park land in relation to subdivision]
bcl:text.#text: If the owner and the local government are not able to agree on the market value for the purposes of subsection (2) (b), the market value must be determined in accordance with the regulations under section 510 (7) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If partial payment of a development cost charge for park land in the form of land is made, the remainder must be paid in accordance with a development cost charge bylaw.
If land is to be provided under subsection (1), either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a registrable transfer of the land must be provided to the local government, or

bcl:text.in:desc: [provision of park land in relation to subdivision]
bcl:text.#text: a plan of subdivision on which the land is shown as park must be deposited in the land title office, in which case section 510 (12) and (13)  applies.

bcl:text.in:desc: [use of money in development cost charge reserve fund]
bcl:text.#text: Despite section 566 (2) , interest earned on money in the park land development cost charge reserve fund may be used by the local government to provide for fencing, landscaping, drainage and irrigation, trails, restrooms and changing rooms, playground and playing field equipment on park land owned by the local government or owned by the Crown and managed by the local government.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of bylaws adopted after application for rezoning, development permit or building permit submitted

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means not determined, rejected or withdrawn;
means, in relation to a building permit,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application for the issuance of the building permit, if the application has been submitted to a designated local government officer in a form satisfactory to the designated local government officer and the applicable fee has been paid,
an application for the issuance of a development permit, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the application has been submitted to a designated local government officer in a form satisfactory to the designated local government officer and the applicable fee has been paid, and
the development authorized by the building permit is entirely within the area of land that is the subject of the application, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for an amendment to a zoning bylaw, if

bcl:text.#text: the application has been submitted in accordance with the applicable procedures under section 460  and the applicable fee has been paid, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the development authorized by the building permit is entirely within the area of land to which the application relates.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), a development cost charge bylaw that would otherwise be applicable to the construction, alteration or extension of a building or structure has no effect with respect to that construction, alteration or extension if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the building permit authorizing that construction, alteration or extension is issued within 12 months after the date the bylaw is adopted, and
a precursor application to that building permit is in-stream on the date the bylaw is adopted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not apply if the applicant for that building permit agrees in writing that the development cost charge bylaw should have effect.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual development cost charges report

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before June 30 in each year, a local government must prepare and consider a report in accordance with this section respecting the previous year.

bcl:text.#text: The report must include the following, reported for each purpose under section 559 (2) and (3)  for which the local government imposes the development cost charge in the applicable year:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of development cost charges received;
the expenditures from the development cost charge reserve funds;
the balance in the development cost charge reserve funds at the start and at the end of the applicable year;

bcl:text.in:desc: [development for which charges may be waived or reduced]
bcl:text.#text: any waivers and reductions under section 563 (2) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The local government must make the report available to the public from the time it considers the report until June 30 in the following year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipal development works agreements with private developers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means an agreement under subsection (2);
means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: providing, constructing, altering or expanding sewage, water, drainage, fire protection, police, highway and solid waste and recycling facilities, other than off-street parking facilities, and
improving park land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a council may, by bylaw, do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enter into an agreement with a developer for the provision of works by the municipality or by the developer;
provide a formula for imposing all or part of the cost of the works on the owners of real property in the area subject to the agreement;
specify when the costs imposed under the formula become a debt payable by the owners to the municipality;
provide that, until the debt is paid, the council, an approving officer, a building inspector or other municipal authority is not obliged to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: approve a subdivision plan, strata plan, building permit, development permit, development variance permit or zoning bylaw necessary for the development of real property of a debtor in the area subject to the agreement, or
do any other thing necessary for the development of real property of a debtor in the area subject to the agreement;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide for borrowing the amount required for the municipality to provide a work under the agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting the matters that may be dealt with in a development works agreement, the agreement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must specify

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the area that is the subject of the agreement,
the works that are to be provided under the agreement,
for each work, which party is to provide it, and
for each work, when it is to be provided,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the developer is to provide works under the agreement, must provide for the payment to the developer of charges collected under this section by the municipality from owners within the area subject to the agreement, and
may require the developer to provide security acceptable to the council to ensure compliance with the agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (2) must not be adopted unless at least one of the following requirements has been met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the bylaw has received the assent of the electors in the area that is subject to the development works agreement;
no sufficient petition against the development works agreement has been presented to council after it has given notice of intention to adopt the bylaw;
a sufficient petition for the development works agreement has been presented to the council.

bcl:text.#text: Sections 212 to 214  of the  apply for the purposes of subsection (4) (b) and (c), except that information required in the notice of intention or on each page of the petition for the agreement is the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an identification of the proposed development works agreement, including the information referred to in subsection (3) (a);
a statement of the proposed formula as referred to in subsection (2) (b);
an identification of when the costs imposed under the formula are proposed to become a debt payable to the municipality as referred to in subsection (2) (c);
an identification of any proposed authority referred to in subsection (2) (d);
a statement of any proposed borrowing referred to in subsection (2) (e).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A formula under subsection (2) (b)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be based on the actual cost or on the estimate of the cost as established by the development works agreement,
must provide for the distribution of all or part of the cost among the owners of real property in the area subject to the agreement, and
may provide for increasing the charge payable by owners by an annual interest rate specified in the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The time limit specified under subsection (2) (c) must not be later than the time at which a building permit is issued for the property.
At the time specified under subsection (2) (c), the charge imposed under the formula on an owner constitutes a debt of the owner to the municipality.
The failure of the municipality to collect the debt at the time of an approval or the doing of any other thing referred to in subsection (2) (d) does not affect the collectibility of the debt.

bcl:text.in:desc: [elector approval required for some loan authorization bylaws]
bcl:text.#text: A bylaw that provides for borrowing under subsection (2) (e) is deemed to be a loan authorization bylaw, except that approval of the electors as referred to in section 180  of the  is not required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Division
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: means a facility or feature that provides social, cultural, heritage, recreational or environmental benefits to a community, including, without limitation,

bcl:text: but does not include a facility or feature within a class of facilities or features that are prescribed by regulation not to be amenities;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a community, youth or seniors' centre,
a recreational or athletic facility,
a library,
a day care facility, and
a public square,

bcl:text.#text: means a charge imposed by an amenity cost charge bylaw;
means a bylaw under section 570.2 (1);
includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: planning, engineering and legal costs directly related to the work for which a capital cost may be incurred under this Division,
interest costs directly related to the work referred to in paragraph (a), and
expenditures made to a person or public authority under a partnering agreement in order to pay capital costs incurred by the person or public authority;

bcl:text.#text: means those items referred to in section 570.2 (1) (a) and (b) for which an amenity cost charge may be imposed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amenity cost charges: imposition and collection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, for the purpose described in subsection (2), impose amenity cost charges on every person who obtains

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approval of a subdivision, or
a building permit authorizing the construction, alteration or extension of a building or structure.

bcl:text: Amenity cost charges may be imposed under subsection (1) for the purpose of providing funds to assist the local government to pay the capital costs of providing, constructing, altering or expanding amenities to benefit, directly or indirectly,
for which the charge is being imposed.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the development, and
the increased population of residents or workers that results from the development

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amenity referred to in subsection (2) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be owned by a municipality or regional district, or
be owned or operated by a person or public authority that has entered into a partnering agreement with a municipality or regional district in respect of the amenity.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), an amenity cost charge that is payable under a bylaw under this section must be paid at the time of the approval of the subdivision or the issue of the building permit.

The minister may, by regulation in respect of all or different classes of developments, authorize the payment of amenity cost charges in instalments and prescribe conditions under which the instalments may be paid.

If a board has the responsibility of providing a service that includes providing, constructing, altering or expanding one or more amenities referred to in subsection (2) in a participating municipality, the board may, by bylaw under subsection (1), impose an amenity cost charge that is applicable within that municipality.
The municipality must collect and remit an amenity cost charge imposed under subsection (6) to the regional district in the manner provided for in the applicable amenity cost charge bylaw.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consultation required for amenity cost charge bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the development of a bylaw that imposes an amenity cost charge, or the development of an amendment to such a bylaw, the proposing local government must provide one or more opportunities it considers appropriate for consultation with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the public, and
persons, public authorities and organizations that the local government considers will be affected by the bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No consultation is required to repeal a bylaw referred to in subsection (1).
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting consultation under subsection (1), including regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing notice requirements and the process for consultation;
prescribing persons, public authorities and organizations that must be consulted;
prescribing circumstances in which no consultation is required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Circumstances in which amenity cost charges are not payable

bcl:text.#text: An amenity cost charge is not payable in relation to a development authorized by a building permit that authorizes the construction, alteration or extension of a building or part of a building that is, or will be, after the construction, alteration or extension, exempt from taxation under either of the following provisions of the :

bcl:text.in:desc: [statutory exemption for places of public worship]
bcl:text.#text: section 220 (1) (h) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [permissive exemptions in relation to places of public worship]
bcl:text.#text: section 224 (2) (f) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amenity cost charge is not payable if no increase in the population of residents or workers is expected to result from the development.

An amenity cost charge in respect of a particular amenity is not payable if an amenity cost charge in respect of that amenity has previously been paid for the same development, unless further development is expected to result in an increase in the population of residents or workers.
An amenity cost charge is not payable in respect of a capital cost for which a development cost charge may be imposed.
An amenity cost charge is not payable in relation to a development for any class of affordable housing prescribed by regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General prohibition against waiving or reducing charges

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as authorized under section 570.6, a local government must not provide assistance by waiving or reducing an amenity cost charge.
This section operates as a restriction on

bcl:text.#text: sections 263 (1) (c)  and 274  of this Act, and
sections 8 (1)  and 21  of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Development for which charges may be waived or reduced

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a development that is eligible in accordance with an applicable bylaw or regulation under this section as being for one or both of the following categories:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not-for-profit rental housing, including supportive living housing;
for-profit affordable rental housing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to a bylaw under subsection (3) and an applicable regulation under subsection (6), a local government may waive or reduce an amenity cost charge for an eligible development.
For the purposes of subsection (2), the local government, by bylaw,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must establish what constitutes an eligible development or a class of eligible development for the purposes of one or more categories of eligible development described in subsection (1),

must establish the amount or rates of reduction for an eligible development, which may be different for different categories of eligible development described in subsection (1) or different classes of eligible development established in the bylaw, and
may establish the requirements that must be met in order to obtain a waiver or reduction under subsection (2) and the conditions on which such a waiver or reduction may be granted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The authority under subsection (2) is an exception to

bcl:text.#text: section 273  of this Act, and
section 25 (1)  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government delegates the power under subsection (2), the person who is subject to the decision of the delegate is entitled to have the local government reconsider the matter.

bcl:text: The minister may make regulations in relation to subsection (3)
what constitutes an eligible development or a class of eligible development for the purposes of one or more categories of eligible development described in subsection (1).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing,
restricting, or
establishing criteria for determining

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amenity cost charge bylaw: specifying amenities and setting charges

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amenity cost charge bylaw must specify the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one or more areas in which development is subject to an amenity cost charge;
for each area referred to in paragraph (a), the amenities that will receive funding from an amenity cost charge;
the amount of the charge or charges imposed in a schedule or schedules of amenity cost charges.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Amenity cost charges may vary as provided in subsection (3), but must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be set as a charge

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: per lot or per unit in a development, or
per square metre of floor space in a development, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be similar for all developments that are expected to result in a similar increase in the population of residents or workers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Amenity cost charges may vary with respect to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different areas specified under subsection (1) (a);
different zones;
different uses;
different sizes or different numbers of lots or units in a development;
any other basis for variation prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In specifying, in the amenity cost charge bylaw, the areas in which development is subject to an amenity cost charge and the amenities in each of those areas that will receive funding from the charge, a local government must take the following into consideration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an applicable official community plan and other relevant planning documents;
expected increases in the population of residents and workers;
the local government's financial plan;
any other information prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In setting amenity cost charges, a local government must take the following into consideration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in each area in which development is subject to an amenity cost charge, the capital costs of amenities that will receive funding from the charge;
the phasing of amenities;
whether the charges are excessive in relation to the capital cost of prevailing standards of service in the municipality or regional district;
whether the charges will, in the municipality or regional district,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: deter development, or
discourage the construction of reasonably priced housing or the provision of reasonably priced serviced land;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any other information prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In setting amenity cost charges, a local government must deduct the following from the estimated capital cost of each amenity in an area:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the portion of the estimated capital cost to be funded by grants and other sources of funding that are external to the municipality or regional district;
the portion of the estimated capital cost to be allocated to the existing population of the area and, as a result, funded by the local government;
the portion of the estimated capital cost to be allocated to the development but funded by the local government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must make available to the public, on request, the considerations, information and calculations used to determine the schedule or schedules referred to in subsection (1), but any information respecting the contemplated acquisition costs of specific properties need not be provided.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the setting of amenity cost charges, including regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjusting or limiting amenity cost charges;
prescribing economic and other analyses that local governments must undertake in setting amenity cost charges;
establishing the method for making deductions under subsection (6) (b);
requiring that the method for making deductions under subsection (6) (b) be applied by an individual with a professional designation specified in the regulation;
specifying a minimum portion that must be deducted for the purposes of subsection (6) (c).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of amenity cost charges

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An amenity cost charge paid to a local government must be deposited by the local government in a separate special amenity cost charge reserve fund established for each area in which development is subject to an amenity cost charge.
Money in amenity cost charge reserve funds, together with interest on it, may be used only for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to pay the capital costs of providing, constructing, altering or expanding amenities specified in the amenity cost charge bylaw under section 570.7 (1) (b);
to pay principal and interest on a debt incurred by a local government as a result of an expenditure under paragraph (a);
to pay a person subject to an amenity cost charge for some or all of the capital costs the person incurred in completing a project described in paragraph (a) if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the project was completed under an agreement referred to in section 570.9 (1) between the person and the local government, and
the project is included in the calculations used to determine the amount of that amenity cost charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Authority to make payments under subsection (2) must be authorized by bylaw.

The inspector may require a municipality or regional district to provide the inspector with a report on the status of amenity cost charge collections, expenditures and proposed expenditures for a time period the inspector specifies.

After reviewing a report under subsection (4), the inspector may order the transfer of funds from an amenity cost charge reserve fund under this section to a reserve fund established for a capital purpose.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provision of amenity instead of all or part of charge

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite an amenity cost charge bylaw, a local government may, by bylaw and in accordance with this section, enter into an agreement with a person under which the person provides, constructs, alters or expands an amenity, or provides land for an amenity, instead of paying all or part of an amenity cost charge.
An amenity referred to in subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be an amenity that is specified in the amenity cost charge bylaw under section 570.7 (1) (b), and
have a location acceptable to the local government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting the matters that may be dealt with in an agreement under subsection (1), the agreement must specify the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amenity to be provided, constructed, altered or expanded or the land to be provided for the amenity;
the location of the amenity or land;
who is to provide, construct, alter or expand the amenity or provide the land;
when the amenity is to be provided, constructed, altered or expanded or when the land is to be provided;
the value of the amenity or land and how the local government and the person determined that value;
any remainder of the amenity cost charge to be paid under subsection (4);
the payment or crediting to the person of the amount, if any, by which the value of the amenity or land exceeds the amount of the amenity cost charge;
any other information prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If partial payment of an amenity cost charge is made by providing, constructing, altering or expanding an amenity, or providing land for an amenity, the remainder must be paid in accordance with the amenity cost charge bylaw.
If land for an amenity is to be provided under subsection (1), a registrable transfer of the land must be provided to the local government.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of bylaws adopted after application for rezoning, development permit or building permit submitted

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  and  have the same meaning as in section 568 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An initial amenity cost charge bylaw that would otherwise be applicable to the construction, alteration or extension of a building or structure has no effect with respect to that construction, alteration or extension if a precursor application to the building permit authorizing that construction, alteration or extension is in-stream on the date the initial bylaw is adopted.

Subject to subsection (4), an amended amenity cost charge bylaw that would otherwise be applicable to the construction, alteration or extension of a building or structure has no effect with respect to that construction, alteration or extension if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the building permit authorizing that construction, alteration or extension is issued within 12 months, or any longer period prescribed by regulation, after the date the bylaw is amended, and
a precursor application to that building permit is in-stream on the date the bylaw is amended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) does not apply if the applicant for that building permit agrees in writing that the amended amenity cost charge bylaw should have effect.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual amenity cost charges report

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before June 30 in each year, a local government must prepare and consider a report in accordance with this section respecting the previous year.
The report must include the following, reported for each area in which development is subject to an amenity cost charge in the applicable year:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of amenity cost charges received;
the expenditures from the amenity cost charge reserve funds, including the expenditures made to a person or public authority under a partnering agreement;
the balance in the amenity cost charge reserve funds at the start and at the end of the applicable year;

bcl:text.in:desc: [development for which charges may be waived or reduced]
bcl:text.#text: any waivers and reductions under section 570.6 (2) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [provision of amenity instead of all or part of charge]
bcl:text.#text: any amenities provided, constructed, altered or expanded by a person under section 570.9 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any other information prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The local government must make the report available to the public from the time it considers the report until June 30 in the following year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information requested by inspector
bcl:section.bcl:text: As requested by the inspector, a local government must provide the inspector with any information respecting amenity cost charges, including information respecting the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the setting of amenity cost charges;
the development of the amenity cost charge bylaw and of any amendments to it, including consultations undertaken in that development.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations made for purposes of this Division
bcl:section.bcl:text: In making a regulation for the purposes of this Division, the Lieutenant Governor in Council

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must take into consideration any applicable information provided to the inspector under section 570.93, and

may make provisions that the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers necessary or advisable for the purpose of preventing, minimizing or otherwise addressing any transitional difficulties encountered in relation to amenity cost charges.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Division does not restrict other powers
bcl:section.bcl:text: Nothing in this Division restricts or affects any other power of a local government under this or any other Act, subject to

in:desc: [general prohibition against waiving or reducing charges]
[development for which charges may be waived or reduced]
bcl:text.#text: the exceptions provided in sections 570.5 (2)  and 570.6 (4) , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the condition that the capital costs of any amenity funded by an amenity cost charge must be recovered only once.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Division
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: means the current capital plan of a board of education as approved under section 142 of the ;
means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a subdivision of land in a school district,
any new construction, alteration or extension of a building in a school district that increases the number of self-contained dwelling units on a parcel, or

bcl:text.in:desc: [development for which charges may be waived or reduced]
bcl:text.#text: an eligible development, as defined in section 563 (1) , in a school district;
means a self-contained dwelling unit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorized by a zoning bylaw or any other enactment, for a parcel created by a subdivision of land in a school district, or
created by any new construction, alteration or extension of a building in a school district that increases the number of self-contained dwelling units on a parcel;

bcl:text.#text: means a school district for which the board of education has indicated an eligible school site requirement in its approved capital plan;
means a requirement for a school site that is set out in
the final resolution of a board of education under section 574 (5) (a) , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approved capital plan of the board of education;

bcl:text.#text: means the charge set under section 575.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: School site acquisition charge payable

bcl:text.in:desc: [circumstances where charge not payable or is waived or reduced]
bcl:text.#text: Subject to section 573 , every person who obtains subdivision approval or a building permit in respect of a chargeable development in an eligible school district must pay to the local government, for each chargeable development unit that is authorized or will be created, the school site acquisition charge applicable to that category of chargeable development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A school site acquisition charge is imposed under subsection (1) for the purpose of providing funds to assist boards of education to pay the capital costs of meeting eligible school site requirements.
A school site acquisition charge payable under this section must be paid at the applicable time as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a development cost charge is payable under Division 19 in respect of the chargeable development, at the same time as the development cost charge is paid;
if no development cost charge is payable under Division 19, at the time of approval of the subdivision if subdivision is required in respect of the chargeable development;
if neither paragraph (a) nor (b) applies, at the time that a building permit is issued in respect of the chargeable development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to subsection (3), the minister may, in respect of all or different categories of chargeable development, by regulation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorize the payment of school site acquisition charges in instalments, and
prescribe conditions under which the instalments may be paid.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Circumstances in which charge is not payable or is waived or reduced

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A school site acquisition charge is not payable under section 572 if any of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the chargeable development is within a category that is exempt from school site acquisition charges under the regulations;

a school site acquisition charge has previously been paid for the same chargeable development unless, as a result of a further subdivision or issuance of a building permit, more chargeable development units are authorized or will be created on the parcel;
subject to a bylaw under subsection (2), the permit authorizes the construction, alteration or extension of a building that will, after the construction, alteration or extension,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: contain fewer than 4 self-contained dwelling units, and
be put to no other use other than the residential use in those dwelling units.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government may, by bylaw, provide that a school site acquisition charge is payable in relation to a building permit referred to in subsection (1) (c).

A school site acquisition charge is not payable under section 572 in relation to the construction, alteration or extension of self-contained dwelling units in a building authorized under a building permit if

bcl:text.#text: subject to a local government bylaw under section 561 (8)  or a regulation under subsection (11) (a) of that section, each unit is no larger in area than 29 square metres, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each unit is to be put to no other use other than the residential use in those dwelling units.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a development cost charge is waived or reduced under section 563 (2), a school site acquisition charge under section 572 must be waived or reduced to the same extent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Determination of eligible school site requirements

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  includes a local trust committee established under the .

Before submitting a capital plan for approval under section 142 of the , a board of education must consult with each local government in the school district, and the board of education and local government must make all reasonable efforts to reach agreement on the following:

a projection of the number of chargeable development units to be authorized or created in the school district in the time frame specified by the minister under section 142 of the  for school site acquisition planning;
a projection of the number of children of school age, as defined in the , that will be added to the school district as the result of the chargeable development units projected under paragraph (a);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approximate size and the number of school sites required to accommodate the number of children projected under paragraph (b);
the approximate location and value of school sites referred to in paragraph (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Following the consultation under subsection (2) with each local government in the school district, the board of education must make a written proposal that sets out its projections on each matter referred to in subsection (2) (a) to (d) for the school district.
The board of education must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider the proposal referred to in subsection (3) at a public meeting of the board of education, and
provide written notice of the date, time and place of the meeting to each local government in the school district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After considering the proposal referred to in subsection (3) at one or more meetings under subsection (4), the board of education must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pass a resolution setting out its decisions respecting the matters referred to in subsection (3), and
forward a copy of the resolution to each local government in the school district and request that the local government consider the proposed eligible school site requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government that has received a request under subsection (5) (b) must consider the resolution of the board of education at a regular council meeting and, within 60 days of receiving the request,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pass a resolution accepting the resolution of the board of education respecting proposed eligible school site requirements for the school district, or
respond in writing to the board of education indicating that it does not accept the school site requirements for the school district proposed by the board of education and indicating

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: each proposed eligible school site requirement to which it objects, and
the reasons for the objection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local government fails to respond within the time required by subsection (6), it is deemed to have agreed to the proposed eligible school site requirements for the school district set out in the resolution of the board of education.

bcl:text.#text: If the local government provides notice under subsection (6) that it does not accept the proposed eligible school site requirements for the school district, the minister responsible for the administration of the  must appoint a facilitator, whose responsibilities are to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: advise all local governments in the school district of the facilitator's appointment, and
assist the board of education and the local governments to reach an agreement on proposed eligible school site requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the board of education and the local governments reach an agreement under subsection (8), the board of education must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend the resolution under subsection (5) or pass a new resolution under that subsection to reflect the agreement, and
forward a copy of the new or amended resolution to each local government in the school district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If no agreement is reached under subsection (8), the facilitator must

bcl:text.#text: make a report to the minister and the minister responsible for the administration of the  setting out the disagreement between the parties and must make recommendations as to the resolution of the disagreement, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide a copy of the report to the board of education and each local government in the school district.

bcl:text.#text: The board of education must attach a copy of the facilitator's report to its capital plan submitted under section 142 of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Setting school site acquisition charges

bcl:text.#text: Subject to the regulations, within 60 days of receiving approval of its capital plan under section 142 of the , the board of education of an eligible school district must, by bylaw, set the school site acquisition charges applicable to the prescribed categories of chargeable development for the school district in accordance with the following formula:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: charge = [(land value × percentage) ÷ chargeable units] × prescribed factor
the school site acquisition charge applicable to each prescribed category of chargeable development;
the value of land required to meet the eligible school site requirements of the board of education;
35%, or, if another percentage is set by regulation, that other percentage;
the number of chargeable development units set out in the final resolution of the board of education under section 574;
a factor set by regulation for the prescribed categories of chargeable development.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount of a school site acquisition charge set under subsection (1) may not exceed the maximum charge prescribed by regulation for each prescribed category of chargeable development.
Subject to section 576, a school site acquisition charge comes into effect 60 days after the day on which the bylaw setting the charge is adopted by the board of education.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of charge or increase to in-process development

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a chargeable development for which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for a subdivision of land or for the issuance of a building permit has been submitted to an approving officer or a local government, as the case may be, and
the applicable fee has been paid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a school site acquisition charge that would otherwise be applicable to an in-process development comes into effect after the chargeable development became an in-process development, the charge does not apply to that chargeable development until 12 months after the applicable school site acquisition charge bylaw came into effect.

If an increase to a school site acquisition charge that would otherwise be applicable to an in-process development comes into effect after the chargeable development became an in-process development, the increase does not apply to the chargeable development until 12 months after the applicable school site acquisition charge bylaw came into effect.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provision of land in place of all or part of charge
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who is required to pay a school site acquisition charge under section 572 may, in place of the charge, or in partial payment of the charge, provide land to the local government or to the board of education, but only if all of the following agree to the provision of that land:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the local government;
the board of education having responsibility for the school district in which the land is located;
the person otherwise required to pay the school site acquisition charge.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No subdivision approval or building permit unless charge paid

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if a school site acquisition charge is payable under section 572 in respect of a subdivision approval or the issuance of a building permit.
Final subdivision approval must not be given and a building permit must not be issued unless one or more of the following has occurred:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicable school site acquisition charge has been paid to the local government;
if land is to be provided under section 577 in the place of a school site acquisition charge,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a registrable transfer of land has been provided to the local government or the board of education, as the case may be, or

in the case of an application for approval of a subdivision, the approving officer has endorsed on the subdivision plan a statement that final approval to the subdivision is given on the condition that the registrable transfer of land will accompany the application to deposit the subdivision plan in the land title office;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person otherwise required to pay the charge has provided to the local government, in a form satisfactory to the local government, security for payment of the school site acquisition charge or security for the provision of the land referred to in paragraph (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Credit for previous contributions

bcl:text: If a person who is required to pay a school site acquisition charge under section 572 has already

the local government may, with the agreement of the board of education, deduct the value of that land or the amount paid, or a portion of either, from the school site acquisition charge that is payable in respect of a chargeable development.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provided land for a school site in the school district, or
paid all or part of the cost of a school site in the school district,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A deduction may not be made under subsection (1)

bcl:text.#text: for land or money provided to the local government under an agreement entered into under section 942 of the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 323, as it read before January 28, 2000, being the date on which this section came into force, or
for land or money provided to the local government or the board of education under a bylaw made under section 575 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transfer of money and land to board of education

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The local government to which a school site acquisition charge has been paid must, promptly after receiving payment, provide the money to the board of education of the school district in which the chargeable development is located.

bcl:text.in:desc: [provision of land in place of charge]
bcl:text.#text: If land is provided to a local government under section 577 , the local government to which the land is provided must, promptly after receiving title to the land, transfer title to the land to the board of education having responsibility for the school district in which the chargeable development is located.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1) or (2), a local government may charge a board of education administration fees and disbursements authorized by regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations for this Division
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing categories of chargeable development for the purposes of this Division;

bcl:text.#text: prescribing categories of chargeable development that are exempt from school site acquisition charges under section 572 ;
requiring a local government or board of education to supply information for the purpose of section 574 ;
for purposes of the formula set out in section 575 (1) ,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing a percentage for the "percentage" variable, and
prescribing factors in relation to each prescribed category of chargeable development for the "prescribed factor" variable;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing maximum school site acquisition charges payable with respect to the different categories of chargeable development;

respecting the setting of school site acquisition charges under section 575 and, without limitation, enabling or requiring a school district to calculate different school site acquisition charges for one or more local governments in the school district;
governing the procedure a local government or a board of education must follow for the purpose of the calculation referred to in paragraph (f);

bcl:text.in:desc: [transfer of money and land to board of education]
bcl:text.#text: respecting administration fees and disbursements that may be charged under section 580 (3) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provincial policy guidelines

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may establish policy guidelines regarding the process of developing and adopting official community plans by a municipality or a regional district.
The minister may establish policy guidelines regarding the process of developing and adopting any of the following by a regional district:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a zoning bylaw;
a subdivision servicing bylaw;

bcl:text.in:desc: [issue of temporary use permit if no official community plan in effect]
bcl:text.#text: a bylaw under section 493 (1) (b) ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [land use contract amendment with owner agreement]
bcl:text.#text: a bylaw under section 546 (2) (a) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister, or the minister together with other ministers, may establish policy guidelines regarding the content of the plans and bylaws referred to in subsections (1) and (2).
Guidelines under this section may be established only after consultation by the minister with representatives of the Union of British Columbia Municipalities.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provincial policy guidelines related to small-scale multi-family housing

bcl:text.#text: The minister may, after consulting with the minister responsible for the administration of the , establish policy guidelines regarding the following:

the process of developing and adopting, by a municipality or regional district, a zoning bylaw for the purpose of permitting the use or density of use required to be permitted under section 481.3  of this Act;

the process of developing and adopting, by a municipality, a bylaw under section 525  of this Act to the extent that the bylaw relates to the residential use of housing units required to be permitted under section 481.3 (5) of this Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the content of a bylaw referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Designation of resort regions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, designate an area as a resort region.
An area may be designated as a resort region only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area includes a municipality, and
the area does not include a portion of a municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ministerial override orders in the public interest

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if a bylaw has been enacted by a local government under any of the following and the minister considers that all or part of the bylaw is contrary to the public interest of British Columbia:

bcl:text.#text: Division 4 ;
Division 5 ;
Division 6 ;
Division 7 ;
Division 8 ;
Division 9 ;
Division 10 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [Subdivision and Development: Requirements and Related Matters]
bcl:text.#text: Division 11 ;
Division 12 ;
Division 13 ;

bcl:text.in:desc: [amendment and discharge of land use contracts]
bcl:text.#text: section 546 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may notify the local government

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of the minister's objections to the bylaw or official community plan, and
that the council or the board must, within 90 days after receipt of the notice, alter the bylaw or plan accordingly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the local government does not alter the bylaw or plan in accordance with the notice, the minister may, with the prior approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, order the bylaw or plan to be altered in accordance with the notice.
On the date of an order of the minister under subsection (3), the bylaw or plan is conclusively deemed to be altered in accordance with the notice.
An order of the minister under subsection (3) is final and binding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ministerial regulations requiring bylaw approval

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the minister may make regulations requiring approval of the minister before the adoption by a regional district of any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an official community plan;
a zoning bylaw;
