bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a telephone or closed circuit television company, on the gross rentals received in the second preceding year from its subscribers for telephone or television service located in the municipality, including telephone interexchange tolls for calls between exchanges in the municipality;

for any other utility company, on the amount received in the second preceding year by the company for electric light, electric power, water or gas consumed in the municipality, other than amounts received for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: light, power or water supplied for resale,
gas supplied for the operation of motor vehicles fuelled by natural gas, or

bcl:text.#text: gas supplied to any gas utility company, other than a government corporation as defined in the  or a subsidiary of a government corporation.
Tax under subsection (2) is subject to the same remedies and penalties as taxes under Part 7  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A utility company liable to tax under subsection (2) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by October 31 in each year, for the purpose of determining the tax payable in the next year, file with the collector a return of the revenue referred to in that subsection that was received in the preceding year, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [Property Tax Due Dates and Tax Notices]
bcl:text.#text: pay the tax imposed under subsection (2) in accordance with Division 10  of Part 7 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As an exception to subsections (2) and (4), in the case of a company to which this section applies for the first time in the municipality,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the company must pay the tax imposed under subsection (2) in the second year of its operation on the basis of revenue earned in the first year, and
the report of revenue earned in the first year must be filed before May 8 of the second year of operation.

bcl:text.#text: Tax imposed on a utility company under subsection (2) is in place of tax that might otherwise be imposed on the specified improvements under section 197 (1) (a)  of the , and taxes may not be imposed under that provision on the specified improvements although they may be imposed on those improvements under section 197 (1) (b)  of the .
For certainty, all land and improvements of a utility company in a municipality, other than specified improvements, are subject to tax under section 197  of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At 10 a.m. on the last Monday in September, at the council chambers, the collector must conduct the annual tax sale by offering for sale by public auction each parcel of real property on which taxes are delinquent.
If the last Monday in September is a holiday, the annual tax sale must instead be held on the next Monday that is not a holiday.
The collector may adjourn the annual tax sale to the same hour on the following day, and from day to day until each parcel is disposed of.
The collector may act as auctioneer at the annual tax sale.

bcl:text.#text: The collector may also offer for sale at the annual tax sale the other improvements on the real property that are taxable under this Act or the  and on which taxes are delinquent.

bcl:text.in:desc: [recovery of taxes by the legal remedy of distress]
bcl:text.#text: A sale under subsection (5) must be in accordance with section 252  of the .
The sale of real property under this section is not a bar to a sale under section 252 of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Council may exempt Crown land from annual tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A council may, by bylaw, exempt from the annual tax sale the sale of any real property owned by the Provincial government.
An exemption under subsection (1) does not relieve the real property from taxes lawfully imposed or prejudice the right of the collector to offer it for sale in a succeeding year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of annual tax sale

bcl:text.#text: Notice of the annual tax sale must be published in accordance with section 94  of the  and must specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time and place of the annual tax sale, and
the legal description and street address, if any, of the property subject to tax sale.

bcl:text.in:desc: [bylaw to provide for alternative means of publication]
bcl:text.#text: If the council has adopted a bylaw under section 94.2  of the , the notice under this section must be published by at least one of the means of publication specified in the bylaw not less than 3 days and not more than 10 days before the annual tax sale.
If the council has not adopted a bylaw under section 94.2 of the , the last publication of the notice must be not less than 3 days and not more than 10 days before the annual tax sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipality may bid at annual tax sale
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person authorized by the council may bid for the municipality at the annual tax sale up to a maximum amount set by the council.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Upset price for tax sale

bcl:text.#text: The collector is authorized to receive, for use of the municipality, the following amounts from the proceeds of a sale under section 645 :

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of delinquent taxes, taxes in arrear and interest to the first day of the tax sale for which the parcel of land and the improvements are liable for sale;
the taxes, including penalties incurred, for the current year on the land and improvements;
5% of the amounts under paragraphs (a) and (b) of this subsection;

bcl:text.#text: the fees prescribed under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The total of the amounts under subsection (1) is the upset price and the lowest amount for which the parcel may be sold.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purchaser at annual tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The highest bidder above the upset price for a parcel or, if there is no bid above the upset price, the bidder at the upset price must be declared the purchaser.
If there is no bid, or no bid equal to the upset price, the municipality must be declared the purchaser.
If the municipality has been declared the purchaser of a parcel, the collector may offer the parcel for sale again later at the annual tax sale on the same conditions as before.
If a purchaser fails to immediately pay the collector the amount of the purchase price, the collector must promptly again offer the parcel for sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purchaser to give authority to register tax sale title

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the time of the tax sale and before the purchaser is given the certificate of sale, a purchaser other than the municipality must provide a statement, signed by the purchaser or the purchaser's agent,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: setting out the purchaser's full name, occupation and address, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [registration of tax sale purchaser as owner]
bcl:text.#text: authorizing the collector to make the application referred to in section 663 (2)  to register, at the appropriate time, the purchaser's title to the real property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A statement under subsection (1) must be preserved with the records of the sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Collector to provide certificate of sale
bcl:section.bcl:text: After a tax sale to a person other than the municipality, the collector must sign and give to the purchaser a certificate that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describes the parcel sold,
states the sale price, and

states that an indefeasible title will be applied for on the purchaser's behalf at the end of one year from the date of sale unless the property is redeemed or the sale is cancelled under section 668.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax sale of Crown land subject to an agreement to purchase

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector may, by sale at the annual tax sale, sell land, the fee simple of which is vested in the Provincial government but held by a person under an agreement to purchase.

A sale under this section is subject to the interest of the Provincial government and the collector must expressly state at the annual tax sale that the interest of the Provincial government is prior to all claims and is not affected by the sale.
Sections 655 to 664 do not apply to a sale under this section.
The collector must sign and give the purchaser of land at a sale under this section a certificate that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describes the land sold,
states the price at which the land was sold,
states that the interest of the Provincial government has priority over all claims and is not affected by the sale, and
states that the sale is made under this section.

bcl:text.#text: The collector must promptly provide to the minister responsible for the administration of the

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the certificate under subsection (4), and
the address of the purchaser.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provincial government may accept tax sale purchaser

bcl:text.#text: The minister responsible for the administration of the  may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: accept the tax sale purchaser under section 653 as purchaser of the land, and
deal with that purchaser to the exclusion of the person whose interest was sold at the tax sale and of all persons claiming under that person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister referred to in subsection (1) accepts the tax sale purchaser as purchaser of the land, the minister must notify the collector of this.

bcl:text: If the minister referred to in subsection (1)
the purchaser is entitled to a refund from the municipality of the amount the purchaser paid together with interest at the rate prescribed under subsection (4).

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not accept the tax sale purchaser as purchaser of the land, or
does not notify the collector within 6 months from the date of sale that the minister has accepted the purchaser,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe a rate of interest for the purposes of subsection (3).
If a refund is made under subsection (3), the collector must promptly replace the amount of the upset price, together with the interest paid to the purchaser, as delinquent taxes on the land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Resale of land purchased by municipality at annual tax sale

bcl:text.#text: If property is purchased by a municipality under section 650  and is not sold later at the annual tax sale, within 9 months after the purchase, the council may sell the property to any person for not less than the total of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the upset price, and

bcl:text.#text: interest accrued from the date of purchase at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the .
On a sale under this section, the council must direct the collector to give the purchaser a certificate similar to that under section 652 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A sale under this section does not affect the period for or the right of redemption by the owner under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of tax sale must be filed in land title office
bcl:section.bcl:text: Promptly after selling property for taxes, the collector must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file in the proper land title office the notice of the tax sale, and

bcl:text.#text: pay the fees prescribed under the  for filing the notice and making the proper references.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Owners must be given notice of tax sale and redemption period

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Not later than 3 months after the sale of property at an annual tax sale, the collector must give written notice of the sale and of the day the redemption period ends, either by serving the notice or by sending it by registered mail, to persons registered in the land title office as

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: owner of the fee simple of the property, or
owner of a charge on the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application, the Supreme Court may order that the notice under subsection (1) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
No liability or responsibility other than as set out in subsection (1) rests with the collector or municipality to give notice of the sale for taxes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assessment and taxes during redemption period

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period allowed for redemption, real property sold at an annual tax sale must continue to be assessed and taxed in the name of the person who at the time of the tax sale appeared on the assessment roll as owner and that person is liable for taxes accruing.

bcl:text.in:desc: [taxes are a special charge on the land]
bcl:text.#text: The accruing taxes continue to be a special lien on the property under section 250  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tax sale purchaser may pay the taxes that become due during the period of redemption, and the amount paid must be added to the amount required to redeem.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of surplus from tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, if property sold at an annual tax sale is not redeemed, money received by the collector at the annual tax sale above the upset price must be paid without interest to the person who was the owner at the time of the annual tax sale, on written application to the council.

The money must not be paid to the owner referred to in subsection (1) if a claim to the surplus is made by another person on the ground that the property belonged to the other person, or that the other person is otherwise entitled to the surplus.
If a claim referred to in subsection (2) is made, the money must, without leave, be paid into the Supreme Court, accompanied by

bcl:text.#text: a copy of the certificate of sale under section 652 , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a statement of the municipal corporate officer setting out

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the facts under which the payment into court is made, and
the names of both the owner at the time of the tax sale and the claimant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Money paid into court under subsection (3) is payable out of court to the party entitled on a court order to be made on application in a summary manner and subject to the giving of the notices directed by the court.
If surplus money remains unpaid 6 months after the end of the redemption period, in the next month the council must have published in a newspaper a notice stating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the owner to whom the surplus is payable,
the date it became payable, and
the amount of the surplus.

bcl:text.#text: If the surplus remains unclaimed 3 months after publication under subsection (5), it must be transferred to the administrator under the .
Money transferred under subsection (6) is deemed to be an unclaimed money deposit under the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Redemption by owner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A parcel of property sold at an annual tax sale may be redeemed in accordance with this section by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an owner or registered owner in fee simple of the parcel,
an owner of a registered charge against the parcel, or
another person on behalf of a person referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The time limit for making a redemption is one year from the day the annual tax sale began, or a further time allowed by bylaw under subsection (6).

bcl:text.#text: A redemption is made by paying or tendering to the collector for the use and benefit of the purchaser under section 650  the total of the following, subject to any deduction under subsection (4) of this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the upset price of the parcel at the time of the annual tax sale;
all costs of which the collector has had notice that have been incurred by the purchaser in maintenance of the real property and in prevention of waste;
taxes advanced by the purchaser;

bcl:text.#text: interest to the date of redemption on any amount in excess of the upset price and on the total amount expended by the purchaser under paragraphs (a) to (c) of this subsection during the period for redemption, at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If part of the amount received by the collector at the annual tax sale for the purpose of land title fees is not required for that purpose, that part must be deducted from the amount that would otherwise be paid under subsection (3).

bcl:text.#text: On redemption of a parcel, the purchaser is entitled to receive from the municipality all amounts paid by the purchaser, together with interest to the date of redemption at the rate prescribed under section 11 (3) of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the municipality has been declared the purchaser and the property has not been subsequently sold under section 650, the council may, by bylaw, extend for one year only the period for redemption.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Redemption payments by instalments

bcl:text.#text: This section applies in relation to land of which the municipality has been declared the purchaser under section 650  if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are improvements on the land,

in:desc: [sale at annual tax sale after municipality declared purchaser]
[resale of land purchased by municipality at annual tax sale]
bcl:text.#text: the land has not been subsequently sold under section 650  or 655 , and
the municipality has not adopted a bylaw under section 660 (6) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person empowered under section 660 to redeem the land and improvements referred to in subsection (1) of this section is entitled to redeem them under subsection (3) of this section if the person pays to the collector, on or before the latest date allowed under this Act for redemption, 50% of the total of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of the upset price for which the land and improvements were offered for sale, and
interest on the amount under paragraph (a) of this subsection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who makes a payment under subsection (2) may redeem the land and improvements by paying to the collector the remainder of the total referred to in that subsection at any time within 11 months and 21 days from the latest date otherwise allowed for redemption.
In the circumstances described in this section, the time for redemption is extended accordingly.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of redemption to be filed in land title office

bcl:text.#text: If real property sold for taxes is redeemed within the time allowed for redemption, the collector must promptly send to the registrar of land titles for filing the notice required by section 273 of the , together with any applicable fee under that Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registration of tax sale purchaser as owner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a parcel of land sold for taxes is not redeemed as provided in this Act, at the end of the redemption period, the collector must forward a notice to that effect to the registrar of land titles.
The notice under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out the full name, occupation and address of the purchaser, and
be accompanied by

bcl:text.#text: the fees payable under the , and
an application in the form approved under the  for registration of title in fee simple in the name of the purchaser.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: It is not necessary with the application referred to in subsection (2) (b) to produce an outstanding absolute certificate of title or duplicate, or interim certificate of indefeasible title.

bcl:text.#text: On forwarding the notice referred to in subsection (1) to the registrar of land titles, the municipality must immediately notify the administrator under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice referred to in subsection (1) operates

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as a conveyance to the purchaser from the registered owner in fee simple, without proof of the signature of the collector and without an attestation or proof of execution, and

bcl:text: as a quit claim in favour of the purchaser of

bcl:text.in:desc: [interests that continue after registration of tax sale purchaser fee simple interest]
bcl:text.#text: subsisting at the time the application to register is received by the registrar, except the matters set out in section 276 (1) (c) to (g)  of the .

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all right, title and interest of every previous owner in fee simple of the parcel, or of those claiming under any previous owner, and

bcl:text.#text: all claims, demands, payments, charges, liens, judgments, mortgages and encumbrances of every type, whether or not registered under the ,

One application may be made under this section on behalf of a purchaser for registration of any number of parcels contained in the same block and listed on the one notice produced for registration, but subject to the requirements of section 158 of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Refusal of registration

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if

bcl:text.#text: the registrar of land titles refuses to register the title in the name of a purchaser of property at a tax sale and no appeal is made under section 311 of the , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: such an appeal has been made and the decision of the registrar sustained.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The municipality is deemed to have been declared the purchaser of the property at the tax sale and the municipality must refund the purchase price, without interest, to the purchaser.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of tax sale on rights of owners

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When real property is sold at an annual tax sale under this Act, all rights in it held by persons who at the time of the tax sale were an owner of the property or the registered owner of a registered charge on the property, immediately cease to exist, except as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property is subject to redemption as provided in this Act;
the right to possession of the property is not affected during the time allowed for redemption, subject to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: impeachment for waste, and
the right of the purchaser at the tax sale to enter on the property sold to maintain it in a proper condition and to prevent waste;

bcl:text.in:desc: [action by owner to have tax sale set aside]
bcl:text.#text: during the period allowed for redemption, an action may be brought under section 666  to have the tax sale set aside and declared invalid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period allowed for redemption, subsection (1) does not operate to affect in any way the rights of the owners of the property and the owners of a registered charge on the property, among or as between themselves.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Action by owner to have tax sale set aside

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who at the time of a tax sale was the owner or the registered owner of a registered charge on the real property may bring an action in the Supreme Court to have the sale set aside and declared invalid.
An action under subsection (1) may be brought on only one or more of the following grounds:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the property was not liable to taxation during the years in which the taxes for which the property was sold were imposed;
the taxes for which the property was sold were fully paid;

bcl:text.in:desc: [notice of tax sale and redemption period]
bcl:text.#text: the collector did not give to that person the notice required by section 657 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: irregularities existed in connection with the imposition of the taxes for which the property was sold;
the sale was not fairly and openly conducted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An action under this section may not be brought until one month after written notice has been given by the person to the council stating in detail the grounds of complaint.

During the period allowed for redemption, subsection (1) does not operate to affect in any way the rights of the owners of the property and the owners of a registered charge on the property, among or as between themselves.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court may reinstate taxes if sale set aside

bcl:text.in:desc: [problems with imposition of tax or conduct of tax sale]
bcl:text.#text: If the court declares that a tax sale is set aside or invalid for a reason referred to in section 666 (2) (d) or (e) , the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide that the amount of unpaid taxes on the real property at the date of sale, together with interest from that date, is a lien on the property as if the tax sale had not taken place, in which case that amount is deemed to be delinquent taxes,
provide for the immediate payment of those taxes, or
otherwise deal with those taxes according to the circumstances.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Council authority to cancel sale in case of error

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period allowed for redemption, if the council finds a manifest error in the tax sale or in the proceedings before the sale, it may order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the purchase price be returned to the purchaser together with interest at the rate prescribed under subsection (2), and
the taxes be dealt with as the circumstances require, either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by restoring the taxes as they were before the sale, or
otherwise as directed by the council.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe a rate of interest for the purposes of subsection (1) (a).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions on legal actions in relation to tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the end of the period allowed for redemption, no action may be brought to recover the property sold or to set aside its sale.
No action may be brought

bcl:text.#text: against the registrar of land titles, the minister charged with the administration of the , the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia or the collector in respect of the sale of the property or the registration of an indefeasible title to it, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: against the municipality in respect of any loss or damage sustained by reason of the sale, except as provided in this section.

bcl:text.in:desc: [property not liable for tax, tax paid or notice of tax sale not given]
bcl:text.#text: A person who at the time of the tax sale was an owner of, a registered owner in fee simple of or an owner of a registered charge on the property must be indemnified by the municipality for any loss or damage sustained by the person on account of the sale of the property if the circumstances referred to in section 666 (2) (a), (b) or (c)  existed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As limits on subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: no action may be brought to recover indemnity or compensation under this section after the end of one year from the time allowed by this Act for redemption of the real property, and

there is no right to indemnity or compensation under subsection (3) if it is shown that the person claiming indemnity or compensation was aware at the time of tax sale that the property was offered for sale, or was aware during the period allowed for redemption that it had been sold.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repossessed tax sale land
bcl:section.bcl:text: If land that became the property of a municipality as a result of a tax sale has been sold by agreement for sale or subject to mortgage and is repossessed by the municipality for satisfaction of amounts due, the land is deemed to again be tax sale land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure if purchaser under agreement for sale defaults

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector must send a notice in accordance with subsection (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: land becomes the property of the municipality as a result of tax sale or failure to pay taxes and is sold by agreement for sale, and
there is default in the payment to the municipality of any instalment or interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The notice under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be sent to the purchaser

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by personal service on the purchaser, or
by registered mail to the purchaser at the purchaser's address named in the agreement for sale, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be to the effect that, if the amounts in default are not paid within 90 days from the date of the service or mailing,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all the right, title and interest of the purchaser in and to the agreement for sale, the amounts paid under it and the land referred to in it will cease and determine, and
the amounts paid under the agreement for sale will be forfeited to the municipality.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application, the Supreme Court may order that a notice under subsection (1) may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
If the purchaser fails to pay or cause to be paid the amounts in default within the period referred to in subsection (2) (b),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all that person's right, title and interest in and to the agreement for sale, the amounts paid under it and the land referred to in it cease and determine,
the land immediately revests in the municipality, free from all claims in respect of the agreement for sale, and
all amounts paid under the agreement are forfeited to the municipality.

bcl:text.#text: Despite the  or any rule of law or equity to the contrary, a person may not commence or bring an action against the municipality for relief against forfeiture or otherwise in respect of the cancellation of the agreement for sale or the retainer of the money paid to the municipality under the agreement for sale.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the collector filing in the land title office an affidavit of the continuation of the default after the end of the 90 day period, together with evidence of notice or service, the registrar of land titles must cancel all charges or encumbrances, of any type, appearing in the records of the land title office against the land.

The registrar of land titles may require evidence of sufficiency of service and, if not satisfied, the service must be done in the manner the Supreme Court may direct on an application by the municipality without notice to any other person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Redemption by municipality of land sold for Provincial taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if

bcl:text: land in a municipality has
under any statute for the recovery of Provincial taxes, school taxes, diking assessments or other charges in arrear, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: become subject to forfeiture to the Provincial government, or
been sold by the Surveyor of Taxes or the Inspector of Dikes to a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are taxes in arrear due to the municipality in respect of the land.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstances referred to in subsection (1), the council may redeem the land at any time during the period allowed for redemption by paying to the Surveyor of Taxes or the Inspector of Dikes, as applicable, the amount required to redeem it as provided in the Act under which the land became subject to forfeiture or was sold.

On the redemption of land by a council under this section, it may add the amount of the redemption payment made by it to the amount of municipal taxes in arrear in respect of the land, and the amount added is deemed to be delinquent taxes under this Act.

If land subject to forfeiture referred to in subsection (1) has not been redeemed, but has been forfeited to and vested in the Provincial government, the council may purchase the land under the terms of any Act that provides for sale of the forfeited land to the municipality.

Despite the sale of land referred to in subsection (1) by the Surveyor of Taxes or by the Inspector of Dikes for the recovery of taxes, assessments or other charges in arrear, the land continues to be liable to taxation by the municipality in which it is located.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions in relation to this Part
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:text.in:desc: [tax collection on behalf of improvement district]
bcl:text.#text: means, except in section 711 , the improvement district officer assigned responsibility for assessing land and improvements for the improvement district;
means, except in section 711, the improvement district officer assigned responsibility for collecting taxes for the improvement district;

means a single family dwelling manufactured as a unit, or in units, intended to be occupied in a place other than that of its manufacture, and designed so that it may be drawn or moved from place to place;
means land used or occupied by a person to provide spaces for the accommodation of 2 or more manufactured homes and for imposing a charge or rental for the use of the space;
, in relation to land, means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is entitled to possession of the land, or
has a substantial interest in the land;

bcl:text.in:desc: [tax sale notice to affected owners and charge holders]
bcl:text.#text: means a notice required under section 720 (1) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Giving notice to improvement districts
bcl:text: If an enactment requires or permits
the notice, service, filing or provision is effected if the notice or document is, as applicable, given, served on, filed with or provided to the improvement district corporate officer.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notice to be given to an improvement district or improvement district board,
a document to be served on an improvement district or improvement district board,
a document to be filed with an improvement district or improvement district board, or
a document to be delivered, sent, submitted or otherwise provided to an improvement district or improvement district board,

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Incorporation of improvement district: general rules

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by letters patent, incorporate an area of land comprising 2 or more parcels, whether contiguous or not, and its owners into an improvement district, under a name and with objects that appear advisable and with powers considered necessary to carry out those objects.
The letters patent for an improvement district may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide that some provisions of this Act do not apply to the improvement district and that other special provisions apply;

bcl:text.#text: provide that some provisions of the  do not apply to the improvement district and that other special provisions apply;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: divide the improvement district into zones, specify the number of trustees to be elected from each zone, provide for the election and method of election of trustees in any zone and provide for general meetings of landowners in each zone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) (a) does not apply in relation to the following sections of this Act and, to the extent that there is an inconsistency between a requirement under those sections and a provision of the letters patent for an improvement district, the requirement under the applicable section prevails and the provision of letters patent is of no force and effect:

bcl:text.#text: section 686 ;
section 690 ;
section 691 ;
section 692 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Incorporation of mountain resort improvement district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may recommend to the Lieutenant Governor in Council incorporation of a new mountain resort improvement district if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the establishment of the proposed improvement district has been approved by the board of the regional district in which the area of the proposed improvement district is located, and
the minister is satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: alpine ski lift operations, year-round recreational facilities and commercial overnight accommodation are offered within the area of the proposed improvement district, or

a person has entered into an agreement with the government with respect to developing alpine ski lift operations, year-round recreational facilities and commercial overnight accommodation within the area of the proposed improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the recommendation of the minister under subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by letters patent, incorporate an area of land outside a municipality and comprising 2 or more parcels, whether contiguous or not, and its owners into a mountain resort improvement district, under a name and with objects that appear advisable and with powers considered necessary to carry out those objects.
The letters patent for a mountain improvement district may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide that some provisions of this Act do not apply to the mountain resort improvement district and that other specified provisions apply;

bcl:text.#text: provide that some provisions of the  do not apply to the mountain resort improvement district and that other specified provisions apply;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: divide a mountain resort improvement district into zones, specify the number of trustees to be elected from each zone, and provide for the election and method of election of trustees in any zone.

bcl:text.#text: Section 698 (1) (b), (c) and (d)  does not apply to a mountain resort improvement district unless the letters patent provide otherwise.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notation on title of land in a mountain resort improvement district

bcl:text.in:desc: [incorporation of mountain resort municipality in accordance with improvement district letters patent]
bcl:text.#text: On the establishment of a mountain resort improvement district under section 676, parcels in the mountain resort improvement district are subject to section 8 (3)  without special endorsement on the indefeasible title.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar of land titles may, and on application of a mountain resort improvement district must, make the following notation on every indefeasible title of resort land issued on or after the establishment of the improvement district:

bcl:text.#text: An application under subsection (2) must contain a description of the resort land that is sufficient for the registrar to identify it in the records of the land title office and must be in the form approved under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of any delay, omission, mistake or misfeasance by the registrar of land titles or the registrar's employees in relation to making a notation under subsection (2),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar of land titles is not liable and neither the Provincial government nor the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia is liable vicariously,

bcl:text.#text: the assurance fund or the Land Title and Survey Authority of British Columbia as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 19.1 of the , and
the assurance fund or the minister charged with the administration of the  as a nominal defendant is not liable under Part 20 of the .

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: "This land is located in a mountain resort improvement district and is subject to the letters patent for that improvement district."

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissolution of water user's community or development district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If it appears to the Lieutenant Governor in Council that an improvement district, other than a mountain resort improvement district, will undertake the functions of an existing water users' community or development district, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may dissolve the water users' community or development district.

If it appears to the Lieutenant Governor in Council that a mountain resort improvement district will undertake the functions of an existing water users' community, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may dissolve the water users' community.
The power of dissolution conferred by subsection (1) or (2) may be exercised despite any other statute, special or otherwise.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may do one or more of the following, effective on the dissolution under this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: transfer to and vest in an improvement district any of the rights, property and assets of the water users' community or development district;
transfer to and declare as assumed by an improvement district any of the obligations of the water users' community or development district;

continue in force any bylaws or resolutions of the water users' community or development district as bylaws or resolutions of an improvement district applicable to the area of the improvement district to which they applied as bylaws or resolutions of the water users' community or development district until those bylaws or resolutions are amended or repealed by the improvement district board;
require the improvement district board to amend or repeal by a specified date a bylaw or resolution continued under paragraph (c);

deem a reference to the water users' community or development district in any commercial paper, lease, licence, permit or other contract, instrument or document to be a reference to the improvement district.

bcl:text.#text: In an order under subsection (1) or (2), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may specify deletions of and alterations in endorsements or entries made against any indefeasible or absolute title or other document deposited in a land title office or created under the  or any statute repealed by that Act.
Despite the  or any other statute, a registrar of land titles must make the deletions and alterations specified as referred to in subsection (5).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Amendment of letters patent and reissue of letters patent

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, authorize the minister to make orders amending letters patent for an improvement district, subject to any restrictions and conditions established by the regulation.

in:desc: [rights and liabilities not affected by revocation and reissue of letters patent]
bcl:text.#text: Sections 39  and 40  apply in respect of improvement districts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissolution of improvement district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, revoke the letters patent that incorporated or continued an improvement district.

If an improvement district is located in a municipality incorporated under section 3 (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council must exercise the power under subsection (1) of this section to revoke the letters patent for the improvement district no later than January 1 of the year that is 4 years after the year in which the municipality was incorporated.

If an improvement district is located in a mountain resort municipality incorporated under section 8 (4), the Lieutenant Governor in Council must exercise the power under subsection (1) of this section to revoke the letters patent for the improvement district effective at the time the mountain resort municipality is incorporated.
On the revocation of the letters patent that incorporated or continued an improvement district, the improvement district is dissolved.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition rules: dissolution, change in area, change in object

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an improvement district is dissolved or the letters patent for an improvement district are amended to reduce the area of the improvement district or to modify or repeal an object of the improvement district, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, do one or more of the following:

bcl:text.#text: If an order under subsection (1) (c) (i) provides for the establishment of a local area service, section 31 (3) to (7)  applies for the purposes of this section.
The requirement in section 13 (1) (a) and (b) of the  to first obtain the consent of a local government does not apply in relation to a service if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the service is continued under subsection (1) (c) of this section on dissolution of an improvement district, and
the service is to be provided by the municipality in an area outside the municipality to which the service was provided by the improvement district at the time the improvement district was dissolved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a municipality or regional district does not have the power to adopt a provision of a bylaw that is continued under subsection (1) (d) as a provision of a bylaw of the municipality or regional district, the municipality or regional district is deemed to have the power to adopt that provision of the bylaw until the earlier of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the repeal of that provision of the bylaw, and
the date specified under subsection (1) (f) in respect of that bylaw.
transfer to and vest in a municipality, a regional district or another improvement district any of the improvement district's rights, property and assets;
transfer to and declare as assumed by a municipality, a regional district or another improvement district any of the improvement district's obligations;
if all or part of the improvement district is located in a municipality,

bcl:text.#text: continue a service of the improvement district as a local area service of the municipality and exercise any power under section 31 (1) and (2)  that may be exercised by letters patent, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: continue a service of the improvement district as a service of the municipality;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: continue in force any bylaws or resolutions of the improvement district as bylaws or resolutions of a municipality, regional district or other improvement district that apply to the area of the municipality, regional district or other improvement district to which they applied as bylaws or resolutions of the originating improvement district until they are amended or repealed by the municipal council, regional district board or other improvement district board;
require the municipal council, regional district board or improvement district board to amend or repeal, by a specified date, a bylaw or resolution continued under paragraph (d);
specify a date for the purposes of subsection (4), which may not be more than 3 years after the date the bylaw is continued under paragraph (d) of this subsection;

deem a reference to the improvement district in any commercial paper, lease, licence, permit or other contract, instrument or document to be a reference to a municipality, a regional district or another improvement district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional letters patent and order powers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite this or any other Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by letters patent or by order, do one or more of the following in relation to the incorporation of an improvement district, the extension or reduction of the area of an improvement district or the addition, modification or repeal of an object of an improvement district:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose requirements on the improvement district;
restrict the powers of the improvement district;
make provisions the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers appropriate for the purpose of preventing, minimizing or otherwise addressing any transitional difficulties;
in respect of a provision included in the letters patent or order under paragraphs (a) to (c), provide an exception to or a modification of a requirement or condition established by an enactment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite this or any other Act, letters patent for an improvement district or an order of the Lieutenant Governor in Council under this Part may establish any terms and conditions the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers appropriate in respect of any matter related to the letters patent or order.
As a restriction, in exercising a power under this section, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may not override an absolute prohibition contained in an enactment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Improvement district board of trustees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The powers of an improvement district are to be exercised and its property is to be managed by a board of trustees consisting of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: trustees elected by the persons entitled to vote as provided in the letters patent, or
if no provision is made for the election of trustees in the letters patent, trustees elected by the owners of land in the improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint the first trustees of an improvement district, or may appoint a person to conduct the first election of trustees.

Except as otherwise provided in the letters patent and except as to trustees elected to fill vacancies resulting from death, resignation or disqualification, the term of office of a trustee continues until the date of the improvement district election that is held in the third calendar year following the calendar year in which the trustee was elected or appointed.
A majority of the trustees constitutes a quorum.
Whenever the trustees in office do not constitute a quorum, the inspector may make provision at the expense of the improvement district for an election to fill the vacancy among the trustees.

If a vacancy referred to in subsection (5) is not filled by the election under that subsection, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint a person the Lieutenant Governor in Council thinks proper to fill the vacancy, and it is not necessary for the person to be an owner of land in the improvement district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Election of improvement district trustees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to vote at an election for improvement district trustees, a person must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a Canadian citizen,
18 years of age or older, and

bcl:text.#text: entitled to be registered as a voter under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Improvement district elections may be held at the annual general meetings of the improvement districts or otherwise, and the voting may be done by secret ballot or otherwise.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, prescribe the procedure to be followed in conducting any election for improvement district trustees.

A person who is qualified to vote at an improvement district election and who voted or applied to vote in the election may appeal to the Supreme Court against the order of the presiding officer accepting or rejecting a vote or ballot or the result of the election.
An appeal under subsection (4) must be made in writing within 2 weeks after the election.

On an appeal under subsection (4), after the hearing or investigation the court believes proper, it may confirm or amend the order appealed against or may declare the election of no effect and order a new election, establishing the date, time, place and conditions.
An election must not be set aside because of an innocent irregularity, unless the court is satisfied that the irregularity affected the result of the election.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Chair of improvement district board

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the letters patent, the trustees must elect one of their number as chair at the first meeting in each year and at the first meeting after a vacancy occurs in the office.
The chair must preside at meetings of the improvement district board.
The chair has a vote, and a question on which there is an equality of votes is deemed to be defeated.
If the chair is absent from a meeting, the members present must appoint one of their number to act as chair.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Meeting procedure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board must, by bylaw, do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish the procedures that are to be followed for the calling of meetings of the board and for the conduct of its business, including the manner by which resolutions may be passed and bylaws adopted;
establish the procedures that are to be followed in calling and conducting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: meetings of select and standing committees of the board,

bcl:text.#text: meetings referred to in section 690 , and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: meetings of any other committee composed solely of trustees of the improvement district acting in that capacity;

in:desc: [regulations for public access to board meetings]
bcl:text.#text: establish the procedures for giving advance public notice respecting the date, time and place of meetings referred to in section 690  and any other meetings required to be open to the public by a regulation under section 687 (a) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The inspector or the chair of the improvement board may call a meeting of the trustees for any purpose, and the chair must do so when requested in writing by the inspector or by a majority of the trustees.
The chair or the corporate officer must give notice to each trustee of each meeting of the improvement district board in accordance with the procedures established by bylaw under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations in relation to improvement district meetings
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

in:desc: [minutes of board meetings and committee meetings]
bcl:text.#text: making the provisions of section 223  of this Act, Division 3  of Part 4 of the  and sections 133  and 282 (2) (c)  of the , as applicable, apply in relation to meetings of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: improvement district boards,
select and standing committees of improvement district boards, and
any other body established by an improvement district board;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: excluding a body under paragraph (a) (iii) from the application of one or more of the provisions referred to in paragraph (a);
modifying any of the provisions referred to in paragraph (a) in relation to bodies referred to in that paragraph;

bcl:text.#text: making section 223 (2)  applicable to meetings referred to in section 690  and modifying any of the provisions of section 223 (2) in relation to those meetings;

requiring that the minutes of a board meeting, or a part of a board meeting, that is not closed under section 90 of the , as that section may be made to apply by regulation under paragraph (a) of this section, be made available for public inspection.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: First meeting of board in each year

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the letters patent, the first meeting in each year of an improvement district board must be held after, but not later than 30 days after,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date in the year on which the annual general meeting of the district, or
the last general meeting of a zone of it has been held.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The time and place of the first meeting in each year must be set

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the corporate officer,
by a majority of the trustees, or
in the case of the first meeting of the improvement district board after incorporation, by the official responsible for conducting the first election.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of select and standing committees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board may appoint a select committee to consider or inquire into any matter and report its findings and opinion to the board.
An improvement district board may establish standing committees for matters the board considers would be better dealt with by committee and may appoint persons to those committees.
Subject to subsection (4), persons who are not trustees may be appointed to select and standing committees.
At least one member of each select and standing committee must be a trustee.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual general meeting

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At least once in every calendar year, an improvement district board must call an annual general meeting of the owners of land in the improvement district at which it presents the audited financial statements for the preceding calendar year.
The annual general meeting must be open to the public.

bcl:text.#text: At least 14 days before the annual general meeting, the improvement district board must give advance public notice of the date, time and place of the meeting in accordance with the procedures established by bylaw under section 686 (1) (c) .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Annual financial statements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The fiscal year for an improvement district is the calendar year.
Improvement district financial statements for a fiscal year must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepared by the financial officer, and
presented to the improvement district board for its acceptance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), the financial statements must be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles for local governments.

The inspector may require or authorize, generally or for a specified improvement district, that the financial statements vary from or include additional information to the requirements of subsection (3).

By May 15 in each year, the improvement district board must submit to the inspector the audited financial statements of the improvement district for the preceding year and any other financial information required by the inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of auditor

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board must appoint an auditor for the improvement district.

bcl:text.#text: Sections 169  and 171  of the  apply to a person appointed under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Officers and employees

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The improvement district board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide for the appointment of officers and other employees for the improvement district, and

bcl:text.#text: subject to the  and the , establish the terms and conditions of their employment, including terms and conditions respecting their remuneration, benefits, expenses, hours of work and manner of appointment, promotion, discipline and dismissal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the event of a conflict between terms and conditions of employment established by bylaw, resolution or policy and those established by contract of employment or collective agreement, the contract or agreement prevails.

Subject to a contract of employment and subject to providing the officer with an opportunity to be heard, the appointment of an improvement district officer may be terminated by the improvement district board as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of termination for cause, by immediate termination without any period of notice;
in any other case, by termination on reasonable notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A termination under subsection (3) (b) may be made only by the affirmative vote of at least 2/3 of all trustees.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Officer positions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The improvement district board

bcl:text.#text: must, by bylaw, establish officer positions in relation to the duties under sections 695  and 696 , with titles the board considers appropriate,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may, by bylaw, establish other officer positions for the improvement district, with titles the board considers appropriate, and
may, by bylaw or resolution, assign powers, duties and functions to those officer positions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the improvement district board may assign to an officer position powers, duties and functions in addition to those required or permitted to be assigned under this Act or another enactment, and
the same person may be appointed to 2 or more officer positions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Words in an enactment referring to an improvement district officer, by name of office or otherwise, also apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the officer's deputy, and
any person designated by the improvement district board to act in the officer's place.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Corporate administration
bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 694 must be assigned the responsibility of corporate administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring that accurate minutes of the meetings of the improvement district board and its committees are prepared and that the minutes, bylaws and other records of the business of the board and its committees are maintained and kept safe;
ensuring that access is provided to records of the improvement district board and its committees, as required by law or authorized by the board;
signing and certifying copies of bylaws and other documents, as required or requested;

accepting, on behalf of the improvement district or the improvement district board, notices and documents that are required or permitted to be given, served on, filed with or otherwise provided to the improvement district or board;
keeping the improvement district's seal and having it affixed to documents as required.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Financial administration
bcl:section.bcl:text: One of the officer positions established under section 694 must be assigned the responsibility of financial administration, which includes the following powers, duties and functions:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receiving all money paid to the improvement district;
ensuring the keeping of all funds and securities of the improvement district;
expending and disbursing money in the manner authorized by the improvement district board;

bcl:text.#text: investing funds, until required, in investments under section 697 (4) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring that accurate records and full accounts of the financial affairs of the improvement district are prepared, maintained and kept safe;
compiling and supplying information on the financial affairs of the improvement district required by the inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General powers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district is a corporation and has all powers necessary or useful in carrying out its objects.
Without limiting subsection (1), an improvement district may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: acquire, hold and dispose of land and other property, and charges on and interest in land and other property;
borrow money and issue bonds, debentures, mortgages and other securities;
settle claims;
assess land and improvements, levy and collect taxes, tolls and other charges and recover them by suit, by distress or by sale of the assessed land;
construct, repair, improve, manage, maintain and operate works of any kind;
regulate the distribution of water, electricity or any other thing or service provided or conveyed by the improvement district;
make agreements;
anything incidental to the things referred to in paragraphs (a) to (g) or necessary to carry out its objects.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All contracts that, if made between natural persons, would have to be made in writing must be made under the district's seal.

bcl:text.#text: Money held by an improvement district that is not immediately required may be invested or reinvested by the improvement district board in investments referred to in section 183  of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers that must be exercised by bylaw

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board may make bylaws for one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: entering into a contract about land or works;
borrowing by way of loan, temporary or otherwise, from a bank or from any person, amounts the board considers necessary;
executing cheques, promissory notes or other instruments that may be necessary or desirable for the purpose referred to in paragraph (b);
borrowing money by the issue and sale of notes, bonds, debentures and other securities in principal amounts the board considers necessary;
establishing tolls and other charges, including charges for capital expenditures, payable to the improvement district, and the times of their payment;
establishing discounts or percentage additions to encourage the prompt payment of tolls and charges under paragraph (e);
establishing the manner in which interest is calculated if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: this or another Act provides a requirement or authority to apply interest to an amount owed to, or owing by, the improvement district, and
the manner in which interest is calculated is not otherwise provided for;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing the basis of assessment of the land and the value of land and improvements in the district;
establishing the method to be followed by the assessor in classifying land in the district for assessment purposes;
regulating the distribution and use of water, power or any other thing or service made available;
regulating and requiring the provision of works and services in respect of the subdivision of land;
in relation to manufactured home parks,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: establishing a charge for fire protection for each space occupied by a manufactured home in a manufactured home park, payable by the person in charge of or operating the park,
establishing the time of payment of the charge, and
authorizing inspection by the improvement district of a manufactured home park and the records of the operator of the park;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing penalties for failure to comply with bylaws of the improvement district board;
establishing a reserve fund for one or more capital purposes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Securities under subsection (1) (d)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be in a form, may bear interest at a rate and may be made payable as to principal and interest at the time, in the manner, at the place and in the currency the improvement district board considers expedient, and
may be made redeemable in advance of maturity at the time and at the price the board, by bylaw, determines at the time of issue.

bcl:text.#text: Section 716  and Division 6  apply to the collection of charges imposed under subsection (1) (l) of this section, and the money owing for the charges is deemed to be taxes recoverable under Division 6.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The powers referred to in subsection (1) may be exercised only by bylaw, but all other powers of the improvement district may be exercised by the improvement district board by resolution.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Process and registration requirements for bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw of an improvement district must be signed by the corporate officer and the person presiding at the meeting at which the bylaw is passed.
Subject to a regulation under subsection (4), an improvement district bylaw is effective only on registration with the inspector.

For an improvement district bylaw that requires registration under subsection (2), the inspector may register or refuse to register it, or take any other action the inspector considers is in the interest of the improvement district or the Provincial government.
The minister may, by regulation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide exemptions from the registration requirement under subsection (2), and
provide that an exemption under paragraph (a) is or may be made subject to the terms and conditions specified by the minister or the inspector.

bcl:text.#text: Section 136  of the  applies to bylaws that are exempt from the registration requirement under subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:text.in:desc: [evidence of municipal bylaws and other records]
bcl:text.#text: Section 163  of the  applies to improvement districts.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Subdivision servicing requirements

bcl:text.in:desc: [works and services in respect of subdivision of land]
bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of section 698 (1) (k) , the improvement district board may, by bylaw, require that, within the applicable subdivision, one or more of the following be provided, located and constructed in accordance with the standards established in the bylaw:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a water distribution system;
a fire hydrant system;
a sewage collection system;
a sewage disposal system;
a drainage collection system;
a drainage disposal system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may be different in relation to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: different circumstances;
different areas;
different land uses;
different zones.

bcl:text.#text: An improvement district must not impose a requirement under subsection (1) in respect of a subdivision under the .

bcl:text: In addition to the authority under subsection (1), as a condition of

an improvement district board may require that the owner of the land provide works and services, in accordance with the standards established in a bylaw under this section, on the portion of a highway that is immediately adjacent to the site being subdivided or developed, up to the centre line of the highway.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the approval of a subdivision, or
the issuance of a building permit if an agreement under subsection (8) applies,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the authority under subsection (1), if an agreement under subsection (8) applies, as a condition of the issuance of a building permit, an improvement district board may require that the owner of the land provide, on the site being developed, works and services in accordance with the standards established in a bylaw under this section.
Requirements under subsections (4) and (5)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be made only to the extent that they are directly attributable to the subdivision or development, and

bcl:text.in:desc: [bylaw establishing charges payable to improvement district]
bcl:text.#text: must not include specific services that are included in the calculations used to determine the amount of a capital expenditure charge under section 698 (1) (e) , unless the owner agrees to provide the services.
If the owner agrees to provide the services referred to in subsection (6) (b), section 565 (2) (a)  applies to the calculation of the capital expenditure charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board and a local government may enter into an agreement under which the local government may refuse to issue building permits in accordance with this section.
The authority to require works and services under this section is limited to works and services that are within the objects of the improvement district as described in its letters patent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements for excess or extended services

bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of this section and section 702 :
means a portion of a water, sewage or drainage system that will serve land other than the land being subdivided or developed;
means an owner as defined in the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board may require that the owner of land that is to be subdivided or developed provide excess or extended services.
If an improvement district board makes a requirement under subsection (2), the cost of providing the excess or extended services must be paid for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by the improvement district, or
if the improvement district board considers its costs to provide all or part of these services to be excessive, by the owner of the land being subdivided or developed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Latecomer charges and cost recovery for excess or extended services

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the owner is required under section 701 (3) (b) to pay all or part of the costs of excess or extended services, the improvement district must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determine the proportion of the cost of providing the water, sewage or drainage facilities that it considers constitutes the excess or extended services,
determine which part of the excess or extended service that it considers will benefit each of the parcels of land that will be served by the excess or extended services, and
impose, as a condition of an owner connecting to or using the excess or extended services, a charge related to the benefit determined under paragraph (b) of this subsection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the owner pays all or part of the costs of excess or extended services, the improvement district must pay the owner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the latecomer charges collected under subsection (1) (c), if the owner pays all the costs, or
a corresponding proportion of all charges collected, if the owner pays a portion of the costs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the improvement district pays all or part of the costs of excess or extended services, it may recover costs by a latecomer charge under subsection (1) (c).

A latecomer charge must include interest calculated annually at a rate established by bylaw, payable for the period beginning when the excess or extended services were completed, up to the date that the connection is made or the use begins.
Subject to subsection (6), latecomer charges must be collected during the period beginning when the excess or extended services are completed, up to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a date to be agreed on by the owner and the improvement district board, or

bcl:text.#text: if there is no agreement, a date determined under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No latecomer charges are payable beyond 15 years from the date the services are completed.

in:desc: [works and services in respect of subdivision of land]
bcl:text.#text: If an owner, in accordance with a bylaw under section 698 (1) (k)  or 700 , provides water, sewage or drainage facilities that serve land other than the land being subdivided or developed, this section applies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to exercise rights under certain water licences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the objects of an improvement district include the operation of irrigation works, the right to divert, store and carry water granted under any licence for irrigation purposes appurtenant to land inside the improvement district is exercisable only by the improvement district or its assignees.
An improvement district referred to in subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has the sole right to the use of all works for diverting, storing and carrying water authorized, constructed, maintained or used under the licence, whether they are inside the territorial limits or not, and
may, without reference to the precedence of licences, distribute the water to any land inside the territorial limits.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsections (1) and (2) apply to licences for domestic or waterworks purposes if the objects of the improvement district include the operation of works for waterworks purposes.
When an improvement district is dissolved, the rights granted under the licences appurtenant to the land within the territorial limits are again exercisable by the respective owners of the land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to expropriate water diversion licences and related works

bcl:text.#text: In addition to the rights conferred on licensees under sections 32 and 33 of the , an improvement district whose objects include the operation of works for waterworks purposes may expropriate

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licence authorizing the diversion of water from a stream or an aquifer that is suitable for a water supply for the improvement district, and
any work constructed or used under authority of the licence and any real property required for the operation, maintenance and protection of the work.

bcl:text.#text: If an improvement district exercises a power under subsection (1) that does not constitute an expropriation within the meaning of the , compensation as determined by the Supreme Court is payable for any loss or damages caused by the exercise of the power.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: has the same meaning as in the ;
has the same meaning as in the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General power to expropriate land and works

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district may expropriate land or works, or both, reasonably required to carry out its objects.
The interest of a person in works located on Crown land, including works on highways, may be expropriated if the Lieutenant Governor in Council has consented to the expropriation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Renewal of works and related reserve funds

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district must make adequate provision in advance to renew works when they require renewal, and must raise amounts for that purpose.

The improvement district board must establish reserve funds for the purpose of renewal of works referred to in subsection (1), and amounts raised as required under that subsection must be credited to the applicable reserve fund.
Money in a reserve fund, and interest earned on it, must be used only for the purpose for which the reserve fund was established.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal if improvement district refuses to provide services

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district has no obligation to convey or supply water or electricity or to provide any service to any person, land or premises.

Despite subsection (1), a person to whom an improvement district refuses to convey or supply water or electricity, or to provide a service, may appeal to the inspector, who may make any order in the matter that the inspector considers just and reasonable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparation of assessment roll

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The improvement district board may direct the assessor to prepare an assessment roll.

The improvement district board must determine the basis of assessment, which may be by parcel, group of parcels, area or value of land or improvements or personal property, or any combination of them.
Complete or partial exemption may be allowed for any of the bases of assessment or any kind or class of any of those bases.
If areas are made a basis of assessment, the land may be classified into grades by any method of classification determined by the improvement district board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of assessment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The assessor must assess every parcel of land or group of parcels in the name of the registered owner who appears entitled to possession of the land.
After preparing an assessment roll, the assessor must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mail an assessment notice to every assessed owner, showing the assessment of the owner's land and, if applicable, the assessment of the owner's improvements and personal property, and
send an assessment notice to every holder of a registered charge on land who requests this in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The assessment notice must state the date of the first meeting of the court of revision under section 710, which must not be earlier than 2 weeks after the sending of the notice.
The obligation to send an assessment notice under subsection (2) is satisfied if the assessor made a reasonable effort to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Court of revision for assessments

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The improvement district board must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appoint 3 board members or other persons to constitute the court of revision, and
provide for the revision of an assessment roll by the court of revision and for the consideration of all complaints about assessment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any person having an interest in assessed land may file with the court of revision a complaint about the assessment of the person's land or other assessed land.
The court of revision must consider the complaints filed and may ratify or amend an assessment.
On completion of the revision, the court of revision must confirm the assessment roll.

Within 2 weeks after notice of the determination of a complaint by the court of revision, a person may appeal to the inspector, who may, after the investigation that the inspector considers proper, ratify or amend the assessment.
