The assessment roll as confirmed by the court of revision and, if applicable, as amended by the inspector is valid and binding on all persons concerned, despite an omission, defect or error in it or in any assessment notice or the failure to send an assessment notice.
An assessment roll referred to in subsection (6) remains in effect until a new roll has been prepared, revised and confirmed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax collection on behalf of improvement district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to improvement districts whose objects include one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fire protection;
street lighting;
financial aid to hospitals;
acquisition of property for hospitals;
ambulance service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the improvement district is located wholly in one or more municipalities, the council of each municipality must levy and collect all taxes that may be levied on real property in the municipality by the improvement district for the objects referred to in subsection (1).
If the improvement district is located wholly in a rural area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the assessor of the assessment district in which all or the greater portion of the improvement district is located must advise the collector of each collection district in which any part of the improvement district is located of the amount of money required to be levied by the collector and the applicable rates, and

bcl:text.#text: the collector must levy the amount according to the basis of assessment established by the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the improvement district is located wholly or partly in a rural area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the consent of the Minister of Finance, the improvement district board may, on or before November 30 in each year, provide to the assessor of the assessment district in which all or the greater portion of the improvement district is located a statement showing the amount of money required by the improvement district for the objects referred to in subsection (1) for the following year, and

bcl:text.#text: on receipt of a statement under paragraph (a), the assessor must promptly apportion to the municipalities and rural area in the improvement district, according to the basis of assessment established by the ,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount shown on the statement, and
an amount estimated for the cost of assessment and collection, interest on money paid in advance of collection, and losses through failure to collect.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the improvement district includes a municipality and rural area,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the assessor of the assessment district in which all of or the greater portion of the rural area is located must advise the improvement district board, the council of the municipality and the collector of each collection district in which any part of the improvement district is located of the amount of money required to be levied and the applicable rates for each of the component areas of the improvement district, and

bcl:text.#text: the council of the municipality and the collector must levy that amount in their respective jurisdictions according to the basis of assessment established by the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount to be raised within a municipality for improvement district purposes must be paid, on or before September 30 of the year in which the amount was levied, by the municipality to the improvement district, which must without delay pay the amount to the Minister of Finance.

If the Minister of Finance considers the amount of money required by the improvement district under this section too large to be levied in one year, that minister may authorize that the amount be levied over a number of years and in the manner that minister considers appropriate.

The Minister of Finance may advance to the improvement district from the consolidated revenue fund amounts requisitioned by the improvement district in respect of the taxes before they are levied or collected.
Except as to the basis of assessment provided in subsections (3) to (8),

bcl:text.#text: the  applies to the assessment, levy, collection and recovery of all taxes imposed under those subsections on land and improvements in rural areas and to the addition of interest,
those taxes, when assessed and levied, are deemed to be taxes imposed and assessed under the , and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proceeds of those taxes must be paid by the Minister of Finance to the improvement district, less an amount that that minister considers should be retained to cover

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: interest on any money paid in advance of collection, and
the annual amount required in repayment of any advance that has been made by that minister.

bcl:text.#text: Sections 709  and 710  do not apply to any taxes imposed, assessed or levied under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipal collection of improvement district taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all or part of a municipality is located in the area of an improvement district, and
the objects of the improvement district include the provision of fire protection or street lighting.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any Act, the council of the municipality must impose and collect all taxes imposable by the improvement district on real property in the municipality.
The improvement district board must notify the council of the municipality of the amount to be raised for improvement district purposes in the municipality for the current year.

The Surveyor of Taxes must advise the council of the applicable rates for improvement district purposes, based on the net taxable value of land and improvements but excluding property that is taxable for school purposes only by special Act, to be applied throughout the area of the improvement district.

bcl:text.#text: The council must, under section 197 (1) (b)  of the , incorporate the rates provided under subsection (4) of this section.
For the purposes of subsection (4) and section 713 (2) and (3) ,
the definition of "improvements" in the  applies, and
the exemptions in sections 129 to 131.01  of the  apply.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Payments to improvement district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On demand, the council must pay to the improvement district board the amount to be raised in the municipality for improvement district purposes.

The improvement district board may ask the council of the municipality to advance the amounts necessary to meet the current authorized obligations of the improvement district and the council may advance those amounts, but only on evidence of the money being needed for operations and obligations of the board.

bcl:text: As a limit on subsection (2), the total of the advances that may be made under that subsection must be according to the ratio that
bears to
according to the revised assessment rolls on which the tax will be imposed.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the net taxable value of land and improvements of the property in the municipality that is in the improvement district, excluding property that is taxable for school purposes only by special Act,
the net taxable value of land and improvements of the property in the improvement district as a whole, excluding property that is taxable for school purposes only by special Act,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The improvement district board must pay to the Minister of Finance, promptly on receipt, money received from the municipality that represents a share of advances made by the Minister of Finance on behalf of land and improvements in the municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax levy by improvement district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district board may, by bylaw, levy taxes to raise the funds considered necessary to meet the obligations of the improvement district and to carry out its objects.

Taxes under subsection (1) may be established on the basis of parcels, groups of parcels, values or areas, or any combination of them, and different rates of tax may be established for different grades or classes of land and improvements.
A bylaw under subsection (1) may establish the minimum amount of taxes payable for a parcel or group of parcels and may provide for discounts or percentage additions to encourage prompt payment.
Unless otherwise provided, a tax is deemed to have been levied and is owing on and from January 1 of the year for which the tax is levied.

A person whose name appears on the assessment roll of an improvement district in any year as the owner of any land is liable to the improvement district for the taxes levied by the improvement district board for that year for that land.

If the improvement district board levies a tax on the basis of values as referred to in subsection (2), it must adopt a variable tax rate system under which rates are separately determined and imposed for each property class.

bcl:text.#text: Section 199  of the  applies to a variable tax rate system under this section and, for these purposes, a reference to a municipality in that section is to be read as a reference to an improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tax bylaw or tax must not be questioned on the ground that the rate of the tax exceeds what is required for the purposes for which taxes may be levied.

bcl:text.#text: Any action in which the validity of a tax bylaw is questioned must be commenced within one month after registration of the bylaw under section 699 .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax notices

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As soon as practicable after a tax bylaw comes into force, the improvement district board must have sent to every registered owner of assessed land a tax notice that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: shows the amount of taxes owing by the assessed owner to the improvement district, and
provides sufficient information on assessment and the rates of tax to show how the taxes are computed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The obligation to send a notice under subsection (1) is satisfied if a reasonable effort was made to mail or otherwise deliver the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Lien for taxes and tolls

bcl:text: Despite any other enactment,
forms a lien and charge on the land on which it has been imposed, levied, accrued or established.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: every assessment made,
every tax imposed or levied, accrued or to accrue on any land, and
every toll or charge established under a bylaw of an improvement district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A lien and charge referred to in subsection (1) has preference over any claim, lien, privileges or encumbrance of any person, except the Crown and municipal taxes previously accrued, and does not require registration to preserve it.

If it is necessary or advisable to protect or enforce a lien referred to in subsection (1) by action or proceeding, this may be done by order of any court of competent jurisdiction, on application and on the notice that the court directs.

A lien referred to in subsection (1) constitutes a lien and charge on the whole parcel of land affected, even though the tax, toll or charge forming the lien may have been imposed, levied, established or calculated on a part only, or on improvements of any kind or class.

If a parcel of land on which there are taxes owing to an improvement district is subdivided, the collector may apportion the taxes among the separate parts of the parcel and their owners as nearly as possible in conformity with the classification of the land comprising the parts at the time the taxes were levied.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interest on taxes

bcl:text.#text: The taxes payable to an improvement district bear interest at the rate prescribed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under section 11 (3) of the  from the March 1 next following the date on which they are levied, until paid or recovered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The interest under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is from day to day deemed part of the taxes, and a reference to taxes is deemed to include all interest so added, and
is to the same extent as the taxes a lien and charge.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax sale for recovery of taxes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to all other remedies for the recovery of taxes, including percentage additions and interest, an improvement district

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may hold a tax sale for the sale at public auction of all the land on which there are taxes owing to the improvement district for 24 months or longer at the date of the sale, and
must hold such a tax sale at least once in each year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The improvement district board must set the date, time and place of the tax sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board powers in relation to tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In order to cover the expenses connected with a tax sale, the improvement district board may, by bylaw, establish amounts to be charged under subsection (2).
The collector must charge against each parcel proposed to be sold at the tax sale the amount set under subsection (1).

Notice, publication or advertisement of the tax sale, other than that required under section 720, is not necessary, but the improvement district board may direct the advertisement of a tax sale as it considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax sale notice to affected owners and charge holders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At least 60 days before the date set for the tax sale, the collector must give written notice to the following, either by serving the notice or by sending it by registered mail,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to each registered owner of a parcel proposed to be sold, and
to the holder of any registered charge on the parcel.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tax sale notice must include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time and place set for the tax sale;
a short description of the land for which the taxes are owing;
the amount of all taxes owing to the improvement district on the land and the amount of interest to the date of the tax sale;

bcl:text.#text: the amounts chargeable as expenses connected with the tax sale, including any applicable fee under the  for issuance and registration of a tax sale deed;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the upset price of the land for the purpose of the tax sale, being the total of the taxes, interest, expenses and fee;

a statement that, if the amounts of taxes, interest and expenses are not paid before the tax sale, the collector will offer the land for sale by public auction at the time and place stated in the notice;
a statement that the proposed tax sale of the land will be an absolute sale and that no right of redemption will remain in the owner or holder of the charge after the sale.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application, the Supreme Court may order that a tax sale notice may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
The collector must retain a copy of each tax sale notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Conduct of tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The collector must conduct the tax sale in accordance with the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the day and at the hour and place set for the tax sale, if the amounts of taxes, interest and expenses for land described in a tax sale notice have not been paid, the collector must offer that land separately for sale at the upset price stated in the notice, and may sell it to the highest bidder;
if there is a bid of the upset price, but no higher bid, the person bidding the upset price must be declared the purchaser;
the collector may adjourn the tax sale from day to day or for a period not exceeding 7 days at any one adjournment until all the land is sold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the purchaser of a parcel of land at a tax sale fails to pay immediately to the improvement district the amount of the purchase money, the collector must without delay offer the parcel for sale again.
If a parcel of land is offered for sale at the tax sale and there is no bid, or no bid equal to or greater than the upset price, the improvement district must be declared the purchaser.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Authority to register tax sale title

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the time of paying to the collector the purchase price of land sold at a tax sale, the purchaser or an agent of the purchaser must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sign a copy of the tax sale notice relating to that land, and
state on the copy the full name, occupation and postal address of the purchaser.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The signed copy of the tax sale notice under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be preserved by the collector with all the other records connected with the tax sale, and
on the execution under section 723 of a deed of the land sold, is deemed to constitute the collector or the collector's successor in office as the duly authorized agent to apply

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on behalf of the purchaser for registration of the purchaser's title to the land, or
in case of the purchaser's death, on behalf of the purchaser's personal representative for registration of the representative's title to the land.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registration of tax sale purchaser as owner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Promptly after a tax sale, the collector must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: execute a deed of each parcel sold by the collector at the tax sale to the purchaser or, in case of the death of the purchaser, to the personal representative of the purchaser, and

bcl:text.#text: forward the deed to the registrar of land titles, together with any applicable fee under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receipt of a tax sale deed under subsection (1) and any applicable fee, the registrar of land titles must register indefeasible title to the land in the name of the purchaser or the personal representative, subject to Provincial taxes owing on the land.
The registration of the improvement district or any other person as the owner of land under a tax sale deed executed under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancels registration of the indefeasible or absolute title of that land and any duplicate indefeasible title or absolute certificate of title outstanding for that land, and

disencumbers the land of all interest of every previous owner or of those claiming under a previous owner, and of all claims, demands, payments, charges, liens, judgments, mortgages and encumbrances of every nature and kind, other than

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the restrictive conditions, reservations and exceptions subject to which the land was held at the time of the tax sale, and
existing liens of the Crown or of the municipality in which the land is located.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In a court proceeding, a deed purporting to be issued for a sale of land for unpaid taxes, and purporting to be executed under this Act, is evidence that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the deed is the tax sale deed that it purports to be,
the sale alleged in the deed was conducted in a fair and open manner, and
there were taxes due and in arrear on the land described in the deed at the time of the sale for which it could be sold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the end of one year after the date on which the application is made to register in the purchaser the title of land sold at a tax sale, an action must not be brought, to recover the land or to set aside the sale of the land, against

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar of land titles, the improvement district, the improvement district trustees or the collector for the sale of the land or registration of an indefeasible title to it, or
except as provided in this section, against the improvement district, the improvement district trustees or the collector for any loss sustained because the land was sold.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who at the time of sale was the registered owner of the land sold, or the personal representative or assignee of that person, or a person who at the time of sale was the holder of a registered interest in or charge on the land, must be indemnified by the improvement district for loss sustained by the person because of the sale of the land if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the land was not liable to taxation by the improvement district during the period for which the taxes were levied on the land sold,
the taxes for which the land was sold had been paid, or

bcl:text.#text: notice of the intention to sell or offer the land for sale was not given in substantial compliance with section 720 (1) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A proceeding to recover indemnity under subsection (6) must be commenced within one year after the date on which the application is made to register the title of the land in the purchaser.
Despite subsection (6), there is no right to indemnity under that subsection if it is shown that the person claiming indemnity

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: was aware at any time that the land was liable to be sold or offered for sale, or
was aware at the time of the tax sale that the land was advertised or offered for sale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of surplus from tax sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, if a parcel of land offered for sale at the tax sale sells for more than the upset price, on written request the surplus must be paid without interest to the registered owner or the personal representative of the registered owner.

The money must not be paid under subsection (1) if a claim to the surplus is made by another person on the ground that the land belonged to the other person or that the other person is otherwise entitled to the surplus.
If a claim referred to in subsection (2) is made, the surplus must be paid, without leave or order, into the Supreme Court, accompanied by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the tax sale notice, and
a statement of the collector setting out

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the facts under which the payment into court is made, and
the names of the registered owner and the claimant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Money paid into court under subsection (3) is payable out of court to the person entitled on the order of the court to be made on application in a summary manner and subject to the giving of notice as the court directs.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax sale of Crown land held under a mortgage or agreement for sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, this Division applies to land in respect of which taxes are in arrear if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fee simple of the land is in the Provincial or federal government, and
the land is held under a mortgage to or agreement for sale from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Provincial or federal government,
a minister of the Provincial or federal government, or
a board or corporation holding or having charge of the administration of the land on behalf of the Provincial or federal government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At a tax sale, the land must be sold subject to the interest of the Provincial or federal government and the collector must state at the time of sale that the interest of the Provincial or federal government is prior to all claims and is not affected by the sale.

The Provincial or federal government may accept the tax sale purchaser as mortgagor or purchaser of the land and may deal with that purchaser to the exclusion of the person whose interest was sold at the tax sale and of all persons claiming under that person.
If the Provincial or federal government accepts the tax sale purchaser as mortgagor or purchaser, that government must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify the improvement district board of this, and
notify the registrar of land titles if the mortgage or agreement for sale is registered in the land title office.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The purchaser is entitled to a refund from the improvement district of the amount the purchaser paid, together with interest at the rate prescribed under subsection (6), if the Provincial or federal government, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not accept the tax sale purchaser as mortgagor or purchaser, or
does not, within 6 months after the date of sale, notify the improvement district board that the government has accepted the purchaser.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe a rate of interest for the purposes of subsection (5).

If a refund is made under subsection (5), the collector must promptly replace on the tax roll, as taxes in arrear, the amount of the taxes, interest, costs and expenses, together with the interest paid to the purchaser under that subsection.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Disposal of tax sale land by improvement district board

bcl:text.in:desc: [registration of tax sale purchaser as owner]
bcl:text.#text: The improvement district board may lease, sell or otherwise dispose of land of which the improvement district has been registered as owner under section 723  in the manner and on the terms it sees fit, and may apply the proceeds of sale for any purpose for which taxes that may be levied by the improvement district board under this Act may be applied.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provision of sinking funds

bcl:text.#text: If a bylaw of an improvement district provides for a sinking fund, the improvement district must pay the instalments of the sinking fund to the Minister of Finance, who must invest them in investments permitted for a trust fund under section 40 (4) of the.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Provincial guarantee of improvement district securities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, on terms and in the manner and form the Lieutenant Governor in Council determines, guarantee the payment of principal and interest of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notes, bonds, debentures or other securities authorized to be issued under this Act by an improvement district for any purpose of the improvement district, and
loans, temporary or otherwise, authorized to be raised under this Act by an improvement district for any purpose of the improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the purposes of an improvement district include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the acquisition, construction, reconstruction, replacement, improvement and extension of works for diverting, storing and conveying water for domestic use and irrigation of land;
the disposal of sewage;
the provision of fire protection;
the provision of street lighting;
the granting of financial aid toward the planning, constructing, reconstructing, purchasing, equipping or operating of a hospital, or the acquiring of land or buildings for those hospital purposes;
the repayment of advances by the Provincial government to the improvement district;
the repayment, refunding or renewal of all or part of a loan raised or securities issued by the improvement district;
the payment of all or a part of any loan, liability or bonds, debentures or other securities, payment of which is guaranteed or assumed by the improvement district;
the payment of any other liability or debt of the improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A guarantee given under subsection (1) must be signed by the Minister of Finance, or by another officer of the Ministry of Finance designated by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

On the guarantee being signed in accordance with subsection (3), the Provincial government is liable to pay the principal and interest of the notes, bonds, debentures, securities and loans guaranteed, according to their tenor.
In the hands of any holder of the notes, bonds, debentures or securities, a guarantee signed in accordance with subsection (3) is conclusive evidence of compliance with that subsection.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make arrangements to supply the money necessary to fulfill the requirements of a guarantee under this section and may advance the amount necessary out of the consolidated revenue fund.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Form of securities
bcl:section.bcl:text: The notes, bonds, debentures and other securities authorized and issued by an improvement district must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bear the seal of the improvement district, and

together with any coupons attached to them, bear the manual, engraved, lithographed or printed signatures of the chair and the financial officer, or of other persons the improvement district board may, by bylaw, determine.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registration of securities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An improvement district that issues or has issued bonds or debentures must keep or cause to be kept, at the office of the improvement district or in the office of the registrar of the Ministry of Finance, a registry book in which

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owners of any of its bonds or debentures may register them as to principal only, and
transfers of bonds or debentures so registered may be registered.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Bonds or debentures of an improvement district pass by delivery unless registered as to principal in the name of the owner in the registry book, in which case the fact of registration must be noted on the bonds or debentures so registered.
After registration, a transfer of a bond or debenture is not valid unless it is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: made by instrument in writing signed by the registered owner or by the authorized attorney of the registered owner, and
registered in the registry book.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Registration of an instrument under subsection (3) must be noted on the bond or debenture.

The registration of a bond or debenture under this section may be discharged and the transferability of the bond or debenture by delivery restored by registration of a further transfer to the bearer of the bond or debenture that is similarly registered and noted on the bond or debenture as referred to in subsections (3) and (4).
After the registration of a bond or debenture has been discharged, its registration may again in like manner be effected or discharged.
Despite registration of a bond or debenture, the interest coupons continue to be payable to bearer and to be transferable by delivery.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Improvement district property exempt from taxation
bcl:section.bcl:text: The land and its improvements of an improvement district are exempt from taxation by the Provincial government, a regional district or a municipality including the City of Vancouver.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection from legal proceedings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A writ of execution against an improvement district may be issued only with the permission of the Supreme Court, and on the terms and conditions the court may specify.
The corporate seal, books, tools and office furniture, fixtures and fittings of an improvement district are exempt from seizure or sale by process of law.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Indemnification against proceedings

bcl:text.#text: An improvement district board has the power to indemnify against proceedings as set out in section 740 .

Without limiting subsection (1), the power to indemnify under that subsection applies in relation to the persons referred to in section 738 (1) (o), (p) or (r)  as though those persons were officers or employees of the improvement district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of receiver

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint a receiver to manage the affairs of an improvement district if it appears in the public interest to do so.
The receiver has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all the powers of the trustees and other officers of the improvement district, and
the exclusive control of the property, assets and revenues of the improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After the appointment of a receiver, an action may not be brought against the improvement district or receiver without the consent of the Supreme Court.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Legal Proceedings in Relation to Local Governments and Other Authorities

bcl:division.bcl:text: Legal Proceedings Against Municipality or Regional District

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Limitation period for certain actions
bcl:text: All actions against a municipality or regional district for the unlawful doing of anything that
must be commenced within 6 months after the cause of action first arose, or within a further period designated by the council or board in a particular case, but not afterwards.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is purported to have been done by the municipality or regional district under the powers conferred by an Act, and
might have been lawfully done by the municipality or regional district if acting in the manner established by law

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice requirement respecting damages

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A municipality or regional district is in no case liable for damages unless notice in writing, setting out the time, place and manner in which the damage has been sustained, is delivered to the municipality or regional district, as applicable, within 2 months from the date on which the damage was sustained.
In case of the death of a person injured, failure to give the notice required by this section is not a bar to the maintenance of the action.

Failure to give the notice required by this section or its insufficiency is not a bar to the maintenance of an action if the court before whom it is tried, or, in case of appeal, the Court of Appeal, believes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there was reasonable excuse, and
the defendant has not been prejudiced in its defence by the failure or insufficiency.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Proceedings against municipality or regional district in relation to damages caused by others

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a proceeding brought against a municipality or regional district to recover damages sustained by reason of an obstruction, excavation, cellar or opening in or adjoining a street, lane, square, public highway or bridge placed, made, left or maintained by a person other than an employee or agent of the municipality or regional district.

The municipality or regional district, as applicable, has a remedy over against the person referred to in subsection (1), and may enforce payment accordingly of any damages and costs that the plaintiff may recover against the municipality or regional district.
The municipality or regional district is entitled to the remedy over only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person referred to in subsection (1) is made a party to the proceeding, and

it is established as against that person that the damages were sustained because of an obstruction, excavation, cellar or opening placed, made, left or maintained by the person added as a defendant or third party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person referred to in subsection (1) may defend the proceeding against the plaintiff's claim and the claim of the municipality or regional district.
The court may order costs to be paid by or to any party or on any claim set up as in other cases.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity for individual local public officers

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of a council;
a director of a regional board;
a trustee of an improvement district;

bcl:text.#text: a commissioner for a local community commission under Division 9  of Part 6 ;
a member of a commission established under section 263 (1) (g) of this Act or section 143  of the ;
a member of a library board under the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of any greater board or of any board that provides similar services and is incorporated by letters patent;
a member of an advisory planning commission under section 461;

bcl:text.#text: a member of a board of variance under Division 15  of Part 14 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a member of the Okanagan-Kootenay Sterile Insect Release Board or an officer or employee of that board;
a member of the Okanagan Basin Water Board;

bcl:text.#text: a trustee of a body of the Islands Trust under the;

an officer or employee of a municipality, regional district, improvement district, library board under the , a greater board referred to in paragraph (g), the trust council under the  or the Okanagan Basin Water Board;

bcl:text.in:desc: [assent voting conducted by more than one local government]
bcl:text.#text: an election official or a regional voting officer under section 179 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a volunteer firefighter or a special constable;

a volunteer who participates in the delivery of services by a municipality, regional district or a body referred to in paragraphs (c) to (l) under the supervision of an officer or employee of the municipality, regional district or any of those bodies;

bcl:link.in:doc: Cremation, Interment and Funeral Services Act

bcl:text.#text: a member of a board of trustees established or appointed by a municipality under section 37  of the ;

a member of a municipal committee, of a regional district board committee or of an improvement district committee under section 689  who is not also a member of the municipal council, regional district board or improvement district board, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: No action for damages lies or may be instituted against a local public officer or former local public officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for anything said or done or omitted to be said or done by that person in the performance or intended performance of the person's duty or the exercise of the person's power, or
for any alleged neglect or default in the performance or intended performance of that person's duty or the exercise of that person's power.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not provide a defence if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the local public officer has, in relation to the conduct that is the subject matter of the action, been guilty of dishonesty, gross negligence or malicious or wilful misconduct, or
the cause of action is libel or slander.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not absolve any of the corporations or bodies referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (l) from vicarious liability arising out of a tort committed by any of the individuals referred to in subsection (1) for which the corporation or body would have been liable had this section not been in force.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warning as defence for local government financial officer
bcl:section.bcl:text: It is a good defence to any action brought against a municipal or regional district financial officer for unlawful expenditure of local government funds if it is proved that the individual gave a written and signed warning to the council or board that, in the individual's opinion, the expenditure would be unlawful.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Indemnification against proceedings for local government officials

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text: means the payment of amounts required or incurred

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to defend an action or prosecution brought against a person in connection with the exercise or intended exercise of the person's powers or the performance or intended performance of the person's duties or functions,
to satisfy a judgment, award or penalty imposed in an action or prosecution referred to in paragraph (a), or

bcl:text.#text: in relation to an inquiry under the , or to another proceeding, that involves the administration of the municipality or regional district or the conduct of municipal or regional district business;
means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a current or former council member,
a current or former municipal officer or employee, or

bcl:text.in:desc: [immunity for individual municipal local public officers]
bcl:text.#text: a person who is or was a person referred to in section 738 (1) , but only in relation to the exercise of powers or the performance of duties or functions for or on behalf of a municipality;
means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a current or former member of a regional district board,
a current or former officer or employee of a regional district, or
a person who is or was a person referred to in section 738 (1), but only in relation to the exercise of powers or the performance of duties or functions for or on behalf of the regional district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Indemnification for municipal officials and regional district officials may be provided as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a council may do the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by bylaw, provide for the indemnification of municipal officials in accordance with the bylaw;
by resolution in a specific case, indemnify a municipal official;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a board may do the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by bylaw, provide for the indemnification of regional district officials in accordance with the bylaw;
by resolution in a specific case, indemnify a regional district official.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: As a limit on indemnification under subsection (2), a council or board must not pay a fine that is imposed as a result of a municipal official or regional district official, as applicable, being convicted of an offence that is not a strict or absolute liability offence.

bcl:text.#text: Sections 100  and 101  of the  do not apply to a council member or board member who could be, or would be, indemnified under a bylaw or resolution under subsection (2) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), a council may not seek indemnity against a municipal official, and a board may not seek indemnity against a regional district official, in respect of any conduct of the person that results in a claim for damages against the municipality or regional district, as applicable.
The restriction under subsection (5) does not apply if the court makes a finding in the action that the person has been guilty of dishonesty, gross negligence or malicious or wilful misconduct.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Indemnification against proceedings for other local public officers

bcl:text.#text: Subject to subsection (2), section 740 applies to the following in relation to any person referred to in section 738 (1) :

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a greater board;
the Okanagan-Kootenay Sterile Insect Release Board;

bcl:text.#text: the trust council under the ;
a library board under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) applies only in relation to the exercise of powers or the performance of duties or functions for or on behalf of the applicable corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity in relation to building bylaw enforcement
bcl:section.bcl:text: A municipality or a member of its council, a regional district or a member of its board, or an officer or employee of a municipality or regional district, is not liable for any damages or other loss, including economic loss, sustained by any person, or to the property of any person, as a result of neglect or failure, for any reason, to enforce, by the institution of a civil proceeding or a prosecution,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Provincial building regulations,

bcl:text.#text: a bylaw under Division 1  of Part 9 ,
a bylaw under section 8 (3) (l)  of the , or
a bylaw under Division 8  of Part 3 of the .

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity in relation to approval of certified building plans

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a municipality or regional district issues a building permit for a development that does not comply with the Provincial building regulations or another applicable enactment respecting safety, the municipality or regional district must not be held liable, directly or vicariously, for any damage, loss or expense caused or contributed to by an error, omission or other neglect in relation to its approval of the plans submitted with the application for the building permit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person representing themselves as a professional engineer or architect registered as such under Provincial legislation certified, as or on behalf of the applicant for the permit, that the plans or the aspects of the plans to which the non-compliance relates complied with the then current Provincial building regulations or other applicable enactment to which the non-compliance relates, and
the municipality or regional district, in issuing the building permit, indicated in writing to the applicant for the permit that it relied on the certification referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the municipality or regional district knew that the person making the certification referred to in that subsection was not, at the time of certification, registered as a professional engineer or architect under Provincial legislation.

If a municipality or regional district makes an indication in accordance with subsection (1) (b), it must reduce the fee for the building permit to reflect the costs of the work that would otherwise be done by a building inspector to determine whether the plans or the aspects of the plans that were certified to comply do in fact comply with the Provincial building regulations and other applicable enactments respecting safety.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Immunity in relation to certain nuisance actions

bcl:text.#text: A municipality, municipal council, regional district, regional district board, improvement district or greater board is not liable in any action based on nuisance or on the rule in the  case if the damages arise, directly or indirectly, out of the breakdown or malfunction of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a sewer system,
a water or drainage facility or system, or
a dike or a road.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Enforcement of Court Orders Against Municipality or Regional District

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Writ of execution against municipality or regional district

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A writ of execution against a municipality or regional district must not be issued without leave of the Supreme Court, which may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permit its issue at a time and on conditions the court considers proper, or

refuse to permit it to be issued or suspend action under it on terms and conditions the court thinks proper or expedient, having regard to the reputed insolvency of the municipality or regional district and the security afforded to the person entitled to the judgment by the registration of the judgment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On being satisfied by affidavit by a competent person on behalf of the municipality or regional district that the municipality or regional district intends to appeal with due diligence from the judgment, the court may refuse to permit a writ of execution for costs to be issued unless security is given to the satisfaction of the court by the person to whom the costs are payable for their repayment to the municipality or regional district in the event the judgment is reversed or varied on appeal.
A writ of execution against a municipality may be endorsed with a direction to the sheriff to levy its amount by rate, and the proceedings on it are to be as provided in this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Copy of writ of execution to be left with corporate officer
bcl:section.bcl:text: The sheriff must deliver to the corporate officer of the municipality or regional district, as applicable, or leave at the office or dwelling house of that officer,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the writ of execution and endorsement, and

a statement in writing of the sheriff's fees, and of the amount required to satisfy the execution, including in the amount the interest calculated to a day as near as is convenient to the date of the delivery.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Local government officers as officers of the court for purposes of execution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For all purposes connected with carrying into effect, or permitting or assisting the sheriff to carry into effect, the provisions of this Division for executions, the corporate officer, the financial officer and the municipal collector, as applicable, are deemed to be officers of the court in which the writ was issued.
As officers of the court, the officials referred to in subsection (1) are accountable to the court, and may be proceeded against by attachment, or otherwise, to compel them to perform their duties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certain local government property exempt from seizure
bcl:section.bcl:text: The corporate seal, tools, machinery, equipment and records, office furniture, fixtures and fittings of a municipality or regional district are exempt from forced seizure or sale by any process of law.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tax to be imposed if amount not paid by municipality

bcl:text.in:desc: [copy of writ to be delivered to corporate officer]
bcl:text.#text: If, in relation to a municipality, the amount, with interest on it from the day mentioned in the statement under section 746 , is not paid to the sheriff within one month after service under that section, the sheriff must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: examine the assessment rolls of the municipality, and
establish a rate sufficient to cover the amount due on the execution, with an addition to it that the sheriff considers sufficient to cover the interest and the sheriff's own fees.

bcl:text.#text: A rate under subsection (1) must be established in the same manner as a rate under section 197 (1) (a)  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After establishing the rate, the sheriff must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a direction to the collector of the municipality,
attach to the direction either the roll of the rate or particulars of it, and
after stating the writ, stating that the municipality had neglected to satisfy it and referring to the roll or the particulars, direct the collector to promptly levy the rate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Payment of municipal amount levied

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, at the time of levying a rate under a direction of the sheriff, the tax notices for that year have not been issued, the collector must add a column on the notices, headed "Execution Rate in A.B. v. the Corporation", and must insert in it the amount required to be levied under the direction.
If subsection (1) does not apply, the collector must proceed to issue separate tax notices for the execution rate.
The collector must with all due diligence return to the sheriff the direction with the amount levied.
After satisfying the execution and all fees on it, the sheriff must pay any surplus within 10 days after receiving it to the municipal financial officer, for the general purposes of the municipality.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Self-insurance by local authorities

bcl:text.#text: In this section,  means a municipality, a regional district or an improvement district.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local authority may, with one or more other local authorities,

bcl:text.#text: enter into a scheme of self-insurance protection under section 187  of the  or under the , or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the consent of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions, enter into a joint scheme of self-insurance protection.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For a regional district, a scheme under subsection (2) may have a single deductible for any number of services.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of this Part in relation to the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing the modifications considered necessary or advisable for applying this Part for the purposes of paragraphs 133, 135 and 138 of the Nisg̱a'a Government Chapter of the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement.

bcl:text.#text: The authority to make regulations under subsection (1) applies to provisions of the  enacted in substitution for or replacement of provisions of this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of this Part to treaty first nations
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing modifications considered necessary or advisable for applying this Part for the purposes of a final agreement that provides the treaty first nation or its government with some or all of the same protections, immunities, limitations in respect of liability, remedies over and rights provided to a municipality and its council and public officers under this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board of examiners

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: There is to be a board of examiners for the purposes of this Division, composed of 3 members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council on the recommendation of the minister, of whom

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one must be nominated by the Union of British Columbia Municipalities,
one must be nominated by the Local Government Management Association of British Columbia, and
one must be nominated by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The members of the board of examiners hold office for a term of 3 years or until their successors are appointed.
If a vacancy occurs because of the death or resignation of a member, the member's successor must be nominated and appointed in the same manner as the member originally nominated and appointed.

The members of the board of examiners must not receive remuneration for their services, but must be paid by the minister the amount of their travelling and other personal expenses necessarily incurred by them in the discharge of their official duties.
A member of the board of examiners may be nominated and reappointed for further terms.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers of board

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board of examiners may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish qualifications and standards for municipal, regional district or improvement district employment according to office and grades;
grant certificates according to grades and skill to persons possessing the qualifications and meeting the standards;
set and hold examinations for, or pass on the credentials of, a person who is a candidate for a certificate;
cancel a certificate on proof of dishonesty or gross negligence on the part of the holder.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The powers and duties of the board of examiners must be exercised and performed in accordance with any applicable regulations made by the board.
The records of the board of examiners and the administrative duties in connection with them are the responsibility of the inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Board may make regulations
bcl:section.bcl:text: With the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council on the recommendation of the minister, the board of examiners may make regulations respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the exercise and performance of its powers and duties,
examinations and certificates, and
any other matter within the jurisdiction of the board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application to City of Vancouver
bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division applies to the City of Vancouver.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inspector of municipalities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint an inspector of municipalities who, in addition to the powers and duties established under this Act, has the powers and duties that may be assigned to the inspector.
The inspector is to be attached to the office of the minister and is to be under the control of the minister.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Official seal and records

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The inspector is to have an official seal inscribed with the words "Inspector of Municipalities of British Columbia".

Every paper record purporting to be issued by the inspector and impressed with the seal of the office is admissible in evidence in all courts of British Columbia without proof of the sealing or of the signature of the inspector, or of the inspector's deputy, to the record.

A copy of a record of the office of the inspector, or a copy of a record kept in the inspector's office, that is certified to be a true copy by the inspector or the inspector's deputy is admissible in evidence in all courts of British Columbia as of equal validity with the original record.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate of approval for money bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government that adopts any of the following bylaws may apply to the inspector for a certificate approving the bylaw:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a loan authorization bylaw;
a security issuing bylaw;
a bylaw imposing a special assessment or a special rate under any Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), the inspector must not grant a certificate

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: until after the time limit for giving notice of intention to make an application to court to quash the bylaw, or
while a proceeding that calls the validity of the bylaw into question, or that seeks to quash the bylaw, is pending.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the time limit referred to in subsection (2) (a) has passed before the application for inspector approval is made under subsection (1), the inspector may, in the inspector's discretion,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disregard any proceeding in which the validity of the bylaw is in question that was commenced after the application for approval was made, and
proceed to give the certificate of approval without reference to the proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A certificate given under subsection (3) has the same effect as if the action or other proceeding had not been commenced.
If a bylaw has been approved, the inspector may also approve the debentures or other securities issued in conformity with it.
A certificate issued under subsection (5) may bear the actual or lithographed signature of the inspector.
The inspector's decision on granting, withholding or refusing a certificate is not subject to an application for judicial review or any other proceeding in any court of British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inquiry into application for certificate

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The inspector may direct and hold an inquiry into an application for a certificate under this Division, and may hear and determine protests.
An inquiry under this section may be held by the inspector, a deputy of the inspector or another person authorized by the inspector.

bcl:text.#text: Section 764 (3) and (4)  applies to an inquiry under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal from inspector's decisions in relation to borrowing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appeal lies to the minister from a decision of the inspector

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refusing to approve a loan authorization bylaw, or
withholding or refusing a certificate applied for under this Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an appeal under subsection (1), the minister must hear and determine the matter, and may confirm, vary or rescind the decision of the inspector.
The determination on the appeal is conclusive and binding on all parties, including the inspector.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate conclusive of validity

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The production of a certificate issued under this Division or of the certified copy of a certificate is, in all courts and places and for all purposes, conclusive evidence that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the bylaw, debenture or other security described in or covered by the certificate has been validly made and issued, and
all statutory and other requirements have been complied with.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The validity of a bylaw, debenture or other security referred to in subsection (1) may not be attacked, questioned or adjudicated on in any proceeding in any court of British Columbia.
A certificate under this Division may be in the following form:

oasis:line.#text: Under the authority of the , I certify that this [bylaw has been lawfully and validly made and enacted] [ debenture or other security has been lawfully made and issued, ] and that its validity is not open to question on any ground in any court of British Columbia.

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Inspector of Municipalities of British Columbia

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inquiries into local government matters

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: With the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, the inspector may hold an inquiry if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the inspector considers it expedient to make an inquiry into or concerning a matter connected with a municipality or regional district or the conduct of a part of its business, or
a complaint is made to the inspector about a matter of municipal or regional district business, actual or projected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An inquiry under this section may be held by the inspector, a deputy of the inspector or another person authorized by the inspector and must be open to the public.

bcl:text.#text: For the purposes of an inquiry under this section, the person holding the inquiry has the powers, privileges and protection of a commission under sections 16, 17, 22 (1), 23 (a), (b) and (d) to (f) and 32 of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The costs, fees and expenses of the inquiry must be paid by the municipality or regional district, as applicable.
During an inquiry, the person holding the inquiry may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct that no action be taken by the council or board on any or all matters designated by the person holding the inquiry;
direct municipal or regional district employees not to proceed with any matter designated by the person holding the inquiry;
suspend a municipal or regional district officer or employee if the person holding the inquiry considers the conduct of the officer or employee warrants suspension.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The person holding the inquiry may rescind or amend a direction or suspension under subsection (5).
Subject to rescission or amendment, a direction or suspension under subsection (5) remains in effect until an order is made under subsection (9).
The person holding the inquiry must report to the Lieutenant Governor in Council

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the evidence received,
on any direction or suspension under subsection (5), and
on the person's recommendations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receipt of the report under subsection (8), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make an order that the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers is in the public interest.

An order under subsection (9) is binding on the municipality or regional district, its council or board, and every elected or appointed official, officer and employee of the municipality or regional district in the same way as if it were a regulation made by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional inquiry authority in relation to regional districts

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The council of a member municipality of a regional district, or a director of an electoral area of the regional district, may make a complaint to the inspector regarding any bylaw, order, decision or action of the board.
If a complaint is received, the inspector, or a person authorized by the inspector, may hold an inquiry.
An inquiry under this section must be open to the public.
Section 764 (3) and (4) applies to the person holding the inquiry under this section.
The person holding the inquiry must report to the Lieutenant Governor in Council on the evidence received and the representations and argument made and must make recommendations.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, on receipt of the report referred to in subsection (5), make an order.
An order under subsection (6) is binding on the board.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:text.#text: means a commissioner appointed for a jurisdiction under this Division;
means a municipality or regional district.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of administrative commissioner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint a commissioner for a jurisdiction

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a report of the inspector that the jurisdiction has failed to or cannot make due provision for the payment of either the principal of or the interest on a debenture issued or guaranteed by the jurisdiction, when the payment is due, or
if authorized by an order of the Supreme Court under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a jurisdiction for any reason fails to provide for the payment of either the principal of or the interest on a debenture issued or guaranteed by the jurisdiction, when the payment is due, any creditor or elector of the jurisdiction may apply to the Supreme Court for an order authorizing the appointment of a commissioner for the jurisdiction to carry out the duties and functions provided for in this Division.
This section applies to a debenture of which, under any Act, the jurisdiction has been made responsible for the payment of the principal and the interest.

A commissioner has all the powers and authority that, before the appointment, were vested in or exercisable by the local government, the mayor or chair of the jurisdiction, the municipal police board, the parks commission, the civic properties commission, any other local government commission, the board of education and the officers of the jurisdiction.
A commissioner must be paid out of the jurisdiction's revenue the salary and other expenses incidental to the commissionership as authorized by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Substitution of commissioner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may at any time cancel the appointment of a commissioner and, on that cancellation, all the powers vested in that commissioner under this Act end.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint another commissioner for the jurisdiction to replace a person whose appointment is cancelled under subsection (1).
If a commissioner dies, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint another commissioner for the jurisdiction as a replacement.
A commissioner appointed under subsection (2) or (3) has all the powers and authority vested in a commissioner by this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Acting commissioner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: With the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, a commissioner may appoint a person as acting commissioner.
An acting commissioner under subsection (1) has and may exercise all the powers and authority of the commissioner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during any temporary absence of the commissioner, or
if the commissioner is for any reason unable to perform the commissioner's duties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the acting commissioner appears to have acted in the exercise of any power or authority of the commissioner, it is conclusively deemed that the acting commissioner acted for one of the reasons referred to in subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers transferred to commissioner

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the appointment of a commissioner,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the members of the local government, the municipal police board members, the parks commissioners, the civic properties commissioners, any other local government commissioners and all officers of the jurisdiction are deemed to have retired from office, and

all the rights, powers and authority vested in or exercisable by the local government, the mayor or chair of the jurisdiction, the municipal police board, the parks commission, the civic properties commission, any other local government commission and other officers of the jurisdiction under any Act are vested in and exercisable by the commissioner.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section does not prevent the full exercise by the commissioner of the powers exercisable by the local government or other municipal body relative to the appointment, control or removal of its officers and employees.
On the appointment of a commissioner,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the school trustees elected in that jurisdiction for the school district of which the jurisdiction is comprised or forms a part are deemed to have retired from office, and
with the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, the commissioner must appoint a sufficient number of persons to maintain the jurisdiction's quota of school trustees.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may confer on a commissioner any rights, powers and authority that could by order be conferred on a council under any Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power of commissioner to make bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A commissioner may adopt bylaws that might be adopted by the local government.

The commissioner must submit a bylaw under subsection (1) for the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council and, on being approved by the Lieutenant Governor in Council, and on being registered if required, the bylaw comes into force and is valid and binding in all respects as a bylaw of the jurisdiction.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers of commissioner to borrow

bcl:text.#text: Despite this Act or the , a commissioner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may make, amend and repeal bylaws authorizing the borrowing from any person of amounts referred to in subsection (2), and
subject to this section, may borrow under a bylaw referred to in paragraph (a) from any person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bylaw under subsection (1) may authorize the borrowing of amounts on the credit of the jurisdiction, not repayable within the same year, that may be necessary for the replacement or reconstruction of, or for the purchase, construction and installation of, alterations, extensions or additions to existing services of the jurisdiction or any matter or thing connected with them.
A bylaw adopted under subsection (1) may make provision for granting to the lender the security approved by the minister, and the commissioner may grant that security under the bylaw.

Before the adoption of a bylaw under subsection (1), the terms of the bylaw, the nature of the security to be issued and the terms of repayment must be submitted in detail to and be approved by the minister, who may impose the conditions the minister considers advisable.
A bylaw under subsection (1) does not come into force until approved by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

Proof of the approval of the bylaw by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under subsection (5) is, in all courts and places and for all purposes, conclusive evidence that the bylaw has been lawfully and validly made, and that all statutory and other requirements have been complied with.
The validity of a bylaw under subsection (1) must not be attacked or questioned or adjudicated on in any proceeding in a court in British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Taxes for sinking fund purposes
bcl:section.bcl:text: With the approval of the inspector, a commissioner may, by bylaw, determine what amount, if any, is to be imposed or provided for sinking fund purposes in any year.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Parcel tax rolls

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All the powers vested in the council as to a parcel tax roll review panel are vested in the commissioner.

bcl:text: A parcel tax roll for a jurisdiction for which a commissioner has been appointed,
is deemed to be valid and binding on the jurisdiction and on all persons.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: as authenticated by the parcel tax roll review panel or by the commissioner or acting commissioner purporting to sit as the parcel tax roll review panel, and
as further determined and confirmed on appeal from the parcel tax roll review panel,

bcl:text.#text: A complaint to the parcel tax roll review panel or an appeal to the Supreme Court, as provided under the , must not be sustained or allowed on the grounds that land in a jurisdiction for which a commissioner is appointed has been valued at too high an amount, if the assessment complained of or appealed against is not more than the assessed value of the same land according to the authenticated real property assessment roll for the year immediately preceding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) applies despite any Act, but without affecting the provisions of an Act relating to complaints or appeals against assessments of improvements.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Differences between commissioner and board of education
bcl:section.bcl:text: Any difference arising between the commissioner and the board of education on matters generally within the jurisdiction of the board of education must be determined by the Lieutenant Governor in Council, whose decision is final.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Commissioner reports to minister
bcl:section.bcl:text: The commissioner must report to the minister as directed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Election after commissioner appointed

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by regulation, provide for the election of a local government for a jurisdiction for which a commissioner has been appointed.

On the election of a local government under subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, revoke the powers and authority vested in the commissioner and, on that revocation, the local government has and may exercise all the powers and authority conferred by statute or by law on a local government of that type.

If provision for an election is made under subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may also make regulations for the election of the required number of school trustees and, on their election, may by order terminate any appointment made by the commissioner under section 770.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restriction on legal proceedings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In relation to a jurisdiction for which there is at the time a commissioner appointed under this Division, a person must not, except with the consent of the Attorney General,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: commence or continue a proceeding in any court in British Columbia in respect of or for the recovery of either the principal of or the interest on a debenture or other security issued by or guaranteed by the jurisdiction or for the payment of which the jurisdiction is liable, or

commence or continue a proceeding in or out of a court in British Columbia in respect of or for the recovery of either the principal of or the interest on a debenture or other security guaranteed by the jurisdiction, if the property pledged or hypothecated in security of the debt represented by the debenture or security was not the property of the jurisdiction at the time of the pledge or hypothecation, but is at the commencement or continuance of the proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) (a) applies despite any Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Regulations for purposes of this Division

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations to carry this Division into effect.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to remove any difficulty that may arise in the administration by the commissioner, and
prescribing procedures governing the commissioner's administration that are considered desirable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Publication of letters patent

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the issue of letters patent under this Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister must publish a notice in the Gazette in the form prescribed under subsection (2), and
the municipal council, regional district board or improvement district trustees, as applicable, must publish in a newspaper

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of the letters patent, or
a synopsis that states where the letters patent may be examined and, if a boundary description is set out in the synopsis, where a map of the boundary description may be viewed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing the form of notice under subsection (1) (a).

bcl:text.#text: Letters patent issued for the purpose of giving effect to a final agreement within the meaning of section 29.1 of the  may exempt a municipality or regional district from the requirements under subsection (1) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Further powers in relation to assets
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may confer on a local government further powers to manage and dispose of assets, including taxation revenue, that the minister considers necessary or advisable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeal to minister respecting construction of drains

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may appeal to the minister if,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in order to provide an outlet for a surface drain, the person must continue the drain into an adjoining parcel of land or across or along a highway, and
the owner of an adjoining parcel or the council refuses to enter into an agreement under which the drain may be continued.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an appeal under subsection (1), the minister may direct the municipality or regional district, as applicable, to provide the necessary works and may determine by whom the cost of the works must be borne.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Power to make regulations

bcl:text.#text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41  of the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations respecting any matter for which regulations of the Lieutenant Governor in Council are contemplated by this Act.

bcl:text.#text: In addition to any other variation authority that is specifically provided, a regulation that may be made by the Lieutenant Governor in Council or a minister under any provision of this Act, or of the  as it is made applicable under this Act, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish different classes of bylaws, municipalities, regional districts, local governments, other bodies governed by this Act, persons, property, circumstances, things and other matters,
make different provisions, including exceptions, for different classes referred to in paragraph (a), and

make different provisions, including exceptions, for different bylaws, different municipalities, different regional districts, different local governments, different bodies governed by this Act, different areas or different parts of areas of municipalities or regional districts, different areas or different parts of areas of other bodies governed by this Act and different circumstances, things and other matters.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — public hearings

bcl:text.#text: Section 464 (3)  does not apply in relation to a proposed zoning bylaw that, on the date this section comes into force, has been given first reading.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — extended compliance period for small-scale multi-family housing

bcl:text.#text: Despite section 481.3 (2) , if a local government applies under section 786 for an extension of time in relation to an area, the local government must adopt a zoning bylaw that complies with section 481.3, in relation to the area, as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the extension is granted, on or before the date set out in the notice of extension;
if the extension is refused, within 90 days after the date set out in the notice of refusal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A local government must give to the minister written notice as soon as practicable after the local government has adopted the last zoning bylaw necessary to comply with section 481.3, other than a zoning bylaw necessary to comply with section 481.3 in relation to an area for which an extension of time is granted under section 786 to the local government.
